At least we could load into Arkham City. Feeling like Batman made Arkham Asylum a must-play, and Arkham City continues that tradition. Arkham City isn't an open world like we seen in other games; it's more like a hub world with a bunch of dungeons. The voice acting is superb, the challenges are inviting, the amazing opening which puts you in the city is dark, the unbelievable ending with his little twists is surprising and again you are feeling of being Batman. The freeflow combat system (you select the direction of his assault and unleash the procedural animation system, shattering his opponents with punches and kicks) is still easy to learn and hard to master to keep combos up and running. It is a worth successor to Arkham Asylum. But again Riddler is there  and he pumped up his game with 400-some Riddler Challenges - still annoying.

Honestly one of my best game experiences of all time. I might be bit biased by nostalgia and being a Batman fan, but even trying to keep that aside it's a must play. The gameplay is fun, plot is also good, they have the OG voice actors for Batman and Joker. The enemies are funny and the music is awesome. The artstyle is great and still holds up, game still looks great.

They really improved what didn't work from the previous game, while further improving what *did* work. The combat feels more satisfying and fluid, with some new features. The game is more open-world than Asylum so there's a lot to explore, There's a lot of side missions to do too. Stealth is given more tools and variety, which makes it more enjoyable to do. The boss fights has been hugely improved as well. The story is considered to be the best in the franchise, so that's a plus.

[h1] Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition [/h1]

[h3] Pros: [/h3] [b]🦇 Compelling Storyline[/b] Batman: Arkham City features a gripping narrative that immerses players in the dark and atmospheric world of Gotham City. The intricate plot, filled with twists and turns, keeps players engaged from start to finish, delivering an unforgettable Batman experience. 🌃📖

[b]🎮 Fluid Combat System[/b] The game boasts a seamless combat system that allows players to unleash Batman's martial arts prowess with fluidity and precision. Combining punches, counters, and gadgets creates exhilarating and visually stunning combat sequences. 💥👊

[h3] Cons: [/h3] [b]🤔 Overemphasis on Combat[/b] While combat in Batman: Arkham City is satisfying, some players may feel that there is an overemphasis on combat encounters at the expense of other gameplay elements such as exploration and puzzle-solving. A more balanced approach to gameplay mechanics could enhance the overall experience. ⚖️🔍

[b]🦇 Technical Issues[/b] Despite its acclaim, the game suffers from occasional technical issues, including bugs, glitches, and performance optimization issues, which may detract from immersion and frustrate players. Improved stability and polish would elevate the gaming experience. 🐞⚙️

[h3] Other Downsides: [/h3] [b]🔊 Repetitive Side Missions[/b] Some of the side missions in Batman: Arkham City may feel repetitive or formulaic, leading to a sense of monotony for players seeking varied and engaging content outside of the main storyline. More diverse and innovative side quests could remedy this issue. 🔄📝

[b]🌎 Limited Open World Exploration[/b] Despite the expansive open-world environment, some players may find the exploration aspects of Batman: Arkham City somewhat limited or constrained, with fewer opportunities for meaningful interaction with the city and its inhabitants. A more dynamic and interactive open-world design could enhance immersion and player agency. 🗺️🔍

[b]Good Points[/b]
[list]
[*]Compelling storyline set in the dark and atmospheric world of Gotham City.
[*]Fluid combat system with seamless martial arts action.
[*]Rich and detailed environments that capture the essence of Batman's universe.
[/list]
[b]Bad Points[/b]
[list]
[*]Overemphasis on combat mechanics.
[*]Occasional technical issues and performance optimization problems.
[*]Repetitive side missions and limited open-world exploration.
[/list]

Arkham City is one of those games where the player needs to really invest their mind and time into everything that's going on around the game world and the story.

On the surface level , everything might seem simple and straight foward but there's a lot happening /happened behind the scenes that the game never forces you to know , it's right under your nose. Collecting the riddler trophies might seem like a waste of time with no rewarding factor than just filling a counter in the statistics screen but that's simply not true , it rewards you with lore , arkham stories , character bios and tapes you can listen to. 

Pay a little more attention to the environment and you"ll figure out how everything in this prison city came to be. Listen to the random converstions among thugs for valuable info , jokes and even lore that you might have missed or didn't read.

Simply put , Arkham City is a gourmet meal and such meals are better consumed slowly while savouring the taste of every bite. The Characters , the atmosphere , the combat and the gadgets , everything flows together so well like peanut buter and jelly. 

Besides a few wasted characters such as Bane and ivy , everything about the game fine asf.

[h1]Arkham City: Soaring Above Expectations[/h1]

[h2]Story[/h2]

"You have the right to remain silent. You have the right to a lawyer. I'm not a lawyer." Rocksteady Studios weaves a complex web of intrigue, pitting the Dark Knight against a rogues' gallery of his most notorious adversaries. The story takes place within the walls of Arkham City, a sprawling prison district housing Gotham's most dangerous criminals. With Two-Face stirring the pot, Joker playing his usual chaotic hand, and shadowy figures lurking in the background, Batman must unravel the mysteries at play while facing his own internal struggles.

The narrative is masterfully crafted, packed with twists and turns that will keep you guessing until the very end. The characters, both heroes and villains, are brought to life with exceptional voice acting and writing, each with their own unique motivations and personalities. Humor is sprinkled throughout, providing welcome moments of levity amidst the darkness. But it's not all just brawls and gadgets; the story delves into themes of morality, justice, and the true cost of vengeance, leaving you pondering long after the credits roll.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]

Arkham City is a joy to play. The free-flowing combat system is addictive, allowing you to chain together bone-crunching combos with effortless grace. Taking down thugs feels incredibly satisfying, thanks to the responsive controls and impactful animations. Stealth mechanics are equally well-polished, letting you outsmart enemies with strategic takedowns and gadgets like the Batarang and smoke grenades.

The open-world environment is a highlight, brimming with secrets to uncover and side missions to complete. Soaring through the skies as Batman is exhilarating, and the detailed environments, from the gritty industrial zones to the opulent opera house, are a treat to explore. The Game of the Year Edition includes all the DLC, adding even more content and challenges to keep you engaged for hours.

[h3]Minor quibbles:** While the core gameplay is fantastic, there are a few minor issues. Some boss battles can feel repetitive, and the Riddler's collectibles can become tedious after a while. However, these are minor drawbacks in an otherwise exceptional experience.[/h3]

[h2]Graphics & Sound[/h2]

Arkham City is dark and atmospheric, perfectly capturing the essence of Gotham City. The character models are detailed, and the environments are richly textured. The lighting and shadow effects are particularly impressive, creating a truly immersive atmosphere. The sound design is equally top-notch, with the score perfectly complementing the action and the voice acting being superb. Kevin Conroy's iconic portrayal of Batman is a particular highlight, adding another layer of authenticity to the experience.

[h2]Overall[/h2]

Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition is a must-play for any fan of superhero games or action-adventure titles. It delivers an engaging story, exceptional gameplay, and a stunning presentation. With its wealth of content and replayability, this is an experience that will stay with you long after you've put down the controller. So, if you're looking for a game that will take you on a thrilling journey through the heart of Gotham City, look no further than Arkham City. Just remember, the night is darkest before the dawn... and Batman is always watching.

::Helpful Tip::
To change your keyboard controls, you need to open your drive (C:\) and then go to the following:
Program Files (x86) -> Steam -> steamapps -> common -> Batman Arkham City GOTY -> Binaries -> Win32
When you do that, you search for BmLauncher, click it to launch the game, and change your keybinds.

Rarely sequels are better than the original... but "Arkham City", the follow up to "Batman: Arkham Asylum", was one of the exceptions to the rule. Not only did it improve on its bland and disappointing predecessor in every possible way, not only it turned out to be one of the best superhero games ever produced, but also it can be counted among the top games in any genre, period. Its not at all necessary to be a fan of the character to enjoy this gem... and I'd argue, its not necessary to play the first game in the series either. Beyond a couple of references to the original, the series could have started at this chapter just as well, and this is what I'd recommend to new players of the Arkham games: It isn't worth it to complete Arkham Asylum just to see the whole story.

The game takes place in a whole section of Gotham City, closed down and turned into a big prison complex, where criminals and supercriminals have free for all and fight among themselves for control. In terms of the gameplay, though, Arkham City represents an open game space where you, the player, can freely travel from spot to spot, climb buildings and swing between them. The mobility, once you get the hang of the game, is superb. Very aerial, just moving around the city becomes an exciting experience, while the non linear nature of the missions and collectibles give you a remarkable feeling of freedom and keeps you interested in the game.

No gameplay feature in "City" is underused... from the exciting and greatly expanded combat, to the numerous gadgets you can employ in many, often creative ways. Most importantly, Arkham City received a lot of surprising attention to detail in regards to interactivity, specially how the enemies and the environment react to certain player actions. Experimenting with the game is often rewarded. The stealth sequences are also greatly improved from Asylum, they're harder, they demand a bit more thinking and skill from the player. They're fun.

But the main dish is still Batman kung fu, and the game doesn't disappoint in this area. The variety and creativity you can invest in your fighting against large groups of foes, greatly honors its Batman license. Furthermore, you aren't limited to play as the Dark Knight this time, and best of all, the other characters all feel very enjoyable and different to Batman.., each has its own set of moves to fight and means of travel. This feature expands the already good variety and replayability of the game quite a bit.

In contrast to the campy, '60s style Batman of the previous game, this is a more modern take featuring a lot more brutality and grit, both in visuals and in writing. The gothic style of the art design coupled with a gameplay-focused architecture, results in a visually compelling, but at the same time entertaining, Arkham City. And the costumed criminals, Batman's main foes, are so much better written and delivered by the voice actors in comparison. They actually feel like the violent, psychopatic, disturbed criminals they're supposed to be. Gone are the endless, and senseless, Joker ramblings on the comm from the first game. Here, all the voice work has a purpose in the narrative. The story line branches a lot more, its not on rails anymore... many things are happening at the same time, not to mention it is more "noir" flavored, and more logical too... without the huge plot holes and implausibilities from the first game.

Perhaps the only design problem from Arkham City is the lack of proper, satisfactory difficulty settings with less of a skill gap. This is a problem which, in fact, seems aggravated from Asylum. "Easy" is, well, easy. Its alright for casual or young players. The normal difficulty, though, is still rather low, and underwhelming for an experienced player... while the "hard" difficulty is incredibly tough to just anybody. While "hard" becomes satisfying after the player truly learns the combat system from experience and gains some skill perks, its almost impossible to beat for a new player, skilled or not. I think an intermediate difficulty, between "normal" and "hard", is missing from the game.

Batman: Arkham City, is still a fantastic game in the present day, even after all these years since its release. Its a modern classic which has never been outdated by modern games, simply because all of its individual components were polished to near perfection and still work so well together. In this sense, Arkham City is like Batman himself, who trained his mind and body to their peak in the process of wearing the cape. And he's still relevant as a character today, after more than 80 years of comic books.

So, it's been a while since I've played arkham city. But on memory, I'd wholeheartedly recommend it. It has some flaws I would say, one of them being, the story feels a little messy at times. But the presentation is amazing. I think the main thing I love about arkham city is how much of a 'video game' it feels. It sounds weird, but the way it's structured, is really immersive. In the sense that, now you're in the sewers looking for a way to the lazarus pit so you can help freeze, that kind of thing, like it finds really fun excuses to put you in new environments.
I think, the boss fights are a little weak overall, because the gameplay is inherently limited in how much it can stretch the player, but the existence of them really helps the game to feel more cohesive too, summarising every big gameplay segment in nice chapters. The soundtrack is, amazing, I can't put into words how good the music is. The gameplay itself is extremely fun, I'm just a big fan of the arkham series combat, particularly on hard difficulty. I understand some people find it a little annoying to spam, personally I really like it as more of a rythm/timing sort of thing, instead of spamming, but any play style is fine, it's not like theres a 'right way' to play. 
What else. Gameplays fun, story presentation is fun. Story elements are a little messy, 
[spoiler] hugo strange was a little disappointing as a villain, he didn't do much. [/spoiler]
But yeah, overall it just feels so immersive and cinematic without taking away control or sort of, overly hiding that it's a video game. It's not afraid to make you do X thing to unlock Y area, but presents it in a way that just feels really fun. You're not exactly sure why you're punching a shark over ice, but it feels purposeful. Sure, it feels like convenient that the only reason you're chasing the ninja is because they happened to be in the museum with freeze and now you need the lazarus pit, BUT, now you're chasing a ninja on the rooftops with a decent story justification and the music is great.
[spoiler] Sure it's a bit weird that batman is carrying the joker out like that at the end, considering the joker is literally evil, I prefer incarnations of batman who genuinely despise the joker, however, the way it's presented felt like a sort of, I dunno, meta sort of respect/sendoff to the character/voice acting, it's hard to describe, but it just felt impactful in a way that goes beyond the story, cinematic, emotional, etc. Like a send off to the whole 'fun' of the characters, not so much the actual in universe character. [/spoiler]
So yeah, overall. I'd recommend arkham city, for sure. Great game. 
Hmm, I guess one thing I would say is that I think the game is a little disrespectful in how it treats the female characters, they all seem to be designed to appeal to a fantasy and make batman feel more 'cool' rather than being actual characters. But other than that it's a great game.

Batman: Arkham City is an exceptional game that truly captures the essence of being the Dark Knight. As a fan of the Batman franchise, I was blown away by the immersive world, gripping storyline, and addictive gameplay.

The open-world environment of Arkham City is beautifully crafted, allowing me to freely explore Gotham City and its iconic landmarks. The attention to detail is remarkable, from the gritty streets to the towering skyscrapers, creating a truly immersive experience.

The storyline is captivating, filled with twists and turns that keep you engaged from start to finish. The game introduces a wide range of memorable characters from the Batman universe, each with their own unique personalities and motivations. The voice acting is top-notch, with Mark Hamill's portrayal of the Joker being particularly outstanding.

Combat in Arkham City is fluid and satisfying. The game offers a variety of combat moves and gadgets that allow you to take down enemies with style. The stealth mechanics are also well-implemented, giving you the option to silently eliminate foes or engage in intense hand-to-hand combat.

Graphically, the game is stunning for it's time, with detailed character models and impressive visual effects. The soundtrack perfectly complements the dark and atmospheric tone of the game, further immersing you in Batman's world.

Overall, Batman: Arkham City is a must-play for fans of the Caped Crusader. It offers a rich and immersive experience, combining a compelling storyline, addictive gameplay, and stunning visuals. Whether you're a die-hard Batman fan or simply enjoy action-adventure games, Arkham City is a title that should not be missed.

The pinnacle of Batman.

This game introduced me to many things. It helped me find an appreciation for comics, an appreciation for game design, and an appreciation for voice acting. I've seen many reviewers dock points from this game for having very simplistic combat mechanics and while yes it is simple enough to learn, there is so much to master. The variety of ways to bust absolute ass is insane and it is incredibly fun to mess around with the mechanics of all of Batman's gadgets and skills. The amount of in universe lore and information about the history of Batman as a whole is nothing short of fantastic. These are supplemental details, but they show that Rocksteady gave the needed care and love that makes a game like this so great and, for the interested party, rewards the player with information in and out of game. As far as voice acting goes, it should go without saying that it is chock full of knockout performances. The late and great Kevin Conroy was amazing here, which is saying a lot because I think this is far from his best performance as Batman. The intensity Conroy exudes while in the role fits the setting perfectly and makes Batman feel like an impending force that should be feared. Mark Hamill is stellar as usual as The Joker, from the maniacal laugh to the incredibly well written dialogue between him and Batman, this may be Hamill's best performance as Joker. The supporting cast is nothing to write off either. The cold and calculated tones of Mr. Freeze that Maurice LaMarche brings is genuinely chilling. Nolan North as The Penguin is a stellar performance and is a perfect fit for the role with the heavy cockney accent and condescending lines. Tara Strong's Harley Quinn is fantastic and bombastic as usual and she always brings a fun performance whenever the character is on screen.

If you have any interest in comics, super heroes, voice acting, music, atmosphere, or simply just want a great game to play then look no further. 10/10.

Best story of the three Arkham games.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand—the hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed—the hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

Way better than I remember and way better than Arkham Asylum. Improves on the combat by introducing new enemies and new special moves and gadgets while also making it seem faster, extending that freeflow combat to new areas never before seen in a Batman game. It completely wipes Asylum's terrible boss fights, dishing out some variety and even puzzle solving, (I.E. the Mr. Freeze fight). The setting itself is as great and atmospheric as ever, building up the dangerous foes you have to fight and adding great bits of environmental storytelling. I wouldn't say it's a perfect game, there is still some tedious padding when it comes to the plot, like when you have to disable jammers, do those stupid password thingies, play those Catwoman missions, etc, a lot of these missions are just stringing Batman along. The side quests are mostly good, some are better than others but man, doing Riddler challenges and getting the trophies just to progress on that one side quests was ridiculous, I hate trying to get those! Batman also sounds a little tired, at least compared to the last game, I also dislike how he blatantly tells the player what to do sometimes or talks outloud, a bit hand-hold-y there, Bats.  Good game, decent story, fun gameplay, you already know you'll like this if you are a Batman fan.

This game is truly the embodiment of what it feels like to be the Dark Knight. This is the game that not only surpassed its predecessor 'Arkham Asylum', but set a new standard for how a superhero narrative can be done and done successfully. 
From the further improvements on combat, the predator sections, new gadgets and combat integration, the vast new Arkham City that is at least triple the size of Arkham Asylum with unique lore drops and background information as to why certain events occur that were hinted all the way back in Asylum. It brought life to the already expanding world of Arkham, with the an ensemble cast of returning talent with the likes of the Dark Knight himself, Kevin Conroy, the Clown Prince of Crime, Mark Hamill, with their respective iconic performances, and brought back returning characters such as The Riddler, Zsasz, Bane, Harley Quinn, Qunicy Sharp, Commissioner Gordon, Killer Croc (for a blink and you'll miss it moment in the sewers) but also introduced new characters that were hinted at in Asylum like Penguin, Two-Face, Ra's Al Ghul, Catwoman, and Hugo Strange. A true masterpiece that further carried out its celebration of Batman media with its gripping narrative, its twists and turns, wealth of side quests, and exemplifies the passion that Rocksteady had for Batman. This game will forever be remembered as a hallmark achievement in the genre that set the standard that others strive for.

Arkham City allows players  to explore iconic locations in Gotham City ,it offers a detailed open-world environment maybe not the largest map for today's standards but keep in mind this is an old game. An ,,old game'' but gold in the hearts of many.

The game features a captivating narrative,maybe it's not the best story but still decent to keep you hooked until you finish the main missions. But there's more ,the side missions quality impress on their own too. With outstanding voice acting from characters and beautiful visuals Arkham City provides an immersive experience to fight criminals and feel as a true vigilante.

The Dark Knight fights crime with an impressive arsenal of gadgets and abilities. With the help of counters you can combo a huge chain of hits on enemies and it feels amazing to strike and evade with incredible accuracy. I was a little disappointed about the simplified stealth mechanics ,it felt like a huge potential lost . 

I liked the exploration and the enigmatic puzzles, the Riddler Trophies but i couldn't find them all..maybe there were too many.. Grappling and soaring around the city is thrilling and fun ,it really feels like you playing as the Batman from movies or comic books.

On a negative side of the coin,side missions can become repetitive after the initial impression and a few glitches can happen from time to time but nothing serious. 

I enjoyed the diverse lineup of villains ,each with his own motives and schemes. The boss fights were fun and well designed despite minor imperfections.

In conclusion, Arkham City is not a perfect game but close to perfection for the comic book fans and superhero fans. My recomendation is to first play Batman : Arkham Origins and Batman: Arkham Asylum.
Playing through the story chronologically is a better choice and should be considered.

Despite my gripes, I had an ok time playing this game, but I really feel like playing as Batman should feel more fun that this.

Batman: Arkham City stands as a crowning achievement in superhero gaming, delivering an unparalleled experience that captures the essence of the Dark Knight like never before. Rocksteady Studios has not only refined the groundbreaking mechanics of its predecessor but has elevated the genre to new heights with a gripping narrative, iconic characters, and an open-world Gotham City that serves as the ultimate playground for justice.

The narrative of Arkham City is a masterclass in storytelling, weaving a complex and mature tale that showcases Batman at his most vulnerable. The sprawling prison city, transformed from sections of Gotham, becomes a battleground where the Dark Knight faces not only familiar foes but also new, enigmatic adversaries. The voice acting, led by Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, delivers performances that define the characters in ways only the Arkham series can.

Gotham City itself is a character in Arkham City, a sprawling urban landscape that feels both atmospheric and lived-in. From the towering skyscrapers to the gritty streets, every inch of the city is meticulously designed to reflect the grim, noir aesthetic of Batman's world. The seamless transition between interiors and exteriors adds to the immersive experience, allowing players to feel the weight of the city's dark secrets.

The combat system, known for its fluidity and depth, remains a highlight in Arkham City. The Freeflow Combat system enables players to unleash devastating combos and counterattacks with unparalleled finesse, making each encounter a ballet of martial prowess. The addition of new gadgets and improved environmental takedowns adds variety to Batman's arsenal, keeping the gameplay fresh and dynamic.

The open-world structure of Arkham City allows for unprecedented freedom in navigating Gotham's grim streets. Side missions and collectibles are seamlessly integrated into the narrative, providing depth and replay value. The Riddler's challenges, in particular, are a testament to the game's clever level design and puzzle-solving elements, offering a rewarding challenge for completionists.

Arkham City's rogues' gallery is a who's who of Batman's iconic adversaries, and each encounter is a thrilling test of wit and skill. The boss battles, ranging from Two-Face to Mr. Freeze, are standout moments that showcase Rocksteady's ability to craft memorable and challenging encounters.

The musical score, composed by Nick Arundel and Ron Fish, complements the dark and atmospheric tone of the game. The powerful orchestral arrangements enhance the emotional impact of key moments, intensifying the overall cinematic experience.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City is more than a game; it's a definitive Batman experience that sets the standard for superhero gaming. Rocksteady's attention to detail, respect for the source material, and innovative gameplay mechanics combine to create an immersive and unforgettable journey through the heart of Gotham. For fans of the Dark Knight and gaming enthusiasts alike, Arkham City is an absolute must-play, proving that sometimes the night is darkest just before the dawn.

Arkham City's standout? The map's a whole vibe! 🗺️ Beyond Arkham Asylum, giving Batman a real playground with skyscrapers and alleyways, deep into Gotham's feels. Easter eggs everywhere! 🐣

Story? A vibe. Deep into Batman's ties, new characters spice it up. Playing as Catwoman or Robin? A twist, kinda tacked on. 🕹️

Skills upgrade? A game-changer. Balance it without making it a cakewalk. Strategy matters for Batman's full upgrade, keeping it real. 🏹

Flaws? Repetitive areas can kill vibes, and some side characters feel forced. But against the immersive atmosphere and killer narrative, they're tiny bumps.

In conclusion, Arkham City tops the OG. Batman: Arkham City ain't just a sequel; it's a flex, leveling up the game. 🦇🌆 Bigger map, epic story, boss battles, and playable side characters—Arkham City takes it higher. Some tiny flaws, but they're drowned out by the epicness. Must-play for Batman fans and action-adventure lovers. 🎮🌟 #ArkhamCity #DarkKnightRises 🦇

Amazing

PERFECT GAME, essential for anyone's library. Batman Arkham City is one of the most enjoyable video games I have ever played in my life. Just going to list what i think are the reasons this game is a must play; Freeflow combat system makes for the cleanest and most destructive fighting/beat-em-up game play (breaking skull and bones of the criminally insane has never been better). Predator sequences allow for creative and unique take-downs and is a master class for the stealth genre of games. Game is rich with iconic batman villains in the main story and side quests. Batman's gadgets are in full effect with classics returning and being upgraded like batclaw, linelauncher, remote batarang, grapple hook, and new gadgets added to the utility belt, the freeze grenade and jammer being my favorite. Main story keeps you guessing what next, with a amazing climax and twist ending that makes replaying employable while you pick apart the hints of foreshadowing. The Catwoman side expansion, which is supposed to be played along side the main game, is my favorite change of pace. It is similar game play but so unique as your approach to stealth changes to work with different abilities and gadgets, and fighting with the cat's expressive combat style is a part of how the developers care for characters other than batman. Do not sleep on the alternative dlc skins, all of them look great in game and all from respected batman universes, the tv animated skins are my favorite because I love the way they clash and stand out in this game.
     While I did have a problem with tedious riddler collect-a-thon as a kid, I found it more enjoyable later as i could apreciate the rewards for finding all of the riddles. You receive viewable in game character models, lore pages about the Batman Arkham universe, extra re playable combat and predator levels with character unique challenges, and get the pleasure to find and beat the shit out of that pencil neck dweeb Riddler while he sits behind his nerdy desk with two monitors and rainbow light up keyboard for thinking he could outwit the worlds greatest detective. 
     Harley's revenge is a great post game dlc that shows love to the greatest crime fighting duo batman and robin. We all wanted robin to be playable in a campaign and switching in-between robin and batman through the story similar to catwoman, is what we are being vindicated for in this campaign, NO NIGHTWING CAMPAIGN IS CRAZY THO. Nightwing is so chill and him being locked to the riddler challenge mode can hardly be fair. All the best gadgets are in this guy's utility belt and he comes with the wayne manor predator challenge, GOAT end of discussion.

"Batman: Arkham City GOTY Edition is Gotham's grand opera of justice. The sequel takes the caped crusader's escapades to new heights, soaring through an open-world Arkham that's both stunning and dangerous. BEST BATMAN GAME
one of the best game

Definitely the best Arkham game (in my opinion)!

The Story is really good having some really cool twists that exceed what Asylum was able to do. The characters are all so entertaining in the best way and the voice acting is phenomenal.

The Setting of Arkham City is just fantastic with it giving the player a more open world experience. All locations are well diverse and offers up more to explore than Asylum did. 

Visually, it's really held up well for this being a 2011 game. Performance was again iffy as i got the same problems that i had in Asylum with there being a tone of stutter that got really distracting. I don't know it's to do with the settings or just how these games are made but the stutter problem is really annoying. And while there were no glitches, I did experience one bug that completely crashed my game. Hopefully it's a settings issue than the game itself being broken. The Art Direction however is just brilliant with all character designs being on point and holding up a pretty good realism look. 

Sound and Audio are amazing with there being more memorable pieces in this game than the previous and I do think that the Audio is greatly improved especially in combat. 

In terms of Gameplay, Arkham City makes major improvements. Movement feels better and it's great to be able to actually fly around as Batman instead of what Asylum offered. Combat offers more variety in taking out enemies and the core systems that made it great feel a lot smoother. Gadgets feel a lot better to use and there is more variety. I really like there being side quests with other villains that offers a lot of playtime on top of the challenge modes. The Riddler is better developed with trophies working as actual puzzles and there being a quest to beat him. There is also the ability to play as Catwoman and while she is really fun to play as, I don't like the grapple mechanic for her. 

Overall, Batman: Arkham City is the definitive Batman game and is a must have for everyone.

Probably one of, if not THE, best superhero games out there. The combat, crime scenes, story arcs, the game balances everything just right and doesn't feel like it's just 'another' game based on another property.

The fact that it integrated a lot of the villains from Batmans villain roster into the plot in a way that doesn't feel forced. Much like Asylum (and Arkham Knight following), you're not just fighting random nondescript thugs fighting for a singular bad guy, or only focusing on thwarting ONE bad guy, but are focusing on multiple villains was a great concept for me when this game first came out.

Gameplay wise, it's just what you's want and expect from a Batman game. Plenty of exploration, investigations, brawling, and gadget use. Even graphically, it holds up considering that it has a mild "cartoon-y" look to it that really helps with the longevity of how it looks.

The Arkham games are classics (well, Origins was lame, but ignore that one), this one in particular. It has all the best elements of a Batman game, with very few negatives.

Thursday, October 31st. The city streets are crowded for the holiday. Even with the rain. Hidden in the chaos is the element, waiting to strike like snakes. And I'm there too. Watching. 2 years of nights have turned me into a nocturnal animal. I must choose my targets carefully. It's a big city. I can't be everywhere. But they don't know where I am. We have a signal now, for when I'm needed. When that light hits the sky, it's not just a call- it's a warning. To them. Fear is a tool. They think I'm hiding in the shadows. But I AM the shadows. I wish I could say I'm making a difference, but I don't know. Murder, robberies, assault- 2 years later, they're all up. And now this. This city's eating itself. Maybe it can't be saved, but I have to try. PUSH MYSELF. These nights all roll together in a rush, behind the mask. Sometimes in the morning I have to force myself to remember everything that happened.

Title: "Arkham City: A Magnum Opus of Gaming Excellence"

Rating: ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

From the moment I donned the iconic cape and cowl in Arkham City, I was plunged into a mesmerizing world that surpassed all expectations. Having spent 13 hours immersed in its captivating narrative and polished gameplay, I can confidently declare this game a magnum opus of the gaming world.

The combat system, a hallmark of the Arkham series, is nothing short of spectacular. Fluid, responsive, and deeply satisfying, every punch, counter, and acrobatic move feels like a symphony of controlled chaos. As the Dark Knight, I found myself seamlessly transitioning from one foe to another, orchestrating breathtaking combinations that left me feeling like the embodiment of justice.

The open-world design of Arkham City is a triumph, offering a Gotham that is as atmospheric as it is expansive. Every alley, rooftop, and dilapidated building exudes a sense of grim beauty, capturing the essence of Batman's world. The attention to detail is staggering, from the rain-soaked streets to the ominous architecture, creating an immersive environment that feels alive with the spirit of the source material.

The storytelling in Arkham City is a masterclass in narrative craftsmanship. The plot is intricate, weaving together iconic characters from Batman's rogues' gallery in a way that keeps you guessing and engaged. The voice acting, led by the legendary Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, is pitch-perfect, elevating the emotional depth of the characters and the overall experience.

The side quests and collectibles in Arkham City are not mere distractions but integral components of the gameplay experience. Each Riddler trophy, each side mission, contributes to the overall narrative, providing a rich and layered storytelling experience that goes beyond the main plotline.

The visual and auditory elements of the game are equally impressive. The dark and gritty art style, coupled with a haunting musical score, creates an atmosphere that is both chilling and enthralling. The attention to detail in character models and animations enhances the overall cinematic quality of the game.

In conclusion, Arkham City stands as a magnum opus in the realm of gaming. Its flawless combat, compelling storytelling, and meticulous attention to detail make it a timeless classic. Whether you're a Batman fan or a gaming enthusiast, this title is a must-play, showcasing the pinnacle of what the medium can achieve.

Pretty good, the combats good but I found it quite annoying at the same time. It alternates between two different fights, the fights involving guns often requires you to be constantly in detective mode and insta killing each enemy which is pretty dull, its also just frustrating since a single mistake can mean your death and enemies pretty much instantly figure out when someone dies. Also the controls for grabbing, jumping and running are all the same so it can stuff up your movements at times. The second fights which usually involve a group of guys attacking you with different tools. Its pretty amazing how all the fighting animations flow but honestly the style of gameplay can be pretty frustrating, most thugs will get back up like 3 times before being fully knocked out, then there are thugs with shields / tazers / body armor which require lots of time and focus to beat, I understand that this style of gameplay is intentional but honestly I find it quite annoying and frustrating when some nameless thug just keeps getting back up.  The combat isn't really that hard since you can always quite readily dodge / counter, just frustrating.

[h2]Gotham's Epic Playground – Arkham City Delivers Beyond Expectations[/h2]

Batman: Arkham City stands as a testament to the brilliance of Rocksteady Studios in crafting an unparalleled superhero gaming experience. From the moment the iconic Gotham skyline appears, you're thrust into a world that encapsulates the essence of the Dark Knight in a way that few games can rival.

The narrative is a gripping rollercoaster ride, seamlessly picking up from the events of Arkham Asylum. The notorious Arkham City serves as an expansive and atmospheric backdrop, a sprawling urban prison that redefines open-world gaming. The stakes are higher, the villains are more menacing, and Batman's world is pushed to its limits.

The voice acting is top-notch, with Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill reprising their roles as Batman and the Joker, delivering performances that elevate the storytelling to cinematic levels. The script is rich with twists and turns, and the interactions between Batman and his rogues' gallery are nothing short of captivating.

The gameplay is a refined blend of combat, stealth, and exploration. The Freeflow Combat system feels more fluid and satisfying than ever, allowing you to unleash a variety of gadgets and combos in a seamless dance of destruction. The predator sections bring out the stealthy side of Batman, offering a strategic and exhilarating approach to taking down armed enemies.

The open-world design of Arkham City provides a playground for the Dark Knight to glide, grapple, and swoop between towering skyscrapers. The attention to detail is astounding, with every nook and cranny hiding secrets, Easter eggs, and side missions that add depth to the overall experience. The city feels alive with the criminal underworld going about its business, creating a dynamic and immersive environment.

Graphically, Arkham City was ahead of its time, with a visual style that remains impressive even years after its release. The character models, animations, and atmospheric effects contribute to a Gotham that feels dark, gritty, and authentic to the source material.

The game's soundtrack deserves special mention, setting the mood perfectly with its haunting melodies and intense orchestration. The musical cues during pivotal moments enhance the emotional impact of the narrative, creating an audiovisual experience that is truly cinematic.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City is a triumph of superhero gaming, setting a standard that many have tried to emulate but few have surpassed. It's not just a game; it's an immersive journey into the heart of Gotham City, where you get to be the Batman in all his glory. Whether you're a die-hard fan of the Caped Crusader or just love exceptional games, Arkham City is a must-play that cements its place as one of the greatest superhero adventures ever created. Don the cape, embrace the night, and dive into the chaos of Arkham City – you won't be disappointed.
I think im the only person that dont like "City". The game is good, but i dont think its better than Asylum or Knight.

The textbook definition of a perfect sequel, Arkham City manages to take everything that Asylum did, and improves upon it tenfold. The combat and stealth flow even better with even more options and gadgets at your disposal. Traversal received a MASSIVE upgrade with the ability to glide and grapnel boost all around the city. The addition of side missions really helps to flesh out the world and show just how much of a hell-hole Arkham City is. Even the boss fights received a significant upgrade from the last game! Even if some encounters leave... much to be desired- *cough* Deadshot *cough*. 

Over-all, Arkham City is a phenomenal game, and it's no wonder why many call this one of the greatest superhero games ever made. Anyone who's a fan of Batman owes it to themselves to give this game a shot!

This is a difficult game to recommend because there are ways in which it is MAGNITUDES better than its predecessor, but also ways in which it is an absolute stinker. Ultimately, City provides a robust enough gaming experience through a world that holds tremendous nostalgic value for me. And that's why I am recommending it.

So what does it do well? The story first and foremost. It has one of the most epic video game openings I've ever experienced. Every encounter feels visceral and salacious. The writing is witty and does not take itself too seriously. Everything is complemented by a great soundtrack. Yet despite the pristine presentation, the cinmaticness of the game never takes over gameplay like it does in many Sony titles. It all culminates in an immersive experience that Asylum could never match due to the latter's smaller scale and linear level-design.

There are compromises however, for going open-world. For one, the predator sections as we know it in Aslyum are virtually gone, replaced by open-ended stealth segments where your options are overwhelming to the point where you don't win by winning but by winning with the most style. There is also a STAGGERING amount of Riddler trophies which is enough to give anyone who's not a trophy hound a massive migraine. Finally those virtual reality training hoops...

I think jumping into City for the first time, you will most definitely be blown away by its presentation, improved combat, and steady supply of gameplay scenarios. Yet like Asylum, its flaws also don't become apparent until repeated playthroughs where you realise it's not that deep of a game after all and what it has in breadth it lacks in depth. This is a game to be consumed in minute proportions and probably not stretched over too long a time. I made the mistake of trying to aim for 100% and it almost made me never want to play it ever again. I think this speaks to ultimately what kind of game City really is.

That said, if you've never played this and you enjoyed Asylum, this is a definite buy.

[Continued from a review on Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY]

The GCPD interviewer reached into her pocket. Pulled out a cigarette. The goon tried to reach across the table for it - she stood, out of his reach, lighting the cigarette. Puffing smoke, pacing around the cramped interrogation room. Walking circles around the goon like a shark in the water.

"The City. Tell me about the City."

"Right, fine, okay." A grumbling, discontented voice. "So the Asylum was good and all. Everyone liked it. But there was something more, there. We were hoping, but didn't expect it'd be [i]that[/i] big a hit. Now we got a budget. Now we got leg room. Time to stretch out. Time to get [i]ambitious."[/i]

"Ambitious."

"Yeah. See, we'd done the Asylum, but that's just one measly little island. What if we do a [i]huge[/i] chunk a' Gotham? What if we go all-out makin' this big open world ta go around?"

"Grand Theft Auto scale?"

The goon recoiled. "No! God, no, fuck that shit. Who has time for that? And what kinda fuckin' comparison is that, anyway?"

"One that was being made at the time."

"Those people're fuckin' stupid. They see a minimap with icons and bark like yappin' fuckin' dogs. 'Is it grand theft auto? What about GTA? It should be like GTA.' Feh. Fuckin' morons, all a' 'em." He eyed the lit cigarette. "Anyway. No. It's an open world packed full a' shit. Cool villains, some ya probably never heard of. Neat shit ta find."

"Riddler trophies?"

The goon winced. "...Look, those mostly suck."

"But there's a reward that makes it worth it."

"...I fuckin' wish." A laugh. "No, don't even bother with those. We put those in as a joke ta make the most annoyin' people on the Internet mad."

"It worked. What about the story?"

"It's just as dumb as the first one. Comic booky, ta be sure. But ya didn't pick up a game called fuckin' Batman because ya thought it'd be War and fuckin' Peace, am I right? The characters, though. We really did a great job with those, this time. We went all out."

"Tell me about Catwoman."

A wince. "You don't wanna hear about Catwoman."

The interrogator leaned in. Pressed the cigarette to the goon's forehead. He screamed.

"OKAY! FUCK! FINE! JESUS! Catwoman's in the FUCKIN' game, are ya happy?! And she sucks! Playing as her sucks! It's bad, it's really really bad, just completely absent everything good about the rest of the game and instead it's replaced with shitty stealth sections and unsatisfying combos! JESUS! But the game's still fuckin' great, alright? It's still worth playin'. There's fuckin'... Talia Al Ghul is there! And she's HOT! And yer gonna love her, I swear."

"We'll see," the interrogator said, as she returned to her seat. "What's left?"

The bigger, better (mostly) sequel to the Asylum game.
An actual open world this time, with the collectibles having a bit more of a reason to exist in it. There's proper side-quests now too, with B-level storylines to explore, some of which are just as engaging as the rest of the story.
That'd be my main failing point in comparison to the first one - the story is a bit less structured, kinda meandering about until the game ends in a ..finale. It's not bad by any means, just that it's worse and you can feel it if you've played the first game not too long ago.

The character work is still amazing - new ones and old all get more screentime, which everyone, including the people who don't play video games, should be ecstatic about.

For 16 years my favorite game has been Chex Quest. It got me through when my dad died, it was my gateway into modding and eventually into coding from there, the first true writing I did was Chex Quest fanfiction - it has been my loyal love for a very long time. I never thought I would have another favorite game.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is now my favorite game, and Arkham City is right up there by it. It's hard to pick one or the other as my favorite - Asylum has a close place in my heart for the hours I spent [i]being[/i] Batman, because believe me you [i]are[/i] Batman - you're not just controlling him, you embody him, you become the Bat. But City is ostensibly more advanced, cleaner, bigger, and with a more expansive story. Maybe you can't compare one as better than the other - they're both amazing.

I have heard these called the definitive Batman games and now that I've played, I agree. The acting by Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill, along with everyone else, is as incredible as always. You can really feel and believe the situation and Batman's stress becomes yours in a delicious way. Hearing the scream of someone in trouble, you [i]are[/i] the Bat, you go to help, you feel what it means to be Batman in both of these games.

Combat is smooth and satisfying, especially for the fact that it makes you think - there is no moment where you are simply clicking the button over and over. Your situational awareness goes to levels you didn't know you had in you and you feel like Batman even more, a one man army "kicking all kinds of major ass" as you might hear from a Tyger chopper's comms. And it's not easy to master either. There's a genuine feeling of accomplishment for doing well in combat, but it's not gated behind being too difficult - effort to learn feels meaningful.

As for the story itself, I couldn't have asked for more. If you are at all capable of doing so at this point, go in without spoilers. I was unfortunately aware of the outcome before playing, and it hampered some of my enjoyment - if you're tempted to look up what happens and still don't know the story/ending, I highly recommend sticking it through and feeling each moment as Batman experiences it - as [i]you[/i] experience it, Batman.

That's what this game is. You are Batman. With everything that comes with that. It's not a superhero simulator or a fighting game or a story told in a comic book. You become the Bat. That's what Batman: Arkham is.

The atmosphere of the Batman comics is perfectly conveyed here, as well as one of the best incarnations of the comics characters. The characters are what make the narrative part of the game interesting. For despite the fact that the plot is intriguing from the very beginning — it is difficult to call it outstanding, and with the exception of the ending there is no drama. And the presence of Catwoman as the second main character is very nominal, cut her out of the story and nothing will change.

The combat system is quite simple and does not have a huge number of combinations. But despite this the fights here still look impressive, due to the huge number of unique kick animations, which makes it interesting to fight here until the end of the game.

One of the game's major flaws is its open world, which is a section of the city of Gotham. It doesn't feel alive and all you can do in it is to do uninventive side quests and solve Enigma riddles (When you find out the number of them, you'll immediately give up). In addition, the city itself is very poorly memorized because of the visual monotony, it has no sights and you do not get lost in it only because it is not big in itself. 

And if you compare it to the previous installment, the only thing it loses to Batman: Arkham Asylum in is exploration. Since the first part was a chamber metroidvania, its locations were fun to explore. Plot events could change their appearance, and getting new devices immediately made you want to try them out to discover new paths, and the locations themselves were much more diverse.

Otherwise, this part is better than the previous one, it has a beautiful, though simple combat system, an intriguing story, interesting bosses and characters familiar from the comics. I think everyone will find something for themselves in this game.

It took several years for me to complete this game. I tried playing it on four separate occasions: in 2013, 2014, 2015 and in 2017, but I just didn’t find it interesting. 

Being my first Arkham game, the design felt very confusing to me and I never felt like I knew where I was supposed to go or what I was supposed to do. 

It finally clicked for me in 2023, when I gave it another chance after having played through [b]Arkham Knight[/b]. Fifth time’s the charm, I guess?

I thought I was going to struggle even more after playing one of the sequels, but it was surprisingly easy to get into it because most of the controls are identical between the games. 

The combat is not as good as in Arkham Knight. Many times I found myself attacking the air rather than enemies, something that I never had happen in Arkham Knight. But don’t get me wrong, the combat is still very satisfying and perfectly serviceable, just not as good. 

I enjoyed the story and atmosphere more in this game. I also absolutely loved the highly inappropriate dialogue between the bad guys. 

One of my favorite things was playing as Catwoman in some of the story missions, and the fact that she gets unlocked as a playable character when you complete the story. Unfortunately, in terms of post game content, she only has a very simple mission to do stealth takedowns on enemies across the city to gather loot. She doesn’t have her own set of side missions beyond that, and she can’t do Batman’s side missions, so that was a bummer to me. 

Coming from Arkham Knight, I was pleasantly surprised that there were no Batmobile segments at all in this game. I also really liked the boss fights, something that in retrospect felt absent from Arkham Knight. 

Despite struggling to get into the game, I ended up enjoying it a whole lot.

It's such a good game and I think the entire Arkham series is so unbelievably good. It's a huge step up from Arkham Asylum and manages to make even the more mundane aspects of it like the Riddler trophies fun since you get to play as such an accurate representation of Batman while you do it. TLDR, great story, great gameplay mechanics, very cool side missions and honestly a really good Batman simulator.

A Timeless Classic: Gotham's Dark Knight Rises in Batman: Arkham City

Rating: ★★★★★

Batman: Arkham City stands as a testament to timeless gaming excellence, even after 12 years since its release. As a devoted fan of the Caped Crusader, I couldn't have asked for a more immersive experience.

Gameplay (5/5):
Arkham City's gameplay is nothing short of phenomenal. The fluid combat mechanics make you truly feel like the Dark Knight, effortlessly countering foes in a dance of martial prowess. The seamless integration of stealth elements and detective work adds layers of depth, making every encounter a thrilling challenge.

Soundtrack (5/5):
The hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the gritty atmosphere of Gotham City. From heart-pounding battle themes to melancholic ambient tunes, the music elevates the overall experience, immersing you further into Batman's world.

Story (5/5):
The narrative is a masterpiece, weaving a complex tale that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Arkham City serves as the ultimate playground for Batman's rogues' gallery, and the plot twists and turns keep you guessing until the very end. The character development is top-notch, adding emotional weight to the overall story.

Side Activities (4.5/5):
The abundance of side activities in Arkham City is both a blessing and a curse. While some diversions feel essential to the Batman experience, a few may seem a tad overwhelming. Nevertheless, the variety of side quests, Riddler challenges, and other activities contribute to the game's overall richness.

Challenge Rooms (4/5):
The challenge rooms offer a satisfying test of skill, showcasing the depth of the combat system. While enjoyable, they might not have the same lasting appeal as the main story or side quests. Nonetheless, they provide a welcome change of pace for those seeking additional challenges.

Replay Value (5/5):
Arkham City's replay value is exceptional. With a plethora of collectables, alternative paths, and multiple endings, the game invites you to dive back into the shadows of Gotham City. New Game Plus mode adds an extra layer of challenge for those looking to prove their mettle as the World's Greatest Detective.

Graphics (3.5/5):
Given its 2011 release, Arkham City's graphics show their age. While the character models and environmental details were groundbreaking at the time, the visual fidelity is not up to par with today's standards. However, this is forgivable, considering the game's age and the outstanding quality in other aspects.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City remains an essential experience for any gamer, even in a landscape dominated by newer titles. Its unparalleled gameplay, gripping story, and memorable soundtrack overshadow the dated graphics, proving that true classics transcend the constraints of time. Don the cape and cowl; Arkham City is a journey every Batman fan should embark on.

Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition takes the caped crusader experience to new heights, offering an immersive journey through the dark, sprawling streets of Gotham. This edition, adorned with extra content and enhancements, solidifies its status as a must-have for both die-hard fans and newcomers alike.

The graphics of Arkham City remain impressive, even years after its initial release. The gritty atmosphere of Gotham is brought to life with meticulous attention to detail, from the towering skyscrapers to the ominous alleyways. The character designs are exceptional, capturing the essence of each iconic figure in Batman's world.

What truly sets the Game of the Year Edition apart is the wealth of additional content that accompanies the base game. From extra challenge maps to additional storylines, players are treated to an extended and enriched experience. The narrative, already engaging in the original release, is further enhanced with new subplots and characters, adding depth to an already intricate storyline.

The combat system, a standout feature of the Arkham series, continues to shine in this edition. Fluid, responsive, and empowering, players feel the impact of each punch and the satisfaction of executing perfectly timed counters. The seamless integration of gadgets and acrobatics contributes to a combat experience that remains unparalleled in superhero gaming.

One of the highlights of the Game of the Year Edition is the inclusion of all previously released downloadable content (DLC). From additional costumes to new challenge maps, this edition ensures that players have access to the complete Arkham City experience. The Harley Quinn's Revenge expansion, in particular, offers a gripping continuation of the main story, providing a fresh perspective on events in the aftermath of the main campaign.

While the game excels in many aspects, the open-world design occasionally leads to minor pacing issues. Navigating the vast city can be overwhelming, but the sheer variety of activities and missions ensures that players always have something engaging to pursue.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition stands as a testament to the enduring quality of Rocksteady's superhero masterpiece. With its captivating narrative, polished gameplay mechanics, and an abundance of additional content, this edition cements itself as the definitive way to experience the epic tale of the Dark Knight in the heart of Arkham City. Whether you're a seasoned Gothamite or a newcomer to the Arkhamverse, this edition is an essential addition to your gaming library.

1. The Good: Overall probably the best in the franchise. The bosses in this game are nothing short of incredibly well done, the combat is as fluent as ever. The gadgets have been expanded upon and the stealth missions are always a blast. The story is well done but again the real seller of this game is the boss fights. 

2. The Bad: The only negative things I can say is really just personal preferences. I like diversity in maps and the universe but this one is constantly dark and pretty much a lot of the same in terms of maps and missions. The dark aesthetic gets old to look at after a while for me personally but it does perfectly fit Batman and the Gotham universe. The side content is definitely there but a lot of the side missions and locations are difficult to navigate in general and a lot of the side quests happen sporadically (which I'm not a fan of) Some side quests are good and some are repetitive. I did not bother finishing all the side quests or collecting the Riddler trophies. Some side quests are good though and can be worth while if you are willing to run into them by chance with some location hints. This game can be buggy at times. Skins look bad in my opinion lol.

The first run was really good and the bosses were way more fun than Asylum even better than Knight tbh. but NG+ sucked.

Don't get me wrong although Riddler is my favoerite part I am glad you don't have to recollect all his riddles cause I got sick of replaying everything else, pretty much just new game with more armoured enemies, I will admit it's cool that they let me keep all gadgets and even orta skip some roadblocks in the main story, even tho I am forced to pick up gadgets I already have, the later game Knight kinda removes some of that redundancy like if you already picked up the rec gun it won't appear in the GCPD heck you can even pick it up early which is cool, unfortunately they hadn't thought of that yet and even dedicated whole side quests to just getting gadgets which thankfully also isn't done in Knight, the side quests are also a problem in general for NG+ cause they lose their charm after the first time unless you took a massive break and most of them you have to wait for and it's still you just doing the same thing as the first time Hush and Deadshot especially sucked in this regard cause they both had a lot of unskipable dialogue during crime scenes and very redundant upload percentages that for some reason require your movement to be extrmely limited(the main game also did this quite a bit) 

Zsass also didn't change for NG+ and you just hear the same story on top of having to wait for his phones(waiting for random points also happens with like every quest that is more than one part save AR and Bane and it sucks cause unlike first game you probably have no RIddler content left you just pace around an empty map with a massive wall through the middle you just can't pass through[at least not in a more convenient way]) I just really feel most of these did not deserve to return for NG+ they offer so little Bane and Mad Hatter were the only ones with propper cobat to actually make it any different so why not have it be mirrored like the riddler content especially the random acts of violence and AR cause they had no plot to them they did not need to be there. at least every quest in Knight actually has a reason to be repeated they all have at least one instance of proper combat(except Man-Bat) sure you couild say at least they learnt their lesson, but this is honestly something they should have thought of from the get go there are some parts where it feels like they ignored a fundamental.

The main game first time around was great, and had a great story as well as very interesting innovations made to the overall gameplay of Asylum one major example is the quickfire gadgets my only problem with it is the aim for the batclaw is so imnconsistent with subsequent taps it's cool to disarm the enemies but it often let's me down with the 2nd fire tho I am greatful that they even let you use the batclaw on trophies although I am glad it wasn't like that in Asylum cause it would have killed some of the puzzles.

The only major problem I have with the main game however is the way it's intersected by the Catwoman DLC cause it comes at the worst possible moments to put way too many cliffhangers in the middle of a videogame, worst of all they both start you off as her and force you to play as her after the credits before you can do anything post game, my other issue with the DLC is there is litterally no explanation as to why Riddler left her trophies and it makes no sense for him to want to test her,

I know I dug into the game alot but I can assure you I still deffinetly reccomend it(maybe don'ty play NG+ tho)

A great follow-up to 'Arkham Asylum' which opens up the map to a confined section of Gotham City.
Glide between rooftops as the Batman -- or switch sides, and prowl the alleyways as Catwoman -- in this instant classic!

While stealth approaches are still always an option, you're now free to really kick some ass in a crowd -- and rioting is frequent.  Your arsenal of combos is more numerous, and you have a variety of special takedown options at your disposal. 

This GOTY Edition contains all the DLC from the game's history -- AND gives players the option to unlock their skins from the start, without the need for a cheat code.
The highlight of these is clearly the DARK KNIGHT RETURNS.

Thursday, October 31st. The city streets are crowded for the holiday. Even with the rain. Hidden in the chaos is the element, waiting to strike like snakes. And I'm there too. Watching. 2 years of nights have turned me into a nocturnal animal. I must choose my targets carefully. It's a big city. I can't be everywhere. But they don't know where I am. We have a signal now, for when I'm needed. When that light hits the sky, it's not just a call- it's a warning. To them. Fear is a tool. They think I'm hiding in the shadows. But I AM the shadows. I wish I could say I'm making a difference, but I don't know. Murder, robberies, assault- 2 years later, they're all up. And now this. This city's eating itself. Maybe it can't be saved, but i have to try. PUSH MYSELF. These nights all roll together in a rush, Behind the mask. Sometimes in the morning i have to force myself to remember everything that happened.

Now this is a really fun game. There were massive improvements here ahead of the last game where now you are in a much bigger location and many more villains appear as well as having more unique fights with them such as with Mr Freeze and so on. many which make you think hard about tackling the boss.

the ending was one hell of a surprise, but it suited the series down to a T as well. the combat has also been improved and the story is very interesting. I do miss Scarecrow though and how he'd poison you subtly giving you all those messed up visions in the first game, but still. Game is a hell of a lot of fun.

Edit: One of my favourite moments was learning about Victor Zsasz's past where he phones Batman from the various payphones to talk about his own past and how he became who he was. Many of the stories are  really interesting of the many different criminals, including some who had not appeared in the first game and expanding upon Batman's Rogue Gallery. I won't give too much away for spoilers and surprise bosses, but you also have Deadshot to contend with and Mr Freeze adjusts to each takedown you attempt on him so no duplicate takedowns. Many of the bosses require you to be creative and think I little more when taking down a boss.

Batman: Arkham City Game of the Year Edition stands as an enhancement to an already outstanding game, solidifying its status as a true masterpiece, particularly in the realm of gameplay. The Arkham series pioneered the superhero video game genre with its revolutionary free-flow combat system, and Arkham City builds upon this success. While opinions may differ on whether Arkham Knight's combat surpasses that of Arkham City, there's no denying the visceral impact of each punch in the latter. The combat system retains its fluidity and technical finesse, with the removal of the throw combo compensated by the addition of two new combo moves: disarm, which aptly disarms and dismantles the enemy's weapon, and a multi-takedown combo, enriching the player's options when faced with a diverse range of adversaries.

In addition to its stellar gameplay, Arkham City excels in storytelling. The narrative takes a significant leap forward from its predecessor, introducing numerous side quests featuring iconic villains and characters from the DC Comics universe. The inclusion of challenging Riddler trophies, numbering a whopping 440, adds depth to the game. While only 400 are required to confront the enigmatic Edward Nigma, the additional 40, entrusted to Selina Kyle, provide a refreshing change of perspective in both missions and free roam segments. The main story is a compelling test for the Dark Knight, weaving a narrative that captivates players and deepens their connection to Gotham's vigilant protector.

How have I not reviewed this game on here yet? It's literally one of my favorite games of all time. It's the first Arkham game I've ever played. It's how I was informed that Luke Skywalker was The Joker. It's how I got confused thinking Tara "I'm islamophobic but everyone hates me for something completely unrelated actually" Strong always voiced Harley Quinn cause I didn't know the late great Arleen Sorkin existed for a time. It's what introduced me further into the lore of Batman and when I started fully appreciating him as a superhero, especially with his no-kiII rule. It's the game that took everything about the first game and expanded & improved on it a hundred fold.

Most of all, it took the story of Mr. Freeze being a sympathetic villain from the 90s Animated Series and made it so much better(WB Montreal did great with his origin story in Origins, too, and Rocksteady gave him a bittersweet yet perfect end to his story in Knight, mind you).

This game is nothing short of perfection, and I can see why one review publication rated this a 6 out of 5.

Batman: Arkham City is a game that will make you feel like the Dark Knight himself. You will explore the vast and gritty prison city of Arkham, where you will encounter iconic villains such as The Joker, Two-Face, The Riddler, and more. You will use your gadgets, skills, and detective abilities to fight crime and uncover a sinister plot by the mysterious Hugo Strange.

The game is a sequel to the critically acclaimed Batman: Arkham Asylum, but it improves on every aspect of its predecessor. The combat is fluid and satisfying, the stealth is tense and rewarding, and the story is engaging and immersive. The game also features a playable Catwoman campaign that runs parallel to the main story, adding more variety and perspective to the experience.

The game is not only a great Batman game, but also one of the best action-adventure games ever made. It has a rich and detailed world, a captivating narrative, and a gameplay that will keep you hooked for hours. If you are a fan of Batman or just enjoy a thrilling and fun game, you should definitely play Batman: Arkham City.

First off, my personal favourite Arkham game in the franchise, the story is a 10 in my opinion, it has just enough side missions to do while keeping the game fresh after completing the main story, and the twist at the end is one of the best of all time. all the boss fights are really good, each of them being unique and fun in their own way, my personal favourite being the Mr.Freeze boss fight. this game kept what made Arkham Asylum a good game, and it strengthened the weak points from it. all new moves, all new gadgets, so many collectibles, and sure, riddler does get annoying to do, but the sastifaction of fully finishing it all is worth it. and the costumes you can use after completing the main story (assuming you got the dlc) are some of the finest and coolest to glide around in. in my honest opinion, if you were to play any of the games, this would be the one i highly suggest you play. this game, in my honest opinion, this game is a 10/10 and the best out of the whole franchise.

Batman Arkham City é um jogo feito pela rocksteady em 2012 que conta a segunda parte de Batman Arkham asylum contém spoilers: Batman Arkham City foi um jogo que me marcou profundamente em minha vida foi o jogo que me introduziu ao mundo dos jogos eu lembro que eu tava na casa de um amigo meu um dia quando eu vi a demo desse jogo eu sempre quis jogar ele e aí foram os 15 minutos mais legais da minha vida eu não tive nem como descrever a sensação de jogar aquele jogo pela primeira vez e depois de uns 9 anos por aí eu consegui finalmente comprar o jogo meu computador é muito humilde ele tem um de processador Celeron e 4 GB de ram então eu tive que dar meus pulos para fazer o jogo rodar mas por sorte ele rodou mas requisitos mínimos e foi uma das melhores experiências da minha vida eu já tinha zerado o jogo na casa desse mesmo amigo umas quatro vezes antes mas quando eu joguei comigo sozinho nossa foi uma experiência totalmente diferente e depois disso eu iniciei o new game Plus que foi uma experiência também totalmente diferente depois disso eu comecei a rodar pelo mapa fiz as missões secundárias eu completei o Azrael Bene o senhor frio que é uma história muito bonita que vai ser fechada no arcanight mas meu computador não roda o jogo então eu vou ficar chupando o dedo e depois eu joguei a dlc da Arlequina que foi uma experiência nova no jogo que eu já conhecia então eu virei aquela campanha separada com um gostinho de quero mais e o jogo me proporcionou também os desafios do charada que até hoje no momento que eu tô escrevendo essa review eu completei os mapas originais de arcan com Batman e eu zerei todos foram em desafio incrível muito gostoso de fazer para quem não fez eu recomendo porque você fica bom no jogo de verdade então façam façam eu não vou me aprofundar muito na história mas o coringa ficou infectado acho que todo mundo conhece coringa fica infectado Batman vai ter que procurar cura mas para quem ainda não jogou eu só isso que eu vou ter que falar porque se você não jogou esse jogo você tá cometendo um sacrilégio para a humanidade a game play do jogo é muito boa mas as melhores que eu já joguei em toda minha vida e quando você pega a mão do jogo você se sente realmente com o Batman tem uma mecânica muito proeminente no jogo que é a mecânica a de free flow de um número determinado de como você entra numa câmera lenta E aí você começa a dar vários golpes críticos e muitas pessoas e você sente imparável de alguma forma então você realmente se sente o Batman nesse jogo cidade por mais que não tenha pedestre ou algo assim é muito Viva o diálogos dos criminosos são incríveis e muito bem feitos te dão uma informação do que que tá acontecendo na prisão no momento já que o Batman caiu literalmente quase que de paraquedas na prisão então eles mandaram tudo logicamente mas maravilhosos as lutas contra chefes são deliciosas bem feitas tanto que eu coloquei 50 horas no jogo você pode ver aí são 49 horas 1.6 e foi muito bom foi muito bom quer dizer está sendo muito bom no momento eu tenho 73% do jogo concluído e é maravilhoso é maravilhoso recomendo para todos que joguem não não sejam preconceituosos com a linguagem estrangeira porque a voz do Batman você se sente que é ele e eu já deixo aqui minha ex condolências ao dublado do Batman Kevin Conroy do Batman em toda a série arca e seu último trabalho foi esquadrão suicida contra a Liga da justiça um jogo que também está na frente a arca e que eu acho que vai dar um pouquinho de polêmica mas a gente ainda não vai entrar nesse mérito eu espero que a pessoa que ler isso aqui não fique muito cheia de palavras mas isso aqui é uma expressão de fã realmente e nada mais justo do que um fã de carteirinha do Batman falando do jogo que muda a vida dele eu só tenho a agradecer essa franquia maravilhosa e é isso não tem mais o que eu falar o jogo é maravilhoso é lindo gostoso enfim jogem jogue jogue jogue.
