You can't get every Riddler trophy you come across right away, you might have to come back with a new gadget. The pink ones are only for Catwoman.

Riddler's hidden question marks are back. If you see one, find some place to see the whole thing and tap the Detective Mode button.

When the game is over, you'll get to go back and get anything you missed.

There are easter eggs everywhere and some of them have achievements for finding them.

The only immediately useful upgrade you can get is the one that slightly slows time when your freeflow combo hits x12, everything else you can get when you feel it's necessary.

When your first set of Augmented Reality glide challenges becomes available, do them for a very useful grappling hook upgrade.

The "Catch" achievement involves a character who you can find on top of the ferris wheel by the steel mill after a certain point in the game. Throw a remote batarang at him. This is also the start of a side-mission.

There's no time limit on finding new leads for side-missions.

There is no achievement/trophy for completing the game on the hardest mode this time around.
Just like in Asylum you'll need to revisit portions of the game for Riddler Trophies as you'll have to unlock gadgets in order to get them. This includes trophies frozen in ice.

You wont be able to solve the question mark alignment riddles until you progress a little into the game.
Your explosive foam can be used on the question marks switches and you can trigger them manually in first person view.

If a Batarang isn't working on a switch this means you'll need to run a current through it by remotely running it into some electricity - fly your Batarang into a conduit and then run it into the switch. A good example of this is a switch next to Calendar Man's cell.

There's a few pressure plate Riddler wall switches that require you to glide into them. Many of these will have you kick off the wall to glide to another switch without touching the ground. If you're having trouble you can Bat Spring yourself up a building and then adjust yourself without having to do a kick off (the controls for it can be unresponsive at times).

Complete the first set of flying challenges for a gadget. The second set is a royal bitch that requires pixel perfect gliding. Only bother if you want the achievement/trophy.

Level up your combat abilities first as this will give you access to easier x5 finishers opposed to x8, timed combos so you can have a higher multiplier, and the x15 combat flow ability.

Catwoman's chapters are mostly towards the end of the game opposed to being scattered throughout. It's not urgent to level her.

If you're having trouble with The Stranger side mission you will be able to see the masked man after completing various plot points. Make it habit to turn on detective mode the moment you're outside after a cutscene and scan the top of buildings.

Riddler will eventually send out green goons mixed into gang groups throughout the game. An easy way to deal with them is by a triple stun or with the late game freeze weapons. By the end of the game if you managed to take them out properly they will reveal all of Riddler's Challenge locations on the map. Not bad if you don't want to bother with a guide!

The 50 combo and 5 gadget achievement can be easily done in the challenge modes.

There's an annoying Riddle in Joker's Steel Mill (the Assembly Line room). The solution to will not appear until the final act of the game even if you managed to beat its location out of someone. If you're curious, the Riddle is "Once assembled, do these two become one again?"

The last two upgrades that get you Riddler trophies are an item that can make platforms in water and the master encryption key for your hacking tool. After that, you shouldn't need any more items to pick up trophies. Use some creative thinking!

When you get the item that can make platforms, spend a while exploring and getting as many trophies as you can. Some Catwoman trophies require you to have opened areas as Batman.

You can break flimsy walls by gliding into them; you don't need any specific items to do that.

You can zoom in to selectively detonate explosive gel; don't be like me and assume selective detonations come later.

You can't put gel on overhead walls; it's either something you'll come to later from the other side or there's a path around it.

If you can't find a riddle marked on your map no matter what you do, it's probably a place to view a question mark.

If you can't find electricity to fly a remote batarang through to hit a fusebox, you might need to wait until you get an item that can shoot electricity directly at it.

The quick-fire grapple -> punch followup is very useful and abusable - it's easily interruptable to counter and can shoot you across rooms. Without the followup it puts the mook into a pretty long stumble animation, too. And it can disarm!

The triple cloak stun is the easiest way to get riddler mooks out of the way while you defeat the rest of the crowd. Be careful, though - it sucks to accidentally take them down when there are only two enemies left.


Batman: Arkham City isn't perfect, but listing the little things I didn't like gets in the way of all the stuff I adored. The voice acting, the challenges, the amazing opening, the unbelievable ending and the feeling of being the Dark Knight -- these are the things that standout looking back. I've beaten this thing twice and still want to call in sick and chase Riddler Trophies.

Batman: Arkham City is an absolute tour de force in the world of gaming. Being a fan of the Dark Knight, I was happy to don the cape and cowl, and I can safely say that this game exceeded my already inflated expectations.

Arkham City's open world is a crime-fighting playground, replete with iconic locations and passphrases that pay homage to Batman's history.

The combat system is smooth and intuitive, making you feel like a martial arts master as you fight groups of thugs with various gadgets and abilities. The stealth elements are equally well done, allowing you to outsmart and destroy your enemy from the shadows, just like Batman should.

But what really sets Arkham City apart is its compelling storyline. The narrative is dark, mature, and masterfully written that takes your breath away. The voice acting, especially with Mark Hamill playing the role of the Joker, is superb. The pace of the game keeps you in suspense, and the side missions add depth to the overall experience.

The game also features a rich selection of unlockable items, quests, and secrets that will keep you engrossed in the game long after the main story is over.

If you're not already familiar with this adventure, do yourself a favor and become Batman - Gotham needs you

As someone who religiously played the first game (Batman: Arkham Asylum) on the Xbox360 as a kid, this is the best continuation to the story and franchise. The Arkham games have always been my favorite, the combat, the gadgets, the story, even the designs of the maps. The Riddler trophies and even the riddles are honestly my favorite because they add a lot of exploration to the game, stumbling across a riddle and looking for the answer or a destructible wall and blowing it up to find the green question marks are fun, even if they don't add anything materialistically aside from achievements and a challenge to find them all. The side quests in this game specifically don't disappoint either, you can finish the main story line as quick or slow as you want and still have hours upon hours of gameplay along with other (DLC) side stories, including Harley Quinns mourning story line and Tim Drake's. It's a very good and well made game especially for releasing in 2012, and the graphics remain great!

The inclusion of playing as Catwoman also adds a nice change and an interesting play for the story, the different mechanics especially. Love climbing on ceilings. Overall, it's an amazing game with a really well thought out story and well made large map. You have hours of playtime and unless you get bored of beating up bad guys, you wont be bored of this game any time soon. 100/10 (Maybe a little biased because of my love for most things Batman, but it is genuinely a good game.)
AR Training and constantly failing is pretty much "rage uninstall" for me. Can't refund, unfortunately, but whatever, won't be playing anymore.

Loved the sequel to Arkham Asylum when it came out - Batman: Arkham City did well to expand on the original's design with a good open-world environment to explore, plus the RPG style upgrade system and the side missions you can undertake.

The main story is great, and I love this PC version combines the Catwoman elements of the story within it, as well as the expansion pack that acts as the epilogue to the main story - and lets you play as Robin. It was also nice to encounter and tackle some of the other Batman villians in this game, such as Penguin and Mr Freeze

The controls remain easy to get into, and I like some of the new gadgets they added in. This is a worthy title in the Arkham series to play through, both for the main story, additional campaign, and the challenge mode.

I had the pleasure of playing Batman: Arkham City and I must say it was the best gaming experience I've ever had. The atmosphere and level of detail in the game environment was absolutely stunning. I was really sucked into the experience of being Batman, fighting crime in a huge open city. The combat mechanics and the way the counter system worked was very satisfying, and the missions were all varied and challenging. The level of detail in the character models, environments, and voice acting were all top notch. I especially liked the side missions and all the secrets to discover. I spent many hours exploring the city and finding all the little Easter eggs. My overall experience with Batman: Arkham City was truly phenomenal, and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the Batman universe.

[h1] Batman: Arkham City [/h1]

Graphics: ★★★★★
The graphics in Batman: Arkham City are outstanding. The game brings the dark and gritty atmosphere of Gotham City to life with detailed environments and stunning character designs.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay in Arkham City is smooth and intuitive. The combat system is incredibly satisfying, with fluid and acrobatic moves that make players feel like the Dark Knight himself. However, some repetitive mission structures and occasional frustrations with the stealth mechanics prevent it from receiving a perfect score.

Story: ★★★★★
The story in Arkham City is engaging and keeps players hooked from start to finish. It's filled with intriguing twists and turns, as Batman navigates through a city filled with iconic villains. The writing is top-notch, offering a deep and immersive narrative that complements the gameplay perfectly.

Characterization: ★★★★☆
The game features a strong cast of characters, both heroes and villains alike. Batman is as brooding and determined as ever, while the villains are portrayed with depth and complexity. The voice acting is excellent, further enhancing the personalities and motivations of the characters.

Replayability: ★★★★☆
Arkham City offers plenty of replay value, with numerous side missions, collectibles, and challenges to keep players entertained even after completing the main story. The open-world environment allows for exploration, and different playstyles can be employed to tackle missions, adding to the game's replayability factor.

Overall Rating: ★★★★☆
Batman: Arkham City is a superb game that successfully captures the essence of being the Dark Knight. With stunning graphics, immersive storytelling, and solid gameplay mechanics, it is a must-play for fans of the superhero genre. While it does have a few minor flaws, this game is a near-perfect experience in the world of Batman.

Rating: ★★★★★

Batman: Arkham City is an exceptional superhero game that truly immerses you in the world of the Dark Knight. The game's graphics and art design are stunning, creating a gritty, comic book-like Gotham City. The story is gripping, with outstanding voice acting and unexpected twists that keep you hooked.

The gameplay is a highlight, with fluid combat, stealth elements, and a variety of gadgets that add depth to the experience. The game's side missions and collectibles offer hours of additional content and enrich the world.

In summary, Batman: Arkham City is a must-play for fans of the Caped Crusader and gamers alike. It's a well-crafted game that captures the essence of Batman in an unforgettable way.

Batman: Arkham City is an absolute tour de force in the world of gaming. Being a fan of the Dark Knight, I was happy to don the cape and cowl, and I can safely say that this game exceeded my already inflated expectations.

Arkham City's open world is a crime-fighting playground, replete with iconic locations and passphrases that pay homage to Batman's history.

The combat system is smooth and intuitive, making you feel like a martial arts master as you fight groups of thugs with various gadgets and abilities. The stealth elements are equally well done, allowing you to outsmart and destroy your enemy from the shadows, just like Batman should.

But what really sets Arkham City apart is its compelling storyline. The narrative is dark, mature, and masterfully written that takes your breath away. The voice acting, especially with Mark Hamill playing the role of the Joker, is superb. The pace of the game keeps you in suspense, and the side missions add depth to the overall experience.

The game also features a rich selection of unlockable items, quests, and secrets that will keep you engrossed in the game long after the main story is over.

If you're not already familiar with this adventure, do yourself a favor and become Batman - Gotham needs you!

Batman: Arkham City Review:

Graphics: ★★★★★
The graphics in Batman: Arkham City are outstanding. The game brings the dark and gritty atmosphere of Gotham City to life with detailed environments and stunning character designs.

Gameplay: ★★★★☆
The gameplay in Arkham City is smooth and intuitive. The combat system is incredibly satisfying, with fluid and acrobatic moves that make players feel like the Dark Knight himself. However, some repetitive mission structures and occasional frustrations with the stealth mechanics prevent it from receiving a perfect score.

Story: ★★★★★
The story in Arkham City is engaging and keeps players hooked from start to finish. It's filled with intriguing twists and turns, as Batman navigates through a city filled with iconic villains. The writing is top-notch, offering a deep and immersive narrative that complements the gameplay perfectly.

Characterization: ★★★★☆
The game features a strong cast of characters, both heroes and villains alike. Batman is as brooding and determined as ever, while the villains are portrayed with depth and complexity. The voice acting is excellent, further enhancing the personalities and motivations of the characters.

Replayability: ★★★★☆
Arkham City offers plenty of replay value, with numerous side missions, collectibles, and challenges to keep players entertained even after completing the main story. The open-world environment allows for exploration, and different playstyles can be employed to tackle missions, adding to the game's replayability factor.

Overall Rating: ★★★★☆
Batman: Arkham City is a superb game that successfully captures the essence of being the Dark Knight. With stunning graphics, immersive storytelling, and solid gameplay mechanics, it is a must-play for fans of the superhero genre. While it does have a few minor flaws, this game is a near-perfect experience in the world of Batman.

Note: About 8 hours of my play time was actually just me leaving the game on overnight.

Graphics: 7.5/10
While the graphical quality of the game was likely good in its time, it is now outclassed by newer AAA games. The people look fine, and so does the environment. But, just like Skyrim, if you look close enough at the finer points, you probably come to the realization that, "This game was made in 2011...". Despite that, it still has good graphics. I use a NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1050 Ti and the game looks good.

Music and Audio: 6/10
The music is fine, I suppose. i'm not much of a game music critic, but I am a music snob, and it's fine. As for the audio effects, it makes a really realistic "pow" sound when you knock out a dude, which is funny but not accurate to life. Everything else is fine.

Difficulty: 7/10
Arkham City has a comfortable learning curve, but I remember toward the end there was this one predator (stealth) level where you had these 6 dudes with guns and tons of stuff to help them capture you. I had to redo that one several times. Other than that, the only other thing that is noteworthy here is just other stealth stuff, which is easy enough if you don't get caught, but it has justified consequences if you do get caught. Then there's the tedious AR challenges, and, of course, the Riddle puzzles which are way too common and the  open world is riddled with them. (pun intended). Other than that, nothing is very tough about Arkham City.

Story: 8.5/10
Being a critic of literature, comic book reader, and "trying to be an author", I actually thought that AC had a good story. It was set up good, had an excellent twist, and delivered the climax wonderfully. But, there really was one thing missing; a choice point. What I mean by that is that, correct me in the comments if I'm wrong, but Batman never really had a big choice that significantly affected the story. One may argue that the alternate ending included as an option with the Catwoman expansion was such a choice point, but you would do well to remember that Catwoman is not the main character. Other than that, I liked the story.

Gameplay: 9/10
The combat is simple, fun, and of an ideal difficulty. The stealth is exciting and sometimes difficult. The exploration and adventure portions are interesting. The only two things I really have against this part is that (1) i'ts almost always the same and never introduces anything new, and there isn't enough elements to make any part of it uncommon, if you catch my drift. And (2) it's not especially difficult. After beating Dark Souls 2, I found that I like difficult games better than games of ideal difficulty. Once you figure out the strategies you need to do to win, you win every time. Enemies hardly change their tactics (though the legendary Mr. Freeze boss fight was a renowned exception. "Residents of Arkham City, you should be more like Freeze!").

World: 8/10
The world in City, which boasts various different zones with different thugs and interesting graphical changes and differences in mood, is good but quite small. Yes, there is an underground portion, but it really doesn't have all that much to do. But the main thing that folks love City for is that Rocksteady packed City full of stuff. It's never empty, and you always have something to do (that is, before you finish the story, side missions, physical challenges, and the infamous Riddler trophies).

Comparison to Arkham Knight
This game is fantastic, don't get me wrong, but Knight does lots of things better. The graphics are superior, there's a more varied and interesting combat system, and the world is "well over 5 times bigger". But, my main (probably more like "sole") reason I don't like Knight as much is because of the Batmobile. When I first got the game, I would just drive around in the car and wreck dudes, also in cars. And I thought to myself, "This is the best game of all time." Then, however, as I advanced in the game, I found that Rocksteady used the car way too much. I understand that the addition of a practical tank that you can drive is a compelling addition. And it was well executed, save for it's over-usage. There is a supple amount of vehicle-based combat in the game, which I dislike to a degree. And then there's the kind of dumb stuff that it makes you do with the car, like siphon power to other stuff. As for the story, I actually haven't finished Knight's, it seems interesting so far. I think the flaw there is the delivery of the story. In Knight, the stakes are much higher, but i don't feel as involved as I was in City. Challenge maps in Knight, however, surpass City in every way. I love the Endless Knight predator map, where you are timed, and the further you get into it, the harder it gets. Oh, and it's endless, just like in the name.

Overall, City is a wonderful game with a good fan base and hours of fun. It had everything a game needs to be successful. If you want to play one in the series, i'd recommend starting with this one. If you don't like Batman, try to look past the Batman part of it and focus on... everything else. If you enjoyed Monolith's Middle Earth duo-logy, definitely play.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Batman: Arkham City, in its Game of the Year (GOTY) edition, is a masterclass in action-adventure gaming. With 11 hours of gameplay, I can confidently say that this title is a must-play for any fan of the Caped Crusader, and it delivers a superlative gaming experience.

Set within a sprawling, walled-off section of Gotham City that has been converted into an open-air super-prison, Arkham City places you in the role of the iconic Batman. The story is a rollercoaster of suspense and intrigue, as you navigate the chaos orchestrated by some of Batman's most notorious foes, including the enigmatic Hugo Strange and the diabolical Joker.

The world of Arkham City is a dark, atmospheric, and intricately designed playground for Batman's gadgets and combat skills. From towering skyscrapers to grimy alleyways, the city feels like an authentic part of the Batman universe. The level of detail in every corner of Arkham City is astounding, providing ample opportunities for exploration and hidden secrets.

Gameplay in Arkham City is a thrilling blend of fluid combat, stealth, and detective work. The combat system is a highlight, allowing Batman to take on multiple foes with finesse. The Freeflow combat mechanic makes you feel like an unstoppable force, delivering punches, kicks, and counters with satisfying precision. The stealth sections, often involving encounters with armed thugs, offer a rewarding mix of strategy and tactical takedowns.

The detective work is another captivating aspect of the game. Batman's detective mode allows you to analyze crime scenes, solve puzzles, and track down villains with a detective's intuition. This mechanic adds depth to the gameplay and offers a strong connection to the Dark Knight's crime-solving abilities.

The voice acting, led by the legendary Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker, is top-notch and adds a layer of authenticity to the characters. The writing and character development in Arkham City are superb, making every interaction, every villain, and every twist in the story utterly engaging.

The Game of the Year edition comes with all the additional content, including extra challenge maps and the "Harley Quinn's Revenge" story expansion, further enhancing the game's replay value. With 11 hours of gameplay, you've only scratched the surface of what Arkham City has to offer.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City in its Game of the Year edition is a tour de force in the world of superhero gaming. With its impeccable storytelling, exhilarating gameplay, and a world that feels pulled right from the comics, it's a definitive Batman experience. Whether you're a die-hard fan of the Dark Knight or simply enjoy exceptional action-adventure games, Batman: Arkham City GOTY is an absolute must-play and stands as a high watermark for superhero games.

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Overall as a Open World game fan, this game is awesome. Lots of exploration to be done as the Dark Knight, which means it comes with tonnes of gadgets at your disposal. Gameplay is quite straightforward as a third person view game, and story is superb.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
As mentioned, the gameplay is an Open World game with lots of action and stealth as the player takes the mantle of the Dark Knight. This also includes multiple in-air, rooftop and street level traversal. Apart from that, players can use different characters with different skillsets. Other than that, there is a skill leveling segment which requires players to level up, making some level of grinding available.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The graphics is relatively good and details. Apart from being quite light and optimized.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The music and theme are relatively good, especially if you are using THX Spatial audio, either via Speakers or Headphones. Music and voice acting is quite good. One complaint is the lip sync being a bit rigid.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Controls are basically like any third-person perspective game with multiple options for various gadgets/skills. Each character has unique abilities tied. The Keyboard+Mouse feels rather natural overall.

[h1]Bugs & Issues[/h1]
Not much game-breaking bugs so far, multiple issues found.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
1. Stuck at random within the world, e.g.: Whilst jumping
2. Some cases sequences does not trigger, reloading game fixes this issue

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Overall a great game, too many things to do and does feel bloated at times, especially the Riddler challenges. Sucks that there is no blood and violence since Batman does not kill.

Batman Arkham City is the perfect sequel. It improves on virtually every aspect of its already fantastic predecessor, combat, detective work and riddles. It gives you an open world in which you can glide around to your hearts content, solving side cases, each of which are incredible little crime stories of their own, and a main Batman story that is much darker and more gritty than anything we have previously experienced and honestly really well written, one of the best Batman stories there are to be honest, with actual consequences and characters dying, pushing the Detective to his mental and physical limits. The characters are also quite honestly the best version of themselves here, Catwoman, Mr.Freeze, Hugo Strange, Zasz, the Joker, they all feel so grounded somehow while still being fantastical in an almost mythic way, and for me at least, the Arkham games are my favorite version of Batman and his world, violent, gritty and noir, authentically Batman. Arkham City achieves all this without sacrificing any of the atmosphere or vibe that made Asylum so great, so yes, Arkham City is the perfect sequel, and in my and many others opinion deserves a spot on the Greatest Games of All Time List. I really cannot sing its praises enough, and you should play it as soon as you can, with the Arkham City Redux if you want completely remastered textures, even though the gothic art design holds up more than well enough, offering us perhaps the definitive version of Gotham.

[h1]It's Worth Playing[/h1]

On the whole, [i]Arkham City[/i] is a game worthy of your time. It expands upon the gameplay of its predecessor, [i]Arkham Asylum[/i], but unfortunately, it's open world bloated and padded out with a lot of boring side content that feels tedious and adds nothing of real substance. 

[h1]Arkham City - The Open World[/h1]

They say bigger is always better, and in that vein, Rocksteady took the core gameplay of [i]Arkham Asylum[/i] and put it into an open world: Arkham City. [i]Asylum[/i] followed a metroidvania approach to design - an open, albeit focused map that extended its exploration by forcing players to obtain upgrades and continuously backtrack to open up new areas. In [i]Arkham City[/i], the whole of the map is immediately open, allowing players to explore as much or as little as they'd like. The problem with this approach in [i]Arkham City[/i], however, is that there is nothing worth exploring. There is not purpose to the sandbox approach,

There are side quests: Riddler challenges, Zsasz's phone calls, a mysterious guy that leaves glyphs, Bane's titan containers, saving political prisoners, tracking down Deadshot, I think I saw something about the Calendar man? None of these are interesting though. 
- Riddler challengers are just collectibles in various forms, and there are [i]a lot[/i]. There are too many. Now when you complete enough challenges you get to save a hostage. The puzzles here are actually unique and interesting. You just have to collect so many to get to each one...
- Zsasz calls, political prisoners, finding Deadshot, and finding the mysterious man are essentially random world events. None of them are interesting. I never completed any of these.
- I didn't even know the Calendar Man had anything.

With any of these, there just is not enough incentive to make me roam around the map hoping to stumble on them. Zsaaz calls are especially egregious, because the phones are usually surrounded by a group of thugs and by the time you beat them all down, you miss the call.  

[h1]The Story[/h1]

The story starts out incredibly weak. Arkham City is just a thing that you have to accept. Somehow, in the span of a few months after the events of [i]Arkham Asylum[/i], the warden, Quincy Sharp, who allowed the Joker to take over his asylum, gets elected mayor, and is manipulated into turning part of Gotham City into a prison. Bruce Wayne doesn't like this idea and gets kidnapped over it, and that's how Batman gets in. The problem here is Batman really has no motivation to do anything other than just leave. Instead, he chooses to stay to single-handedly stop yet another prison riot. But to call it a riot is somewhat misleading, because letting criminals loose to kill each other was kind of the whole point of Arkham City. 

But I digress. The story does eventually get much better, with several twists that keep you on your toes. The use of Ra's al Ghul and Mr. Freeze were fantastic. The cherry on top, of course, was further pushing Batman's relationship with Joker, which culminates perfectly.

[h1]Catwoman...[/h1]

Catwoman felt very shoehorned in. She plays a role at the very start and the very end of the game. Since she plays completely different from Batman in both combat and movement, she's hard to get used to. Some of her Riddler trophies also required Batman to obtain (e.g. the trophy is blocked by a destructible wall which Catwoman cannot break), which felt really cheap. It feels like Catwoman was supposed to play a bigger role, but due to time and/or scope creep, she got relegated to a few awkward side sections. She would have been better off as just being DLC.

[h1]Difficulty spikes[/h1]

Based on achievement stats, there is a notable drop off as players moved through the story. The reason being, I think, is that the game just gets relentlessly hard. About 60% of the way through the game, everyone has guns. There is sweet little Batman can do against guns. You can disable 2 at a time, but when 8 guns are in play, you still have to deal with 6 guys shooting you. The game requires you to be both exceptionally clever and patient, as it takes away any advantages you may have over guns (e.g. destroying vantage points and heat goggles that disable your stealth), and once in combat, Batman can only take away one gun at a time. If you grapple the gun away, someone else can just pick it up. Even when you get the upgrade to destroy guns, you can only do one at a time. I sympathize with everyone who dropped off, because this wasn't really a satisfying way to up the difficulty. And that speaks nothing of fights where you'll have guys with guns, stun sticks, shields, knives, and the unarmed ones constantly throwing objects at you. It's hard. It's frustrating. It's just not really fun. 

[h1]So What's Good?[/h1]

The core gameplay carried over from [i]Arkham Asylum[/i] is still solid. At times, the enemy count can get overwhelming, and the streamlined nature of the combat can make Batman do things you didn't really intend (e.g. leaping across the room to hit a stray enemy or grappling the guy next to the guy with the gun).  

There is still a good mix of exploration, puzzle solving and combat that helps mix up the gameplay. 

Like its predecessor, [i]Arkham City[/i] pits Batman against an impressive roster of classic villains. Each boss fight is unique, requiring the player to do more than mash the attack button to beat them down. The fight with Mr. Freeze in particular was my favorite. Any time you damage Freeze, he becomes immune to that attack. This forces the player to change strategies on the fly, all while hiding from Freeze, whose attacks will obliterate you, and whose armor is nigh impenetrable. 

[h1]Overall[/h1]

I know I highlighted a lot of negatives, but I still enjoyed the game. The core gameplay, for the most part, is enough to carry it. It feels like Rocksteady was attempting to take 3 steps forward from [i]Arkham Asylum[/i] and in doing so maybe overexerted themselves. The main story works. The setting, the writing, the villains, it all works. What doesn't work is the excessive bloat. Did there need to be over 300 Riddler challenges? Did Catwoman need to be part of the main campaign? Was any of the side content really worthwhile? Does the sandbox design serve the gameplay in any way? 

In my opinion, the answer to all of these is no. I would have preferred a much more focused gameplay experience, more akin to [i]Arkham Asylum[/i], rather than having content for the sake of content. I think I 100% completed [i]Asylum[/i] in about 10 hours. [i]City[/i] took me about 25, and I didn't 100% it. For me, that extra 15 hours did nothing other than make my experience worse.

Even if the game is old (2011), it still holds up pretty well in comparison to many more recent games.

Graphics have a bit that cartoonish look that ages well. Gameplay and fight while easy is still relevant and enjoyable. The maps is quite small but there are plenty to do and it's not filled with redundant objectives. However if you're a collector and want to gather all the collectibles, you're in for a long time.

It's enjoyable to switch from Batman to Catwoman and to Robin if you have the Harley Quinn DLC (quite enjoyable as well but much shorter and linear).

When it's on sales you can get this or the full package (Asylum, City, Knight & Origins with DLC) for such a cheap price that it's a steal.

Overall I'm impressed that this game is still that good after 12 years. Arkham asylum which I played a few year ago was also a delight.

I haven't quite beaten this main campaign yet, I'm the type of player where I like to beat the main campaign then go back for side quests.

Arkham City is clearly a step up mechanically from Arkham Asylum. The combat is better and the flight system kicks booty. The music is also way better, although that's a minor detail. I think there is one too many type of enemy, and I would choose to get rid of the blade guys, mostly because the counter is stupidly complex to do on PC. I also wish that more of the gadgets took out enemies in one hit. It doesn't make sense for me that a shock charge that's strong enough to magnetize a massive hook doesn't also knock someone out or kill them. I know it's a Batman game, but still...

I also tend to get randomly spotted a lot in this game, and it's unclear why. The bad guys in Asylum were idiots, and maybe they wanted to challenge the player a bit more. But sometimes, I'll be in the middle of a silent take down and some other guy from across the map will randomly turn around and spot me. It happens often enough to put it in this review.

I also don't like the snipers mechanic. They're super overpowered, and the game doesn't always tell you they're there until you're dead. Placing them around the city makes sense from the story perspective, but it's annoying mechanically to come around a corner and get brained by a sniper who you couldn't see beforehand. Not sure what I would do to fix that. But it's annoying.

I also don't find Strange a compelling villain, and his secret partnership is so stupidly half-baked that it doesn't make any sense. In fact, of all the flaws with this game, that is my biggest one: the villain(s) in the main plot-- other than Joker-- suck. There's no big boss battle. You just go up, take out Strange's henchmen, then a cutscene takes out Strange and any other villains that may be lurking around. I really hated that. Like, it's so weak in my opinion that I knocked off a whole 1.5 stars for it.

But those are all the things I dislike.
I like the way Riddler's puzzles are done (although, there are DEFINITELY too many of them). I like most of the side quests (except Zsasz, which is a cool side quest, but in order to do it, you have to stop everything you're doing and find a phone). I like the Catwoman stuff, and I think it's cool to get a second main character to use while fighting. I enjoyed playing as her more than I expected.

I LOVE that you can just end the campaign by walking out of Strange's vault with the gold. That is the kind of thing that elevates Rocksteady's Arkham games above other superhero games. The aesthetic is amazing, just like Asylum. There's a palpable sense of doom overshadowing everything, and it feels so much like a Batman story in that regard. They didn't overstuff the plot with villains, etc. I can always find complaints in a game, but there are so many things this game does right.

One of my favorite games of all time, it still looks good and plays good. The story and setting, the atmosphere, the level design, the writing and acting, are all top notch. And the gameplay fires on all cylinders; whether you are swooping through the streets of Gotham, beating thugs to a pulp with a variety of move and challenges, or swinging across rafters high up in the shadows above your unsuspecting targets, the game never stops being engaging and challenging. This is truly a videogame masterpiece, and I really mean it when I say this is one of the few games I have every played for which I don't have any significant constructive criticism. It know exactly what it wants to be and achieves it perfectly. I cannot recommend this game highly enough - and while you certainly can play it just fine with mouse and keyboard, I think the ideal experience is to be had with a controller.

[u]In a nutshell:[/u] Arkham Asylum, only bigger and better.

If you are familiar with the first game in the series, this is the basically the same thing, but on doping agents. Take the already established and proven action-brawler, refine the controls, make the use of the gadgets more intuitive, expand the storyline of each character, and make the whole experience open world. A recipe for success, if you ask me. Combat feels much more fluid and varied than before. The dark and well-thought-out story delivers the same quality of before while taking radical, irreversible steps too.

[u]Recommended if:[/u] You like a dark detective story, an interesting take on well-known comic characters, and if you want to meet your favourite comic characters animated and voiced with a great attention to detail.
[u]Not recommended if:[/u] You are an achievement hunter, as most of the challenges feel not only hard, but also a bit tedious and repetitive.

Game does not allow player to change difficulty, and mission fights cannot be exited.  Thus, if a fight ends up being too hard, you're just fucked.  For example, the joker boss fight, in which, aside from Joker, there are at least a dozen henchmen, plus *TWO OTHER FUCKING BOSSES*!  In a room with no cover, no elevated places to use the grapnel hook to get temporary relief, nothing whatsoever to give the player a fair chance, and with amusement park train cars rushing through periodically (and injuring you if they hit you) just to make it more frustrating.  After trying this mission numerous times, and looking in vain for some way to lower the difficulty, I finally ended up uninstalling the game.  I'm not going to waste my time with another playthrough on lower difficulty because I despise games that put their players in this untenable postion.

Batman: Arkham City is a really underwhelming game. It honestly doesn’t succeed in any facet. Its gameplay is unengaging. Its story is abysmal. Its characters are uncompelling. It is needlessly padded out with tons of filler. It’s dragged down by a host of issues. The game does not deserve “Overwhelmingly positive” reviews. I can only imagine it received such widespread adulation because it is a Batman game and it certainly is a Batman game, but is it good? No. Is it terrible? No. It’s middling at best.

The combat is unsatisfying. It can be fun here and there, but there just isn’t any depth. It doesn’t feel earned. I didn’t come away from it feeling like Batman. I felt like I was just playing a very violent rhythm game. On top of that, it’s weird in practice, too. Sometimes Batman will leap across two screens to attack a bad guy, then he’ll fumble an attack on a bad guy right next to him. There’s no rhyme or logic to it. And you’ll be pissed off when it happens because you then lose your combo for no good reason.

The game is utterly filled with content, but that doesn’t mean it is good content. It is Filler City. It is seriously padded out with a lot of meaningless content that is either trifling at best or just atrocious at worst. It suffers all the pitfalls of a Ubisoft-style open-world and is no more compelling for it. The side activities are shoddily implemented and feel tacked on as a way to expose the player to more of Batman’s rogues gallery. Unfortunately, it just doesn’t work for creating a fun or interesting experience. Why would I care to see more of these characters when the experience is the same for every one of them? They aren’t interesting to see. They are window dressing. I feel like 75-85% of the game could have easily been cut. And the resources dedicated to more meaningful, interesting content. 


The story is just abysmal. Batman himself is completely uninteresting here and the central dilemma plaguing him and the world at large is equally uncompelling. He has zero personality beyond delivering gruff lines to everyone around him while all the characters you interact with are homicidal maniacs that would be better off dead. The villains are particularly heinous here and it beggars belief that Batman lets them live after the crap they pull off repeatedly in the game. Even the villains that aren’t wholly evil act idiotic here, too, and it drags the story down even further.

There are two massive drivers of events in the game and one is completely shrouded in mystery til the very end, so you have zero reason to care about it. And the other is much more immediate, but due to the flat performances and needlessly tacked on filler, it doesn’t feel urgent at all. It is barely a blip in your mind. And you feel there are no stakes whatsoever to what you are doing.

I know Batman is a gruff character with a somber demeanor, but he’s more than that. We have seen him across a large variety of media. And he can be so much more. And be more dynamic and interesting. He’s complex with a lot of issues that extend well beyond the surface. And we just don’t see any of that here. It’s just the most surface-level interpretation of Batman being Batman and that’s that. 

I came away from this game feeling like I may have enjoyed parts of it, but it was ultimately just a tedious experience and after playing other games, my opinion has been revised downwards. It just isn’t a good game. It wasn’t even a good game for its time. I’ve played a ton of games from its time period recently and it doesn’t measure up to any of them. I know my opinion is in the minority, but hey, it is what it is.

You might be skipping this thinking "oh it's just the last-gen version of Arkham Knight, I bet everything is the same minus the batmobile". No it really isn't; the main difference is not in the more obvious points such as graphics fidelity or controls prompt, it's in the rhythm of combat. Yes it's simpler, there is no medic or electrified suits here, but you'll find the rhythm of attacks and counters to be more satisfying. Unlike in arkham knight where you are forced to use one very specific quickfire gadgets to counter certain type of attack (batarang for charging thug, batclaw for electrified goon etc) you are free to tackle the combat with fists only ...if you're up to it. Difficulty of challenge maps lies in the number of thugs and their attack speed (not to be underestimated on Hard modifier), not on cheap tricks like spawning 8 shield thugs at once like AK. 
Predator encounters also have different vibes, excluding the apparent absence of Fear Takedown; it is smaller and denser, and though the thugs still jog in conveniently slow speed, they move faster compared to thugs in AK (which the more compact map size also contributes to). It's easier to be seen and shot, and those henchmen really don't miss. Admittedly, the predator maps' design could feel pretty artificial at times (like having gargoyles and gargoyle-like objects where they clearly don't belong, or odd stretch of floor grates on unlikely places) but they do provide unique environmental takedowns that you rarely see on AK. (window takedown, vent takedown, overhanging choke etc)

As for the open world, it is small and offers very little after you're done with campaign (practically devoid of thugs to the point where you can memorize everybody's location) but it does have solid, gloomy dead-city vibe which stimulates the imagination; how it might have looked like before Arkham City, how did the prisoners live here amidst the gang war and so on. 

Ultimately, this game is for those of you who want a more compact and focused combat experience, less frustrating but longer combat challenge maps, and smaller but denser predator maps.

First of all, the game was great as well with the DLC. Then trying to 100% the game was a massive pain. Specifically, the Riddler Challenge/Campaign. They weren't that hard to say but was tedious to do it for four characters and hearing Riddler voice ever time I failed was slowly losing my mind. After finishing the hard part of the game, went to play the Harley DLC leaving me one last trophy which I left it alone until I got the others first.

This game has become one of my favorite games and if you haven't played it already then play it right now. 

I'll admit I could not get into at first. My goal was to get all the achievements like I did in Asylum and the 400 Riddler collectibles was a bit overwhelming. With the mindset of I have to get everything I enjoyed it less and it felt like a task to play. I only got about 6 or so hours on the game and didn't touch it for months. I finally decided to pick it up again, except now with the mindset of play and enjoy the story and worry about collectible and side missions later. The story is great and I quickly become obsessed with the game. 

The combat in Asylum was great and fun, but City adds more moves that (once you get the hang of them) creates even more entertaining fights. The ability to play as different characters with different moves helps to make the combat challenges more interesting and less repetitive. 

The amount of side mission and Riddler collectibles adds much more playtime, but it can be a bit tedious. I focused on the main story so I am just now getting to the other stuff, and the amount of trophies is starting to annoy me a bit. Most of the side missions are quite fun, and are kept short and sweet (loved the Mad Hatter one), but for some I feel like it ends too quickly and easily (like the Zsasz mission). 

Overall, this is an amazing game. If you enjoyed Arkham Asylum, you will absolutely love this game. The combat is entertaining, side missions are fun, and main story is great. 10/10 would recommend.

This is a big improvement over Arkham Asylum, which was already excellent. More of the same punchy combat, improved by more gadgets and a variety of enemy types. Combat often feels more like a puzzle now; you have to think about how and when to take out the enemies that require special moves. The story is even better than the first game. Being able to explore the whole city is much more open, like you'd expect a Batman game to feel rather than the small corridors of the Asylum. I really enjoyed the story on the whole, although there were a couple of annoying boss fights. The ending is particularly good. If you enjoyed the first one, absolutely play this.

[b]Pros[/b]
- Features Catwoman (which is not only cool, but also adds a new skill tree and some variation in gameplay)
- Graphical upgrades since Arkham
- While Arkham Asylum was very linear, being in the city really opens it up with lots of verticality
- You can now use the Batclaw to pull yourself to ledges while gliding, which is really useful for the new open environment
- New additions: Double take down, smoke bomb, slide tackle, double parry, titans are less annoying, knife dodge, different format of Riddler puzzles, line launcher can change direction in flight, electrical charges, freeze projectiles, shield enemies, armoured enemies, lots more enemies with guns, a gun disabler device
- Really enjoyed the boss fight with Mr. Freeze, as you have to think about the environment and use all your abilities
- There's a section where Batman is knocked out and needs help, and you're playing as Catwoman. You're given a choice whether to escape with your loot and leave Batman to die, or go save him. You can genuinely just leave the city and leave Batman to die, and the credits roll
- Nice short main story with lots of extra side content if you want to keep playing
- The annoying Scarecrow sections from the first game are gone (with only one annoying mad hatter section to replace them)

[b]Cons[/b]
- I found the number of new gadgets and abilities rather overwhelming. It's built for consoles, so everything's on a D-pad switcher and various controller button combinations which I constantly forgot or mixed up
- The game crashed during a boss fight

[h1]Batman: Arkham City[/h1]

[u]The story:[/u]

Arkham City is my favourite entry in the trilogy by far. The story is incredibly fun to follow, but my only gripe with it is that Strange was barely a factor in the story by the end. Even though, since the beginning, it was sort of a given that strange would be the centrepiece of the story, unfortunately, the same can't be said about the side missions in the game. They were very bland in comparison to the main story and felt like useless filler.

[u]The Gameplay:[/u]

Moving on to the game play, it is for sure a big step up compared to Arkham Asylum. The issue is that while the combat felt good and the stealth even better, the Catwoman sections of the story were quite the bore to play through. Her movement felt extremely lacking in comparison to Batman's, and the combat was less engaging with her lack of gadgets. The bosses in the game were quite fun, though, especially the Mister Freeze fight, which was super innovative.

My biggest gripe with this game, though, is its Riddler missions. As is usual with these games, for some godforsaken reason they need to include a collectathon in the game for it to be complete. There are over 400 Riddler trophies and such that need to be collected for you to even complete his side story. While I understand it's completely optional, it does feel like a slap in the face to have to endure such unnecessary filler to get the achievement.

Last but not least, the Riddler's Revenge content. Honestly, I've never dealt with a more infuriating set of challenges in my life. To complete the related achievements, you have to endure the same sets of maps four times as Batman, Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing. This whole set of challenges takes filler to a whole new level. The way Arkham Asylum handled challenges was extremely fun. They were challenging but not overdone in quantity, with not much repetition. Here though? Were forced to endure the terrible movement of Catwoman and the horrifying mass of missions and campaigns.

[u]Overall:[/u]

Ignoring my gripes with the collectathons in the game, I think that Batman Arkham City is a top-notch game that tells its story in a way that's enjoyable and never infuriating. It's a relaxing game with an incredible story that leaves you itching for more. There are low points in the game, but the overwhelming majority of it is worth your time, even when not on sale. I do suggest waiting for the insane sales that the game frequently has, though.

One of the best games of all time. Still holds up in 2023. 

The great parts - 

The game's atmosphere.

Combat, stealth/predator sections are awesome and highly improved from Arkham Asylum with new mechanics, gadgets and takedowns,

The music and voice acting is top notch.

Boss fights - Mr. Freeze and Ra's al Ghul are one of the best fights not only in the series, but in all of gaming as well.


The only downsides are - 

The story is not that great, it starts off strong, but it is difficult to ignore the plot holes. Nevertheless, it is an enjoyable ride.

There are too many Riddler trophies and collecting them is required to finish a side mission.

Nighwing is only playable in Challenge maps and does not have a story DLC. Additionally there should have been a dedicated tutorial for the character as his moves are quite different.

You can only change Display settings and keyboard and mouse controls from the game launcher and not the in-game menu

This was the first game in the Arkham series that I played. Definitely a 10/10 for me.

FYI I ran into some problems wherein the first time I launched the game, the cutscene would play and then the game would crash without any errors or prompts. This happened repeatedly. I searched some forums online and found that it had to be some issue with Nvidia PhysX, The fix was simple.
1. Go to the NVIDIA Control Panel
2. Click on Set PhysX Configuration from the side pane
3. Select CPU as the PhysX processor from the drop down list and you're good to go.
The game ran smooth after that.

After buying the full trilogy (and being really pissed off that Arkham Knight wouldn't work with my $1000 laptop) I got bored of Arkham Asylum after playing the gargoyle parts over and over because that one guard named John wouldn't stop finding my location instantly I decided to give the next game in the incredible trilogy. Arkham City encapsulates the great elements of open world and fast-paced combat perfectly into its amazing story. All of the boss fights feel genuinely different and it's impossible to predict what happens next. The voice acting is incredible and with the talents of Kevin Conroy, Troy Baker and Corey Burton it truly feels like you're grappling through the (sometimes submerged) streets of Gotham. 

Overall, Arkham City is a great game with even greater fun and it will remain IMO as the best Arkham game

Well, what to say about Batman: Arkham City? For starters, it's an exceptionally designed game. The game is truly "immersive" in the way it sets the whole atmosphere and mood of the world. It draws you into the Batman universe and lets you experience being the hero like you've always imagined. For example, everything from gliding and grappling around the city to using gadgets and pummeling goons feels accurate and fine-tuned. The story is intriguing with some good plot twists and features plenty of fan-favorites including Catwoman, the Joker, Harley Quinn, Mr. Freeze etc. You can also expect stellar voice acting and a phenomenal sound track. As for game length, my completion time for the main story clocked in around 50 hrs. ,and there's still more to play after the credits roll! Not to mention challenge mode and the bonus chapter. Overall, I would rank Arkham City as one of the best games I've played as well as the best superhero action game ever made. An easy 9/10.

I have mixed feelings on this game, the combat system is greatly improved from arkham asylum allowing more gadgets to be used and bringing in new ones as well. The game features incredible voice acting and the graphics still hold up fairly well. Now I did like the story but it kinda has an identity crisis, it can't decide weather it wants to be about Joker or Hugo Strange, I previously didn't like the game so much but my latest play through i really did enjoy it, I'd hesitate a bit to call this an open world game at least by modern standards and I can imagine this was probably pushing the limits back then. There were some points in combat where batman would randomly attack a different target, idk if it was something i did or a bug. One of the things I did not like was how many times you would go to one place to get something then go back to the original location only to have to go to an entirely new area, it becomes a bit repetitive. Overall while I didn't enjoy as much as Asylum or Knight, it's hard not to find some joy with dynamic duo of Kevin Conroys Batman and Mark Hamils Joker

Attention, residents of Gotham City, Prisoner 00 Destroy Lonely has escaped. I repeat, prisoner 00 Destroy, Lonely, has escaped from Arkham Asylum. Do not engage, he is extremely dangerous and a threat to public safety. Victim reports claim he is the Fashion.. Demon.

As a devoted fan of the Dark Knight, I can confidently say that Batman: Arkham City is an electrifying masterpiece that pushes the boundaries of what a superhero game can be. Rocksteady Studios has once again proven their expertise in crafting an immersive and gripping experience, taking players on a dark and atmospheric journey through the sprawling open-world streets of Gotham City.

From the moment you step foot into the decrepit and dangerous Arkham City, you are immediately engulfed in a rich and intricately designed world. The attention to detail in the environments, from the iconic landmarks to the sinister alleys, is simply breathtaking. The developers have managed to capture the essence of Gotham City, making it feel like a character in its own right, adding to the immersion and the sense of being the Caped Crusader.

The gameplay is where Batman: Arkham City truly shines. Fluid combat mechanics, intuitive controls, and an extensive array of gadgets make you feel like you are truly embodying the Dark Knight. Engaging in bone-crushing battles against a diverse array of villains, each with their unique abilities and strategies, provides an adrenaline-pumping experience that remains enjoyable throughout the game.

The storytelling in Arkham City is compelling and mature, successfully capturing the essence of Batman's world. The narrative delves into the darker aspects of the Batman mythos, tackling complex themes such as morality, justice, and the blurred lines between hero and villain. The game's voice acting is top-notch, with Mark Hamill's iconic portrayal of the Joker stealing the show and Kevin Conroy reprising his role as Batman with gravitas.

One of the most impressive aspects of the game is the rich gallery of rogues that Batman faces. From iconic villains like Two-Face, Poison Ivy, and Penguin to the enigmatic and terrifying Hugo Strange, each character is given enough depth and personality to make them memorable and captivating foes.

Arkham City's side missions and collectibles offer a vast amount of content that will keep players hooked for hours on end. Whether you're solving intricate Riddler puzzles, tracking down notorious criminals, or uncovering hidden secrets, there's always something exciting to do within the boundaries of this twisted city.

Moreover, the game's seamless integration of detective work adds a refreshing layer of gameplay that showcases Batman's intellect and strategic prowess. Solving crime scenes using forensic tools and piecing together clues feels gratifying and highlights Batman's multifaceted nature as a hero.

In terms of presentation, the graphics are stunning, and the music score perfectly complements the dark and brooding atmosphere, further immersing players into the world of Batman. Additionally, the attention to detail in character designs and animations contributes to an overall visually appealing and polished experience.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City is a tour de force in superhero gaming, offering an outstanding combination of compelling storytelling, exceptional gameplay mechanics, and a beautifully crafted world. Whether you're a die-hard Batman fan or just looking for an exceptional gaming experience, Arkham City is an absolute must-play. It cements itself as a legendary title that will be celebrated for years to come

Personal words about the game: When I first played this game, I played it as a pirate copy and because the game was not original, the save files were reset every time I closed the game. This meant I had to play the game without ever quitting or turning off my PC to complete it. Most people around me used to play mainly football or FPS games and since none of them played story-based RPGs or stealth-themed games, I couldn't find a solution to the problem of losing save files. Of course, I was happy to play the game after purchasing it. While playing the game, I was thrilled inside as it was something I had always wanted to play properly since my childhood but never got the chance to do so.

There's something to tell about the story: The game starts with a pointy eared shadow sneaking up on the thugs but this pointy eared person is not Batman. It's Catwoman, the other playable character in the game. After a short sequence of theft and capture, the game switches to the main character. The continuation of the game continues with Bruce's speech against this new prison and things are not going well for him. Later one of the three major villains in the game, Hugo Strange. Reveals that he knows Batman's true identity and foolishly releases him into Arkham City instead of directly killing him. What a genius. After that, you wear the costume and face a lot of puzzles to solve, save, and investigate in a small, lifeless open world. Meanwhile, the only problem is not the revelation of the secret identity. Also the development and wider use of the titan formula used by Joker in Asylum. To investigate this matter, Batman goes to Joker's location and is poisoned by Joker. He also has to find a solution to this problem. In Arkham games, the story always ends within one night and this game is no exception. The story progresses nicely and diversely. So side characters appear as part of the main story and continue without losing momentum. For example, characters like Mr. Freeze and Mad Hatter have almost no difference between main and side missions. Of course, this is not a bad thing because their side missions are of main mission quality, which positively affects the game. Finally, having 2 playable characters means 2 different perspectives, so some of the stories interact with each other.

Retinal Pleasure or Art: Textures and graphics have been further enhanced compared to the first game. Especially the frozen police station in the Mr. Freeze fight, the section filled with water by Penguin, and the League of Assassin sections were beautifully designed. Costumes have been diversified and detailed for all controllable characters. Perhaps the Batman Beyond costume could be a little skinnier, then it would be much better.

Mechanics: This game, which is already a sequel to a game with very good mechanics, naturally reached the peak of its era with even more improved mechanics. It excels in close combat, and you can use the equipment you possess to create various combos during fights. Now let's talk about the important mechanics of stealth that the game has. It's important to note that you shouldn't expect a Thief-style stealth like in the previous game. The stealth in this game involves climbing on ledges, hiding in grates, staying in plain sight of enemies, being able to move silently even while running, and gliding over your enemies. Then you take them down, but this kind of stealth suits the game well because Batman is more of a super-secret agent ninja than a realistic character. Apart from that, you can use your equipment for stealth purposes. For example, you can place three explosive gels on a wall and detonate them when enemies approach, taking them all down effortlessly. Additionally, there are Riddler's puzzles, and it was quite enjoyable to solve them using the equipment you possess. Also, the mechanics of Catwoman, Nightwing, and Robin are similar in the same regard. All four characters have unique styles, but they can be roughly categorized as 2 acrobatic and 2 heavy hitters. Catwoman and Nightwing are acrobatic fighters, while Batman and Robin are heavier fighters. This doesn't mean they are slow, it's just that their movements are not as acrobatic as the others, which is reasonable considering their origins.

Atto Finale: In the end, if you still haven't bought the game, get it and play. You will not regret it because of the diversity of the story, the richness of mechanics and the ability to experiment with various trials thanks to its small mod kit. In fact, you will even seek more games of this kind.

If you just completed Batman Arkham Asylum, you will definitely enjoy the sequel from that game.
Batman Arkham City is a great part 2 of this amazing franchise and doesn't disappoint in any way.
There is a big open area "Gotham City" that you can explore, a lot of side quests, a rich & fun main story and a lot of Riddler Challenges & Trophies to do and collect a long the way.
You will meet old characters from the previous game such as[spoiler] Zsasz, Poison Ivy, Bane, Riddler, Harley Quinn, etc. and the main man himself; the Joker.[/spoiler]
It took me a total of 75 hours to fully complete the game and get all of the achievements. (Main story, Side quests, Riddler Trophies & Challenges, Combat & Challenges Mode, DLC content and miscellaneous trophies like "Perfect Freeflow 2.0".
I think most of the time gets invested in collecting the riddler trophies and doing side activities.
Nonetheless, the game provides even more combat moves from the previous game and this time you even start with almost all of the Batman Arkham Asylum gadgets from the beginning.
In conclusion: If you enjoyed Batman Arkham Asylum, then this game won't disappoint you at the slightest.

[h1] The Batman Sequel That Does Everything Right [/h1]

The sequel to Rockysteady's Batman: Arkham Asylum, Arkham City brings a whole new experience to the Batman Arkham franchise. With new gadgets, a new fighting system, an entire city to explore, and a great story. 

[h1] The Batman Rises [/h1]

[spoiler] The game tells you to climb ACE Chemicals in the first 10 minutes of the game (hilarious! I know!) [/spoiler] The story greatly improves from Asylum, and has the amazing voice work of Kevin Conroy (may he R.I.P.), Mark Hamil, Troy Baker, Steve Blum, and more other great VAs. The story has excellent foreshadowing, and keeps you engaged until the end. [spoiler] Except for the Catwoman Episodes [/spoiler]

[h1] The Ruined City [/h1]

In Arkham City, you play in a ruined [spoiler] Gotham [/spoiler]. The city is swarming with thugs and other obstacles in your way. There are more collectibles than last time, but they are not too difficult to find. The textures in the map are meh for a 2011 game, but luckily, there are many graphics mods you can download from nexusmods to make the game more visually appealing. 

[h1] The Improved Gameplay [/h1]

Not much to say when it comes to the gameplay, other than it is drastically improved on with the better gadgets, more fighting animations, and a more precise fighting system. The gameplay gets better when you see how these elements affect the gameplay of other characters. 

[h1] Riddler's Dungeon [/h1]

Riddler's Revenge will take the most time in your completionist playthrough. You have 4 characters to play instead of 1, and the maps can be hard for everything to work perfectly. On the other hand, some of the maps are fun with certain characters.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Batman: Arkham City advances the game with new gameplay elements, gadgets and characters. For a completionist playthrough, you will struggle with it (possibly burnout from the Riddler's Revenge Challenges), but the rest of the game is the breath of fresh air you need.
Makes you really FEEL like Batman. Just don't do Riddler stuff you will regret it.

Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition, developed by Rocksteady Studios, is a gripping and atmospheric action-adventure game that transports players to the heart of Gotham City's darkest corners. With its immersive open-world, engrossing storyline, and polished gameplay, Arkham City stands as a true masterpiece that showcases the pinnacle of superhero gaming.

One of the standout features of Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition is its sprawling and immersive open-world environment. The game expands upon the foundations laid in its predecessor, Arkham Asylum, by allowing players to freely explore a vast section of Gotham City that has been converted into a prison district. Every street, alley, and towering structure is meticulously crafted, creating an atmospheric and dynamic cityscape that oozes with noir-inspired ambiance. The attention to detail, coupled with the diverse and beautifully realized districts, brings Gotham City to life like never before.

The gripping storyline of Arkham City is another highlight of the game. Players assume the role of Batman as he navigates the treacherous streets of Arkham City, pitted against a cast of iconic villains led by the enigmatic Hugo Strange. The narrative unfolds with intricate twists and turns, offering a thought-provoking exploration of Batman's psyche and his relentless pursuit of justice. The writing is superb, with powerful character development and memorable dialogue that captures the essence of Batman's struggle against the forces of darkness.

The gameplay mechanics of Arkham City are refined and polished, offering an exceptional blend of stealth, combat, and exploration. As the Dark Knight, players have access to an extensive arsenal of gadgets and combat techniques, allowing for creative and strategic approaches to encounters. The fluid combat system seamlessly blends punches, counters, and gadgetry into satisfying combo-driven battles. The predator sections, which emphasize stealth and silent takedowns, provide a thrilling cat-and-mouse dynamic as Batman takes down enemies one by one. The intuitive controls and responsive gameplay mechanics ensure that players feel like the ultimate crime-fighting vigilante.

The Game of the Year Edition of Arkham City includes all the previously released downloadable content (DLC), further expanding the already rich gameplay experience. From additional story missions and challenge maps to new playable characters, the DLC enhances the longevity and replayability of the game, providing players with even more content to explore and enjoy.

Visually, Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition is a feast for the eyes. The game boasts stunning graphics, with detailed character models, atmospheric lighting, and impressive visual effects. The grim and gritty art style perfectly captures the essence of Gotham City, creating a visually immersive and believable world.

In addition to its captivating single-player campaign, Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition offers an engaging challenge mode that allows players to test their skills in combat and stealth scenarios. This mode provides a satisfying and competitive experience, as players strive to achieve high scores and perfect their Batman skills.

In conclusion, Batman: Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition is a tour de force in superhero gaming. Its immersive open-world, gripping storyline, and polished gameplay make it an essential experience for both Batman fans and lovers of action-adventure games. Whether you're exploring the grim streets of Gotham, engaging in intense combat encounters, or unraveling the dark secrets of Arkham City, every moment of Arkham City - Game of the Year Edition is an exhilarating and unforgettable journey. Don the cape, embrace the shadows, and immerse yourself in the ultimate Batman experience.

One of the best games ever made. The Arkham trilogy/quadrilogy (origins) is a complete masterpiece, Asylum, City, and Knight are all some of the best games ever (Origins is also amazing). Some of it may be from nostalgia when playing these game as a kid, but even without seeing these games through nostalgia-tinted glasses, they still hold up as masterpieces. The voice acting (RIP Kevin Conroy) was phenomenal, story well written, combat/gameplay being simple but extremely fun with some challenge to it, and the music being absolutely breathtaking, with slow and atmospheric tracks, followed by tense orchestras and choirs building up to an epic finale. It was all so tightly knit and crafted with love for Batman, the DC universe, and games as a whole. Hopefully there will be another Arkham game in the coming years. 

10/10, RIP Kevin Conroy, you'll always be the one true Batman for millions out there.

This game was my childhood. When asylum came out my dad would play it and I'd sit on the couch and just watch for hours. I remember how excited he was when the sequel (this game) came out, as was I.

Perhaps I value this game more because it is shrouded by the pure nostalgia and fond memories I have of it, but it sincerely is one of my favorite games that I have ever played.

Some lines are cheesy, but many carry a great impact with them, of course due to the incredible performances from the entire voice cast, but ESPECIALLY Kevin Conroy (rest in piece) and Mark Hamill, as they reprise their roles as Batman and Joker.

The music of this game can be anything from thrillingly intense as there will be an entire orchestra of many stringed instruments and the haunting use of a choir in the background, to more quiet and stress building pieces, even to just emotional ones.

The story is truly something special and unique with a good twist and many hints toward that twist that you will notice on subsequent playthroughs.

I somehow managed to not even mention the combat in these games yet. 
There are 2 main types of combat, that being FreeFlow combat, and Predator combat. 


The FreeFlow combat is seriously incredible. It feels much more fluid than it had in Asylum, which is a theme of this game. The game as a whole took everything that made Asylum great and made it spectacular, the hand to hand combat being part of that.

The combat is normally criticized for being "button-mashy" which I can see where people are coming from, but it really is deep and complex and even challenging as the game continues. It is incredibly satisfying and the animations flow together incredibly well. It's easy to pick up but hard to master, which is perfect in my eyes.

The predator combat is one of the most unique systems that the game has to offer. You play as Batman in stealth encounters where you must pick off armed enemies one by one until you have cleared the area. Music intensifies, henchmen's heartbeats rise as they find fallen members and their movements get more sporadic and much much more.

I hate to use the overused term, but... It really makes you FEEL like Batman.

I wish I could say more but the amount of respect I have for this series as a whole is something too immense to put into words for a steam review.




Thank you Rocksteady for helping to craft this cornerstone of my childhood.

The Bat is back and broodier than ever in this upscaled addition to the Rocksteady canon. Naturally, this means doubling down on the combat, gadgets, side-missions, and the world itself. Before I go into detail, does Arkham City prove itself a worthy sequel to the legacy of Arkham Asylum? 100%, and in many ways surpasses it.

The story is grand, engaging, and packed full of iconic Batman rogues, all underlit by an absolutely chilling operatic theme. Without spoiling too much, it does a marvelous job at elevating the stakes and action, with multiple factions vying for control of the isolated Arkham City. With the exception of Hugo Strange, Catwoman, and Robin being underutilized, it was a fantastic story that really expanded on the Batman mythos. Speaking of, Batman himself is definitely more moody this time around, but beside the fact that he’s the Dark Knight, there’s a good reason for his grumpiness here.

In Arkham City, you’re working with a much bigger playground than before, which feels like the perfect size. Landmarks are clear and gliding has been made more involved and practical for travel, making it a blast to coast around the city. What’s more, the various side missions are short, sweet treats that put the spotlight on the lesser featured villains. Sure, some missions are a bit less deep than I’d like, but it was cool to see so many new and returning faces.

Most noticeable of all, the combat has been greatly expanded, both for and against you. But don’t be mistaken, the game is still heavily in your favor. The special moves and gadgets make going through this entry a relative breeze. Like Arkham Asylum, City is easy if you know what you’re doing. To me, the draw of Rocksteady combat (beside the animations) has always been trying to build the biggest combo using the largest variety of special moves. And with challenge mode being back and bigger than ever, allowing you to now play Catwoman, Robin, and Nightwing, there’s no shortage of opportunities to lay the hurt on some unsuspecting mooks. This extends to the breakout boss fights like Mr. Freeze as well, which really emphasizes thinking outside the box.

Batman Arkham City is an extraordinary game that has captivated players for a decade. From its release on the Xbox to today, it remains an absolute gem in the world of video games.

The game's gripping storyline continues the narrative from Arkham Asylum, immersing players in a sprawling prison-like Gotham City. Facing iconic villains like The Joker and Two-Face, the plot unfolds with unpredictable twists, delivering a cinematic experience that keeps you hooked.

The open-world of Arkham City is a marvel, with incredible attention to detail. Every corner is filled with secrets and side missions, creating an engaging playground for Batman fans. The seamless navigation mechanics allow you to truly embody the Dark Knight as you glide through the night sky and traverse rooftops.

The gameplay mechanics are exceptional, featuring fluid combat and empowering gadgets. Each encounter feels like a perfectly choreographed dance of strategy and timing. Whether countering enemies or silently taking down thugs, the satisfaction is unmatched.

Batman Arkham City is a timeless masterpiece that continues to shine. It's a must-play for anyone looking for an unforgettable gaming experience.
