I don't even know what to say or what to begin with. I lost my safe file back in the day and needed to start all over after a long break, which made me prone to being frustrated and disappointed throughout the experience, but it went surprisingly well.
The game kept me hooked for quite a while so I 100%-ed the campaign + the DLC and it didn't feel repetitive at all. Some challenges or riddles showed new ways to use your skills and gadgets, which I didn't even know where possible.
The graphics, mechanics, animations and the amount of them counting their smoothness is shocking for me, because this game is almost [b] 12 years old [/b] at the time of review. I just wish that Robin's arc would be longer and that there would be a Nigthwing campaign, because I adored their unique combat styles which were on par with Batman's.
[b] Definitely recommend to grab this one at least on sale and give it a go. [/b]

The sequel to Arkham Asylum, and in what few ways the original was lackluster or had fault, this game improves and delivers. The story expands to more than just fighting Joker, and the combat is anything but stale as many old moves are present from the start and new moves are introduced throughout the game. Quick fire gadgets are implemented in a much more streamlined way, and the various takedowns in the Predator section are both easier to pull off and more varied. In my opinion, this game is the pinnacle of the Arkham series. 10/10, although I admit the Riddler's Revenge DLC was a bit of slog to go through.

Pretty Good Story continuity with it's predecessor Arkham Asylum. Riddler's Trophies stories explain somehow the few Questionmarks left with the intro cutscene too. Overall a nice game, as you can play with Catwoman (Catwoman DLC) and Robin (Harley's Revenge DLC)  besides Batman. More takedown combos!!

Arkham City is simply one of the best games ever made. Not only is the story enthralling even 10 years later, the game itself is simply amazing in the way it handles and how they executed nearly every element of the game. The improvement between Asylum and City was so vast that it almost makes it tough to go back to Asylum due to the massive upgrade that City had. Combat is honestly at it's peak here, as it has just enough variety to make each fight fun, but not too much to where you feel overwhelmed. Even if you're not a fan of Batman and his adventures, I advise everyone to get this game.

Batman Arkham City is a great game that improves on the greatness of Arkham Asylum in plenty of ways. I enjoyed that some of the unlockable abilities from the first game were available from the start, such as the gargoyle takedown where you grab someone from above and hang them on it. There are also plenty of new gadgets and the main hub is a massive improvement from the first game with new ways to get around with gliding, more buildings and criminals throughout. The story also felt improved over the first game and the ending was great. This is definitely the best game I have played recently.

Batman: Arkham City - A Dark and Riveting Superhero Adventure

Introduction:
Step into the gritty and atmospheric world of Gotham City once again in Batman: Arkham City, the critically acclaimed action-adventure game developed by Rocksteady Studios. In this review, we delve into the shadows to explore why this sequel to Batman: Arkham Asylum has become a beloved and iconic entry in the Batman gaming franchise on Steam.

Engaging Open-World Gameplay (9/10):
Arkham City takes the gameplay of its predecessor and expands it into an open-world setting, allowing players to freely explore the vast and atmospheric streets of Gotham City. As Batman, you'll navigate through towering skyscrapers, dive into the grimy underbelly of the city, and engage in exhilarating combat encounters with a variety of iconic villains. The seamless integration of exploration, stealth, and combat mechanics creates an immersive and satisfying gameplay experience.

Combat Perfection (10/10):
The combat system in Arkham City is a highlight of the game, building upon the already excellent mechanics of Arkham Asylum. As Batman, you'll unleash a flurry of punches, kicks, and gadgets in fluid and brutal combat sequences. The timing-based combat system rewards skillful play, allowing players to chain together devastating combos while countering enemy attacks with precise timing. The combat in Arkham City is both empowering and deeply satisfying, making players truly feel like the Dark Knight.

Captivating Storyline (9/10):
The narrative of Arkham City is a dark and gripping tale that immerses players in the corrupt and dangerous world of Gotham City. As Batman, you find yourself trapped within the walls of Arkham City, a sprawling prison overrun by criminals and ruled by the enigmatic Hugo Strange. The intricate plot weaves together iconic Batman villains, including The Joker, Two-Face, and The Riddler, leading to unexpected twists and turns that keep players on the edge of their seats.

Immersive Atmosphere and Stunning Visuals (9/10):
Gotham City is brought to life with a stunning level of detail and atmospheric design. The gritty streets, dilapidated buildings, and iconic landmarks create an immersive and believable world. The dark and moody visuals, coupled with the exceptional voice acting performances, including Mark Hamill's unforgettable portrayal of The Joker, further enhance the overall experience and make Arkham City a truly immersive and cinematic adventure.

Abundance of Side Quests and Collectibles (8/10):
Beyond the main storyline, Arkham City offers a wealth of side quests, challenges, and collectibles to discover. From solving intricate puzzles set by The Riddler to tracking down hidden Riddler trophies scattered throughout the city, there is always something to do and explore. These additional activities provide hours of additional gameplay and reward players with valuable upgrades and secrets, further extending the longevity of the game.

Conclusion:
Batman: Arkham City is a superb action-adventure game that showcases the dark and brooding world of Gotham City with exceptional gameplay, a captivating storyline, and stunning visuals. The seamless blend of exploration, combat, and stealth mechanics, coupled with the gripping narrative and iconic characters, make for an unforgettable gaming experience. Whether you're a Batman fan or simply a lover of immersive open-world adventures, Arkham City is a must-play title that solidifies its place as one of the greatest superhero games of all time. Embrace the cape and cowl, and let Arkham City take you on an unforgettable journey into the heart of darkness.

Game is old and hasn't been updated to run with Windows 11.
AMD double driver? Microsoft Net 3.5? Come on. The launcher even
fails with flying colors. Error. Uninstall.  Bang head against wall.
Realize the installer is missing Direct X stuff.

So I install Direct X End-User Runtime Web Installer.
Installs missing files. Done. Game starts. As good as I
remember. Now to act like Gotham Knight never existed.
Then I realize how dated this game's combat is mechanically, and did not
age well.

 I have to deduct points. Protocol 10 was a letdown. Scanning helicopters while getting shot at was tedious. There's an overabundance of stealth sections, not enough combat in the campaign. I found myself learning on the fly and dying.

Also guns. Stop tossing guns into everything and calling it hard. Seriously. There is an overabundance of armed enemies. 9 times out of 10 I get hit after or while disarming an enemy. Batman is the only character that can destroy weapons as a special ability. My advice? Play defensively. Always. 

Near mid to end game, most common enemies have guns, and after you beat the game, 90% of them are packing assault rifles by default, and they will shoot you outside of street brawls. Through fences and rooftops. It's worse than the stinking helicopters. It made kid me angry in 2012, and still irritates me in 2023.

New game plus is just moronic. They remove the visual cues and that just makes combat more chaotic and irritating. Everything is already an ugly, washed out grey and blue. On top of that enemies can hit you coming out of a counter, which is already difficult to tolerate if they pile up on you. The only way to get more exp is to do New game+. It's just a harder and sometimes unfair experience. Getting around in Arkham City is a chore. Movement feels restricted and slow. 

The gadgets in this game are mostly gimmick related outside of combat, and only serve to chase down hidden stuff. In combat gadgets do three things. Stun an enemy or freeze them. Sometimes knocks em down. That's it. Beyond that, Catwoman is the only character with crowd control, and I find her more fun to play as than Batman. Nightwing and Robin  don't count, because they are bonus characters that you can't use in the main campaign.

Overall a solid game, but lacks any replay value outside of the fun combat. 7/10.

During the installation process, along with the DirectX libraries, another program will be installed called AMD Dual-Core Optimizer which was meant to improve the performance on systems that run Windows XP and use old AMD Dual-Core CPUs.

On PCs that run Windows Vista and later and/or an Intel CPU, you won't need that program because it will impact the performance and cause other issues.

Unfortunately when you launch the game for the first time you don't get the choice to decline the installation of AMD Dual-Core Optimizer (that's why I left a negative review).
In order to stop that program from being installed, do as follows:

If the program is already installed, you should uninstall it. Go to "Programs and Features", select "AMD Dual-Core Optimizer" and click "Uninstall" (perhaps it will take a while, do not cancel the process and wait); afterwords, reboot the PC.

1) Go to the installation folder of the game (right click on the game title -> properties -> local files tab -> browse local files)
2) Open "installscript.vdf" (right click -> open with -> use Notepad)
3) Scroll down until you see the word "AMD", followed by a bunch of code between the two perpendicular { and } brackets; delete that portion of code, beginning from the word "AMD" to the last perpendicular bracket (note that you must leave the brackets on the left side and everything else)
4) Save the file. Make sure you didn't delete anything that has to do with DXSetup, VCRedist_x86 and DotNetFx35
5) When you're done, go to the "Setup" folder and delete "amd_dc_opt.exe" (this is an optional step, just to be safe)

If you've done everything correctly, when you launch the game the installation of AMD Dual-Core Optimizer won't start.

REMEMBER TO NOT VERIFY THE INTEGRITY OF GAME FILES, OTHERWISE YOU MUST REPEAT THE PROCEDURE

My Review From 2 Years Ago

Batman Arkham City is an incredibly special game to me. This may sound a little corny, but it changed my life. Massively. If I didn’t play this game way back in March 2017, I wouldn’t have become the massive Batman fan that I am today. I may not have watched The Dark Knight Trilogy, and since those were the movies that got me into film and filmmaking, then I may not have started looking at movies the way I do now. This game has a special place in my heart and I just have to say: Thank you, Rocksteady. And this game still holds up on a replay. The graphics are really good, especially for the time, and the sound effects in this game are unforgettable. If you asked me to recreate any sound from this game, I could do it. From the footsteps, to the grappling hook, to the explosive gel, it is all just so memorable and I don’t know why. The combat here is incredibly fun. Building up your combo is incredibly satisfying and there are so many different moves you can use to get through each encounter. Also, the boss fights in here are great and they are all varied and unique, especially Mr. Freeze. Stealth is a blast too, although catwoman’s stealth sections can be a little tricky. The story and writing here are fantastic as well. The characters are all interesting and the story has a ton of twists that I did not expect. Overall, this game is a blast. It never has a dull moment and it has truly changed my life. If you want a game to play, play the Arkham Series. I’m sure you will have a great time with them.

10/10

When I Revisited The Game Last Year:

Since I played Batman Arkham City last year and did a review for it, I didn’t really feel the need to do another one this year, but I do still want to talk more about it. The game itself is still absolutely phenomenal, with a compelling and fantastically written story, incredibly engaging combat and stealth, and a ton of attention to detail. But, even aside from that, I don’t think I would be reviewing movies and games or be as interested in them if it wasn’t for Arkham City. I first played this game in April 2017. Nowadays, I mostly play single-player narrative-driven games, with some exceptions, but before 2017, that definitely wasn’t the case. I mostly played survival games, some online multiplayer shooters, and other similar types of games. Arkham City definitely changed that. I don’t remember many games having a story that really impacted me before this game and after that, I started playing more games like it (firstly the other Arkham games) and now those make up the bulk of the games I play. It goes beyond games as well. While I think I’ve always liked Batman, Arkham City really got me into the character and ever since I played, I’ve been a huge Batman fan and still am today, collecting comics, memorabilia, etc. I’ve gotten to meet some Batman writers at conventions which was really cool too. And since I enjoyed this game so much, I decided to watch The Dark Knight trilogy a few months later since I had never seen them before at the time. And after I watched that trilogy, that’s when I really started to appreciate movies (though it would be a few more years before I started reviewing them) and not just passively watch them. So yeah. Saying Arkham City changed some things in my life is an understatement and I don’t believe I would be the same person without it. While I think Arkham Knight executes some elements better than City (more on this in my coming Arkham Knight review), I have to say that Arkham City is not only my favorite game in the series but my favorite game of all time for having this much of an effect on me. If you haven’t played Arkham City yet, you absolutely should and I hope you enjoy it as much as I do.

Thank you, Rocksteady.

I'm going to review each separate part of the game

I recommend playing the main story and the non-tedious side missions only if you do buy this game. The whole package I don't recommend in general though because the other parts of the game aren't that great. Especially the boring-as-hell challenges.

Main Story

I hate the combat in these games with a passion. Mainly because your character's movements are mostly arbitrary and you have no idea what exactly they will do other than "attack" or "counter". You don't know which direction they will counter in, which enemy they will target next, you have little agency in movement during combat. Battles last forever. It feels like crap. It's easy too, but when you "lose" ever it's because of the above issues, not because you made some sort of mistake. After all, all you have to do is press A to attack and Y occasionally when you need to counter. Whether the game allows those attacks to connect with an optimal enemy or one with 50 other enemies around them is up to the game though. You have other techniques you can do, but no real way of indicating which enemy to do any of them on for sure, so it feels like you just hope the game does it on the right enemy for all your attacks and actions. Enemy about to shoot you? Sorry you targeted a different enemy and got shot and died. You couldn't do anything about it - it's just the game's decision. WHY CAN'T I HIT MULTIPLE ENEMIES AT ONCE WITH SWEEPING KICKS OR SOMETHING IF THEY SURROUND ME? You have no agency in combat other than punch one guy, counter the guy who ran up behind you - maybe use a gadget and hope it targets the right enemy. Dealing with multiple enemies at once is out of the question outside of some special attacks you can occasionally use that stun them, you can never kill multiple enemies in one go, that'd be a fun and quicker. You have to suffer through punching each enemy one-by-one to kill them. Or spend 200 years creeping up on each enemy like it's dishonored (much better game) if the room layout lets you.

The graphics are great. The story is quite interesting, and the exploration of the city and light puzzle solving elements are fun. This game isn't all that long so the reliance on "bat-vision" isn't too annoying. I actively just avoid combat since it's such a drag. At least the game gives you options to take out opponents without having to start another brainless boring brawl session. Great voice acting and the appearance of each superhero/supervillain look fairly accurate to their original designs. I appreciate that aspect. I'm not much of a superhero fan but it was interesting seeing all these supervillains in the game.

There are simply too many riddler collectibles. I got all of them, but it gets to be a drag after a while. Rather than pepper the world with things that give you a tiny amount of EXP that look exactly the same, pepper the world with actual interesting experiences and encounters. Focus on side missions with actual interactions with characters, and if you need collectibles, have a smaller amount that give you something particularly useful like a new optional gadget or skill or something.

Challenge pack DLC / Riddler's Revenge

Absolutely abysmal DLC / extra content that is just "fight some enemies" times one million. The combat in these games is the most boring part. The exploration is more interesting and the light puzzle solving as well. No I don't care about getting a combo of two million (mashing A and Y and maybe B for fun) for three hours to get a medal and an achievement. F*** off with this garbage. I'm glad this fad of "attack and wait to counter and no enemy lock-on" went out of style eventually. Arkham Asylum, Shadow of Mordor, and this game are the ones with that combat style I've played and I'm already completely sick of it. There's a reason the achievement rates for this part of the game are the lowest out of the whole package. It's not fun and takes forever.

Harley Quinn's revenge

It's a small DLC that focuses on story and combat. It's essentially another mission that adds on to the main story, and is pretty good just like the rest of the main game but honestly if I bought this dlc separately I would feel like it isn't worth whatever you could charge because it's such a small thing and is almost completely reuse of assets in the steel mill area of the main game's map. Nothing much to it, and almost entirely just fighting trash normal enemies too.

Overall this whole Arkham City game would have been recommendable if it wasn't padded with so many awful combat sessions. If you play the game just for the story it's more fun than trying to do the soul-sucking challenges. So I'd recommend if you just play the story, but don't recommend the other parts.

A wholly fun, but flawed game. It seems like they're immune from criticisms, but there;s plenty of room for them.

The city looks great, but feels dead. There's only a small group of NPCs that aren't violent.

The combat is a lot of fun, with a lot of variety. You can get some awesome beat downs going. It flows great, and is a lot of fun...until it doesn't. The camera spins you around, and Batman punches at air instead of jumping at the enemy. The game also has problems with the many uses of Y. Sometimes it continues to stay on Smoke Bomb instead of Ground Takedown. Sometimes instead of Interrogate it only gives Silent Takedown.

Detective mode turns itself on a lot during combat. It's not my controller, as it never happened when I played Asylum right before this. I've also tested it with multiple controllers.

The riddles are great, and challenging. The AR training is fun, until you get to that one that almost makes me need a new controller.

They added a compass, which was great. Unfortunately, it doesn't work inside a building, or underground. I see we used satellite radio technology there.

The camera spinning at times also caused me to grapple onto things I wasn't aiming at when I hit RB. When you get launching around town with the upgrade...it's awesome though. You can really move around the city quickly.

The Catwoman DLC is great. Her third mission was one of the most fun in the game. I like the minigame of climbing walls with her...except that the game starts after you hit the wall, not when you hit it, which would make more sense. It's very noticeably breaking the rhythm. Also, inverted takedowns make you not return to the ceiling for some reason. The Harley Quinn DLC is rather weak since they lock out all the menu functions from the map button. If you forget a combo, you have to go to google to remember. This is absolutely stupid.

The bosses to interrogate are a great upgrade from just finding the maps in Asylum.

I could go on, but overall it's a blast. It's well worth playing. I'm not even a Batman fan. These were recommended after my run through the Assassin's Creed series. I got the three games for $15.
Big improvement over Arkham Asylum with an actual open world map but still frustrating with endless wave of enemies to fight
this game puts most current games to shame in so many ways

One of my favorite Batman games from the Arkham Collection! Great story progression & beat-em up mechanic's. I do wish there was a better full controller support bc some counters/dodges/(Y) are unusable even with the proper controller mapping. 10/10

This is a difficult thumbs up tbh, but in the end I cannot blame WB for MSoft issues. If you own a Ryzen processor and are using Windows 11, good luck getting this game to run at all. Nothing works, no amount of fiddling will prevent the game from crashing anywhere from seconds after loading in, to several minutes of Batmanning it out. Very frustrating... I decided (considering that I was already unhappy with the W11 experience in general) to do a fresh install of W10. And...

The game runs beautifully. The best game of the series I think, and I enjoy them all with some caveats. Be prepared to visit PCGamingwiki on this one folks, but I think it is worth it.

This game is an ideal sequel to a really good game. Its sharpened mechanics, more enemies types, more encounters (Azrael!!!) that actually will pay off in later games and is exiting.
The only weak part of the game - as it was in the asylum - its boss fights. There are no intimidating enemies and final encounter with Bane ends...in a quick disappointment manner.
Open world is not really big - but it rather plus, than disadvantage, because it rich on encounters, points of interest and various locations (at least until you complete the game, then openworld feels a bit empty, but beating a shit out of thugs is still fun).
The amount of gadgets Batman has is even bigger and ability to use much more of them without losing combo makes fights spectacular.
There are only 2 things that a really bothered me - THE FREAKING TON of Riddler trofies and Catwoman 
 predator challenges. (yes, this game has a dlc-campaign for Robin, that continues the main story, ability to switch to the Catwoman in openworld (but her missions are most grinding-type), and all 3 of them + Nightwing for challenges.
Getting all achievements requires grinding through, so i would recommend just enjoy the main story, Robin campaign and trying some challenges (imagine  other heroes as difficult modificators Batman -> Nightwing -> Robin -> Catwoman).
Must buy if you are into DC and 3rd person actions

An absolute gem of a game. Everything about it - the story, the gameplay, background score - is absolutely brilliant. This game actually makes you feel like Batman, and that's so awesome for a game. A bit of an unpopular opinion maybe, but I felt that the ending was perfect and I'd go as far as to say that the ending cutscene and the credits roll was the best part of this game's experience for me. It is certainly one of those games that everyone MUST play at least once.

Arkham City is a great follow-up to Arkham Asylum. While I prefer Asylum's tighter plot and setting, City delivers a larger, more cinematic experience. The combat flows better, the world is larger, and the amount of subplots take the game from a Metroidvania to an open-world game. And what's more important is that City allows Rocksteady to go ham on the story. Whilst Asylum felt like a insulated story taking place within the Batman mythos, City allowed Rocksteady to claim ownership over the story they penned. It allowed them to give a story that was gripping and original from start to finish. Sadly this game was followed up by what I thought was a disappointing Arkham Knight, but YMMV. Great game. Recommended.

Arkham City is an amazing game that is worth trying out and has plenty of content for those who want more.

[h1]YoU kNow… BaT-mAn… We LiVe in A SociEty! …. And I'm tired of pretending that I like the contemporary gaming[/h1]
Don’t get me wrong, Batman. I like this game. Simply to say – ‘The first game with improvements.’ I did’t have problems running it on Manjaro (It’s an Arch distro, btw). The game-play loop is good. The story – dramatic! Classic DC Animated Universe. Paul Dini - good writing. 
The fighting mechanic is ..terrible..  one button mash. Probably to be easy for the children. After all they are nagging on the parents for presents.
Speaking of nagging -  “it is hardly a surprise…”  nyu-nyu .. whatever – The nagging cut scenes after dying can be funny – If was made in a game with proper controls. But, wet again Dark Souls have the more simple “YOU DIED” sentence.   
And the stealth system, Batman? Oh, boy! The stealth system. Who made it? It was someone extremely sneaky.. .. I know! Cobblepot!
So, we have a “Stealth is optional” type of action game. And the both main gameplay systems are unresponsive counter-intuitive trash. Thanks I hate it.
And still, I consider this to be the best game in the series. It is easy 80% subjective rating, from me. The rest of the game series just “jumped the shark”, after this.
But something still, bothers me. Makes me uneasy. No, it’s not just the fighting mechanic.
Something that I feel in other games, too. And I finally got it! I hate this current trend of artificially inflating the value of a game by adding “social network” memorabilia - achievement, collectable cards and clunky services connected to the games. Achievements does not add an additional game value. This just adds irritation that most of the time is perceived unconsciously, by the player. [b]Yea, I’ve learned ThIs woRds from Hugo Strange…[/b] This incentivise the gamer to play a game just to get the “social credit” that deserves. Even if the player don’t like the game. Because ‘You’re not a good gamer, if you don’t achieve 100% completion’.
That’s why gamers always complain for something and they don’t know why. Not just about the Easy Difficulty in "Sekiro" or the other Souls games. Films, too. Star Wars; Lord of the Rings; etc.
[b]Pride and Accomplishment in action! Ladies and Gentlemen. Pride and Accomplishment![/b]
I don’t want to be fed with artificial ingredients, any more. So I’ve decided to return the favour. 
[b]This are my review rules – The game starts with 100 points. And for all the artificial social bloat that I don’t like I will subtract points – “maluses”. And my final review score will be calculated by my subjective Content Quality percentage applied on the points that are left. Fractions are rounded down. If the game reaches 0 or below by only subtracting artificial ingredients – I will not recommend the game, by default. But still I will give you a score by removing this percentage from the negative score. Because I’m generous.
[i]Here we go…[/b]
-10 - The game is OS restricted (-10) : No Linux Support
-15 – DRM exist (-10) and (-1) for every DRM : Steam(-1); Games for Windows(-1); SecuROM (-1)
	Mac App Store(-1); Origin(-1)
-14 –  Platform Game Launcher exists (-10) and (-1) for every launcher: Steam(-1); Games for Windows/XboxLive(-1); Mac App Store(-1); Origin(-1); SonyPS(-1); Nintendo(-1)
-11 – 3rd party EULA’s (-10) an (-1) for each EULA: ‘Batman: Arkham City GOTY EULA’
-12 – The game has different editions/bundles (-10) and (-1) for every edition/bundles: stand alone (-1) and 1 bundle (-1)
-11 – Crappy port(-10): Nintendo WiiU - “Batman: Arkham City Armored Edition”(-1)

….Switzerland, Austria, Czechoslovakia, Italy, Turkey, And Greece/
Poland, Romania, Scotland, Albania, Ireland, Russia, Oman…

-17 – Steam Achievements (-10) and (-1) for every 10 achievements: 64 achievements (-7)
-28 – Steam Trading Cards (-10) and (-1) for every 5 cards: 7 normal cards (-2) and 7 foiled cards (-2) and two types of badges normal and a foiled one (-2) and a card buster drop (-1) ; Emoticons (-5) and Profile Backgrounds (-6) from card crafting
-36 – Market Items exists(-10) and (-1) for every tradable item: normal (-7) and foiled (-7) cards; buster card packets (-1); Emoticons (-5); Profile Backgrounds (-6)
-18 – Points Shop Items Available (-10) and (-1) for every item available: 8 items (-8)
-11 – “Socialised Technical Support” (-10) and (-1) for each annoying tech-serves : (Steam) Cloud Saves –  I can’t delete the cloud saves easily;[/i]
-183 Total (at least)
So, the score is: 100-183= -83. I will remove my subjective 80% from the negative score. It’s -66.4 and rounded downward. Sorry Batman. There are more toxicity in this game than in a chemical vat. Final Review Score (-67/100). I told you I’m generous.

I'll try to play favorites here since this is my favorite game of all time.
 
But genuinely this is (probably) the best hero video game ever made, (yes even more than Spider-Man PS4), The music is Phenomenal, most of the sidequest are great, The boss battles in this game are some of the best (minus 1, and 1 that should have been one, don't wanna spoil but if you know you know) plus the Mr. Freeze Fight is still one of the best Bosses in the series if not THE best and is one of the best stories from a game, HONESTLY if you love a good Batman story filled with twist and turns, Plenty of Easter Eggs that reference stuff from the comics plus actually lore in the Arkhamverse, fantastic villains and incredible voice acting (RIP Kevin Conroy) than this is the game. 

I will say to a handful downsides that the game does have is that the combat is rough, not as bad as Arkham Asylum but not as great as Arkham Knight, it's right in the middle tbh. Also if you are a fan of the free roam music in this game do not get too attached it leaves mid-way towards the end of the game (weird glitch that Rocksteady still hasn't fixed). Also those two bossfights I mentioned earlier, just kind of a letdown tbh.

Having played all of the arkham games (minus asylum,yes I played origins). This game is by far the best superhero game. Having started with Knight and worked my way backwards, I really much prefer the less overtuned combat in city. The first time i played this game I was blown away by the amount of detail in the city. Combat is very solid, Open world is amazing and story i@ by far the best stories in all of the games (origins is number one). Batman skins are amazing, the catwoman dlc is annoying if you wanna stay immersed in the story, and just like every arkham game I wish you could roam around with all the characters in free roam ( like every arkham game)

By far if you want bang for your buck this would be a must purchase for any superhero fan and made me realize why the dark knight is my favourite superhero 


Also it runs on steam deck on very high and a solid 60 (I use proton)

The world feels so full and it isn't like now days open worlds, with repeating quests to do that don't really have any significance at all to what is going on around you. The main story is great but obviously hard to follow if you haven't played Arkham Asylum. (which how could you not?!)
The side quests are stories of there own and flesh out more detail into the villains you are up against. And defeating them sure does feel satisfying. 
The combat and stealth challenges are actually challenging and only get annoying if you don't pay attention to your surroundings.
You get to play as Cat woman! (and also Robin and Nightwing in the challenges)  

My only downside with the game was that it does not run as well as it probably should getting crazy stutters and even sometimes crashes when gliding through the city but it would settle itself rather quickly or crash on texture loading.

But still... 9/10 Would gladly listen to Kevin Conroy again!

I remember playing the game of the year version on my Mom's Xbox when I was little, and now that I've finished it on Steam I'll say that it's still just as fun as it was back then. The Combat has been heavily improved from Arkham Asylum, the open world hub area is bigger now, side quest have now been added each having upgrades and XP to reward Batman or Catwoman upon completion, oh yeah for got to say this game adds 3 new playable characters besides batman each with unique playstyles. You have Catwoman being weaker than batman in health and really lacks in gadget but her speed in combat and traversing the city makes her a joy to play, Robin being almost a mirror of batman but with the use of his extendable Bo Staff he can deal with many enemies and counter gun based enemies with his shield. Nightwing being a challenge mode exclusive character he pretty balanced for combat and stealth encounters having a mix of speed and AOE gadgets and abilities. 
I don't really like to spoil story elements so if you could buy this game and give a play to experience the best Batman story ever.

I'd recommend this game to anyone remotely interested in Batman.

Batman Arkham City is not only a great sequel to Batman Arkham Asylum, it is also a generally great story surrounding the caped crusader himself. It is daring, fun and introduces villains that more causal Batmanfans might not know about (or very little)

I do must say that I personally prefer the original Arkham Asylum over City. It may be stiffer in terms of gameplay, but the overall atmosphere, world and art-direction capture me more than those in City (whom are still great btw!)

It is definitely more packed with content than AA (just look at the 200 more added "Riddles") and is now a more true open-world with side-quests and all. 

Easily beatable under 10 hours if you just go for the main story plus a few sidequests. But if you go for NG+, Riddler, all the sidequests and DLCs, you might see yourself play this for up to 30 hours easily.

For many the fan-favorite of the series and I cant blame them. For me however just a great follow-up to an even greater Entry to the Arkham Series.

Batman Arkham City is a fantastic sequel and almost better in every way possible from its predecessor. If you haven't played or bought the first game Arkham Asylum you should check that first.
It has a much better story that hooks you instantly, great boss fights, equipment variety, challenges and many more.
Combat is still the same which is a turn off for some people so bear that in mind.

Otherwise, it is an incredible game everyone has to play even non batman fans.

I want to start this off with I do recommend this game. It is a good game, there's a lot going on and a lot to do- 10 hours in and I feel like I've only really scratched the surface. That being said, for every good thing about it, there seems to be something that sours it a little.
I never played this game before this year, so let me tell you as someone with no nostalgia: It's beautiful. There's a lot of obvious love here in every location and how seamless and easy it is to get lost in and explore.
On the note of exploration: The controls are too sensitive sometimes. I cannot tell you how many times I got stuck trying to glide off a railing but I climb up instead.
Coming off of Asylum, I was not looking forward to combat in this game. But it's actually much easier to get combos and there are a lot of other fun, creative ways to take down opponents.
It's just too bad that, unlike Asylum, this game is pretty dead set on forcing you into arena battles with a large number of enemies you have to take on all at once. Doesn't feel very Batman to me, but I guess it is fun every now and again.
Oh- but that thing about combos being easier to get? That's not because the combat is better. In fact, it's probably just because combat is *too* responsive. This means you'll often end up knocking out that Riddler informant you've been dancing around trying to keep up for this fight that could have been over forever ago, and hitting that dodge too fast on a knife-wielding enemy will land you a punishing 3x hit that you... just sort of have to deal with. That's not even getting into some of the combat inconsistencies. For some reason, Batman will auto-turn to fire a batarang at the enemy the camera is pointed at, but he won't do the same when quick shooting the charge gun- he'll just shoot it blindly off screen if you happened to already have him turned away. 
Oh, but about the Riddler informants and comparisons to Asylum- I really like how this game handles the Riddler! The Riddles and quests are challenging and take me a minute to puzzle out instead of just going "Oh, 'bird-' I'm looking for the Penguin poster" or whatever. Though this game does have some riddles like that, it's so wide and expansive that the search for them truly feels like exploration and not just squinting into random corners of an office trying to find Cluemaster's shoelace or whatever. You even get to answer actual non-Batman related riddles, which I feel was sorely missing from the first game and I did whine a bit about to some friends. The best part of the riddles in this game over Asylum- hands down- is definitely the informants. Huge step up from just finding a single map with all of the locations you'll probably only get to after getting through %80 of them anyway if you're looking for them on your first play through like I was. The informants add more agency to that, and the location of the clues don't always match up to where you have to go to activate them. This is great for puzzles like the "perspective" riddles, where finding where you need to go to activate them.... is the whole point of the puzzle. Give you anything more, and it's just handed to you.
HOWEVER- there is no longer a "teeth" counter. (Teeth have been replaced with balloons, penguins, and... more teeth- but I'll be using teeth for simplicity.) The teeth counter made keeping track of how many you needed super simple and teeth were usually found in clumps of three, which made them less like mindless collectibles (that's what the riddles were for...) and more like a marker of explorable areas. Have 11 teeth? Sounds like you missed a corner of that room you were in- should be divisible by 3, bud. Have 12 teeth but need 15? A whole other area of the building is probably still locked off- don't stress out and keep on with the story. I can see why this may not be a feeling you want or even see as feasible to evoke in such an open world, and to that I say: dump the group of three, but keep the counter.
But hey- this game is way too old for anything I say now to impact it or how it was made... It's also way too fun for any of this to really... matter?
It's a great game! Lives up to the hype. I'm actually sorry I never played this back when it just came out and my brother was telling me to give it a shot, but I'm happy to catch the train this time around. I know most people looking to buy this kind of game don't even read the comments- but if you're down here looking to get the game for yourself or a fellow Batman lover: It's more than worth it! Any time I've gotten shot because I jumped over a gap I was trying to glide between or fallen into water or felt like a boss fight was kind of cheap has been immediately swept away by the thrill of the next piece of the action.

I have synesthesia syndrome. In this syndrome, it is difficult to react to things around me.
I am a fan of Batman.I watched all the Batman movies since I was a kid.But not the games.I could not play because of my problem.
One day, one of my friends, who realized that I love Batman, gave me this game as a gift.
The game was difficult for me in the first few minutes.But I wanted to continue.My problem in the game was that I could not react to enemy attacks.
At that time I had two choices, to continue or not.I wanted to finish the game because Batman was one of the most popular characters in my life.My decision was to continue.I tried to make a connection between what I see and my fingers.And this became the most important goal of my life in six months.
Until today, I played the game several times on hard mode.And I could even play other games.It even made me react better in real life.So I can definitely say that Batman is my hero.

Batman: Arkham City Game of the Year Edition is a masterpiece of action and adventure gaming that delivers an immersive and thrilling experience for fans of the Dark Knight. Developed by Rocksteady Studios, the game boasts incredible graphics, a compelling storyline, and fantastic gameplay mechanics that make it stand out from other superhero games. The game takes place in a massive open-world environment that allows you to explore and experience Gotham City like never before.

The game's combat system is one of its standout features, with fluid and satisfying melee combat that's both accessible and challenging. The game also features a variety of gadgets and abilities that allow you to approach combat in different ways, adding depth and strategy to the gameplay. The game's stealth mechanics are also impressive, allowing you to take down enemies from the shadows and feel like a true superhero.

The story of Batman: Arkham City is also well-crafted, with a host of memorable villains and supporting characters that add to the overall immersion of the game. The game's voice acting is top-notch, with talented actors bringing the game's characters to life and delivering dialogue that's both witty and engaging.

Overall, Batman: Arkham City Game of the Year Edition is a must-play game for fans of Batman and action-adventure games. With its incredible combat system, compelling storyline, and immersive open-world environment, it's a game that's sure to keep you entertained for hours on end.

TL;DR: Batman: Arkham City Game of the Year Edition is an action-packed adventure game that offers a thrilling and immersive experience for fans of the Dark Knight. With its fluid combat system, engaging storyline, and impressive open-world environment, it's a game that's sure to keep you hooked from start to finish.

Batman Arkham City takes Batman Arkham Asylym and improves on everything. The game is quite similar to Arkham Asylym so if you've played that this will be an easy game to learn(not that there is learning curve). Basically you just beat the crap out of criminals and solve a couple of puzzles every now and then.

The game takes place a couple of years after the events of Arkham Asylym. You are captured by Doctor Strange who knows that Bruce Wayne is batman. He sends you to his prison that he build in the middle of Gotham called Arkham city. You have to escape from Arkham city and stop Stranges plans to take over Gotham.

If you're going to play this game I recommend using a controller also TURN OF DIRECTX 11 FEATURES and PHYSX. They will crash the game every 5 minutes. If you disable them you shouldn't have any problems. Overall Batman Arkham City is  an awesome game and is definitely in the top 10 beat 'em games  of all time.

Firstly, the game has a fantastic storyline that keeps you engaged from start to finish. The game is set in a massive open-world environment, which allows you to explore the city of Gotham and experience immersive gameplay.

The game mechanics are exceptional, with seamless combat and stealth mechanics that make you feel like you are the Dark Knight. The game also features an extensive range of gadgets and upgrades that can be unlocked as you progress through the story, making for a satisfying progression system.

The graphics and visuals are top-notch, with detailed character models, stunning environments, and a dark, moody atmosphere that perfectly captures the essence of Gotham City. The voice acting is also excellent, with legendary voice actors such as Mark Hamill (the Joker) and Kevin Conroy (Batman) reprising their iconic roles.

Overall, Batman: Arkham City is a must-play game for any fan of the Batman franchise or anyone looking for an amazing action-adventure game. It's a thrilling experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end. Highly recommended!

The second adaptation of the Batman Arkham games, and well its a really great game. Originally released in 2011, still holds up in 2023. But the story felt a bit short and fast. By the time i was getting fully invested with the story, i was 3/4's of the way through the story. There are a few spots in the game that can be headache inducing, but once/if you know how to flow in combat, its easy. The only thing that makes this a longer game is the side quests. Here are some reasons to play Batman: Arkham City:

Be the Batman - Let's be real, who wouldn't want to be the Dark Knight? In Arkham City, you get to live out your wildest superhero dreams and take on some of the most iconic villains in the Batman universe.

The Voice Acting - Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamill as the Joker? Enough said. The voice acting in this game is top-notch and adds an extra layer of immersion to the already engaging story.

The Combat System - The combat system in Arkham City is smooth, intuitive, and downright satisfying. You can take on multiple enemies at once and chain together combos for some truly epic takedowns.

The Gadgets - Batman has a seemingly endless supply of gadgets at his disposal, and using them to take down enemies and solve puzzles is just plain fun.

The Open World - Arkham City is an open-world game, and it's a blast to explore. There are tons of hidden secrets, easter eggs, and side missions to discover, making it a game you can sink hours into.

The Story - The story in Arkham City is compelling and well-written, featuring twists and turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Plus, the game's portrayal of the Batman-Joker dynamic is nothing short of iconic.

The Atmosphere - The dark, gritty atmosphere of Arkham City is perfect for a Batman game. It feels like you're really in Gotham City, and the game's attention to detail is impressive.

The Rogues Gallery - Arkham City features a wide variety of Batman's most notorious villains, including the Joker, Two-Face, the Penguin, and more. Taking them down one by one is immensely satisfying.

The Challenges - If you're looking for a challenge, Arkham City has plenty of it. From the game's notorious combat challenges to the Riddler's fiendish puzzles, there's always something to test your skills.

The Batcave - Who doesn't want to explore the Batcave? In Arkham City, you get to do just that, and it's a blast. Plus, it's a great place to upgrade your gadgets and prepare for your next mission.

Many great additions over the last game over the entire board. The combat feels great and it feels like you're a badass even though you're left clicking 90% of the time and right clicking when you see a blue warning icon pop up. Story was good but there is an urgency to it which makes pursuing side missions even harder as you have to snap yourself out of the main story loop to help catch some other villain.

 The collectibles/achievements are just there to lengthen the game for people that enjoy wasting time and provide little to no actual value to your playthrough. Other than that, it's a pretty solid game that will give you about 10 hours of fun, it's short but it rarely feels that way in the stealth sections where you have to take one guy out, AFK for 10 minutes while the other guards come together and then split up again, rinse and repeat. The worst offender is batman sometimes blocking instead of doing a stealth takedown that alerts enemies that made my blood boil around the 6 hour mark and it just soured the complete experience until the end sequence.

 This game -as I've said- improves over its predecessor (Arkham Asylum) but falls short in other places considerably which balances it out at the end for an OK game.

Batman Arkham City is the sequel to the critically acclaimed Batman Arkham Asylum. Set in old Gotham, now known as Arkham City, the run down abandoned section has been walled off for inmates from Black Gate and Arkham Asylum. The "prison city" is overseen by the mysterious Doctor Hugo Strange who's intentions are not made well known immediately. Batman sets out to investigate and stop Hugo from initiating what he refers to as "protocol ten" while simultaneously dealing with a handful of his most well known adversaries that are in the midst of a gang war. Batman Arkham City is an upgrade in every way to its predecessor, the combat is more fluent and landing larger combo's has never been easier with all sorts of useful tools to unlock and upgrade. The map is just the right size and very fun to run roof top to roof top getting in brawls. The graphics are very good for 2012 and have a nice gloomy feel as a batman game should, please if you have not played this yet, give it a go now!

As someone who's seen and played so many superhero and batman things trust me when I tell you that this game is a work of art for DC. The characters are some of the best versions of DC characters, the combat is great and fluid, though it isn't perfect and glitches happen, and the story is one of the best Batman stories ever. The only real problems I have it that some of the post game content will have you looking up guides and The Riddler Trophies. To complete his side quest you have to find over 450 trophies scattered across the map and even my love for batman cannot convince me to do that.The positives heavily outweigh the negatives though and makes it the best game out of the best game franchise.

“I am vengeance, I am the night, I am Batman!”
Rest in peace, Kevin Conroy.

Another embarrassment but less embarrassing than Asylum.

The graphics are amazing, I find the environment very fascinating, there's tons of detail, and you can explore every part of it. 
The story seemed okay but I stopped after 6 hours as you can see, because of gameplay reasons.

The gameplay is a shitshow. Gliding feels clunky, because it's mouse controlled. Combat and Stealth is greatly improved but still not perfect. Blade dodges don't seem to work, interesting to see a bug still in the game after 10 years of it being out. Every action seems more responsive now that I think about it. But it falls behind in other areas. Whilst I'm grateful there's no more Scarecrow, well, yet. I am frustrated by the fact that some boss fights and side missions are so poorly designed. Like they are tedious and hide information from you constantly. I got stuck on Penguin thinking there was some strategy to take him out, like I can run up to him through brute force and punch him. Nope. You have to find a gun to disable his gun, then run up to him, then take him out. ????????????? This is dumb. Missed opportunity too, to do something revolutionary. 
The open world exploration is okay, but again has this "Keeps information from you" stuff. I get confused why I can't collect some riddler trophies. 
So after having quite a few deaths in the game for different reasons, I realized some big flaws. Before Penguin, there's this ice bridge section, and holy shit this was not tested at all. This section is buggy and quirky, which don't mix. It's so dumb. And given that it's a one shot kill if you fall into the water, it's really bad game design. 
Even worse than this, I got to the section where you have to scan robots to get to Ra Ghul? or something? I did that last night, and found out how they got through the door. I leave the game there, and quit. Come back this morning, game didn't save. Apparently I have to do all that again. This is a flaw with a checkpoint save only system. This is just shit. Terrible. On top of the game being widely inaccessible too, lacking settings that could help players who can't necessarily play as well as others (I have timing issues and meltdowns), it was clear that this isn't a good quality game. 

As usual though, I approach these types of games with an open mind, but I just can't see this being any good. I've played games for over 18 years, so I understand what makes them good and what quality of life features they need, as well as accessibility. The Batman series lacks everything. It's a waste of talent. I'm not looking forward to trying Arkham Knight which is next for me to play.

While some still think Arkham Asylum was amazing, and it was, Arkham City absolutely took elements from the previous game that worked well and built on them. Arkham City's fights and predator mechanics really start to come into their own, with challenge modes that are still a blast to take on. As with all the good batman games, you get to feel like and operate like the dark knight, utilizing a variety of gadgets and techniques to utterly terrify and brutalize everyone. The story picks up from Arkham Asylum as you might expect, and comes to what I think was a satisfying conclusion though kinda bitter but nevertheless expected. Definitely a recommend.

[strike]What if we took everything that was good about Arkham Asylum and made it not good instead?[/strike]

Ok to be more fair, this game is probably fine on its own merits, but I think it's totally lousy as an Arkham Asylum follow-up. The unique, semi-open claustrophobia that I found cozy, fun, and novel in Asylum is replaced by the trendier "huge open world of openness" shtick that is fine and all but totally not in the spirit of the first game and not really for me.

My "Not Recommended" is for anyone who liked Arkham Asylum's level design, structure, and to some degree its tone. Those are gone.

+ writing for plot was good
+ Characters had some substance
+ Graphics are decent for age

- Gliding, particularly where it is required for objectives (AR training, Ra's Al Ghul main quest). Game brought down some by bad platforming mechanics. It can be useful to watch a youtube walk through on when to dive/end dive rather than try to follow path indicated in game.
- I could really do with less button mashing in combat. Some cases let you take out NPCs quick, but there a lot requiring repeated strikes, and a lot of mobs. Harley Quin's Revenge is real bad with this,

Similar to Arkham Asylum in terms of gameplay, but this time the world is much more open & the game is much bigger. There's a lot more to explore, a lot more to do, including a ton of awesome missions & honestly a few too many Riddler Trophies, but I can totally overlook that because at the end of the day this game is a masterpiece and I'm having a BLAST!

You know that thing where in the last game you probably spent 99% of your time running around Arkham Island with Detective Mode ON at almost all times to pick up secrets and solve puzzles? Remember how that made the textures look worse, it made everyone look like skeletons & it put a blue filter around everything? Arkham City gives you incentive to turn OFF Detective Mode a little in a fistfull of situations. For example, when you're gliding around the city, you'll probably turn Detective Mode off because then you'll be able to see the guide arrow pointing you to your destination. This gives you much more incentive to look around and enjoy the sights of Arkham City & appreciate the love poured into the fine details in the graphics & Easter eggs.

Kevin Conroy & Mark Hamill reprise their roles as Batman & The Joker, and they play off of each other as brilliantly as they always do. The story is fantastic, but in truth I do have one concern about it: Apparently, a large section of Gotham has been closed off and a bunch of criminals have been left to their own devices with no government to watch over them or hold them accountable for their actions. I'm sorry - who exactly thought that would be a good idea? The fact that these criminals wouldn't be able to organize their own Fire Dept within Arkham City alone would make this a blatantly terrible idea if executed in real life. I would absolutely go so far as to say the whole premise feels very contrived. Still, Arkham City is a very fun playground for Batman, the city feels as dangerous as it should, and contrivances aside, the story is otherwise fantastic. If you can get past the premise, you'll have a non-stop blast from beginning to end!

Overall a fantastic sequel to Arkham Asylum. It takes the same gameplay and applies it to a new story set in a more open setting. Arkham City is a gated-off part of Gotham that was made into a maximum security prison (basically like Manhattan in Escape from New York). The world isn't very big but it basically functions as an open world with side quests and collectibles while the main quest sends Batman around the map to explore the interior "dungeons".
This is the main difference in design compared to Asylum, which was more of a metriodvania where the exteriors functioned as a hub. Sure the hub had some collectibles, secrets and fights, but you spent the absolute majority of the time in the different interior levels. In Arkham City, you spend the majority in the open world (at least if you do the side quests).
When it comes to combat it's basically an improved version of the one in Asylum, which is great. The only thing that annoyed me was not being able to cancel takeout animations if someone is attacking me. It's like Batman has the reflexes of a bat except when he's in the middle of finishing someone off. Then he needs 5 seconds where he can't interrupt what he's doing. Otherwise, the combat is extremely fluid and responsive.
I also love the fact that the stealth gameplay isn't slow. It feels just as great as in Asylum to quickly jump down, take someone out and then disappear leaving the rest scared. But I think Asylums level design was better at encouraging stealth while City favored brawls a bit more. The open world also doesn't feel designed with stealth in mind but this is also somewhat true for the dungeons. Compared to Asylum, City's dungeons are more focused on complex ways of traversal with gadgets and then rooms with brawls, than the methodical hunting Batman does in Asylum. The mechanics are there though, this is just my experience of the level design.
My big gripe with the game is that the story isn't written in a way to encourage exploration since Batman is always on a literal timer in the story (not mechanically but narratively). As I was playing the main quest I found no motivation to stop and do silly riddles while Batman/Gotham was on the verge of death/collapse, it just didn't make any sense to me. So I finished the main quest and put the game down but after a week I felt the need to return and do the side quests. It was nice that the game allowed me to return after the credits and story wise I still think it makes sense for Batman to tie up the loose ends.
The side quests themselves were fine. Some endings hinted towards a sequel (Mysterious Watcher and Identity Thief) so it'll be interesting to see if they are resolved in Arkham Knight.

This is a really good game. I liked it so much I think it actually made me like the previous one less. This game takes everything that was good in Arkham Asylum and improves it so much. The movement is smoother. The fighting is better. The environment is bigger. The Riddler challenges are more varied and harder. 

This is THE Batman game. You don't need to be reading this review to know that - you already know that. I could rehash things people have already said but it really is as good as they say it is. I was itching to get home from work and continue playing this game. It looks great, the voice acting is great, the story is great, it just feels so complete. 

Pros:
Looks beautiful. Arkham City is gorgeous. The lighting is so atmospheric and it is easy to navigate the map due to in-game signage.
Arkham City is big enough to feel real but not so big that it's oppressive. As someone who is burned out by modern, gigantic open worlds, it is the perfect size.
So many types of challenges! You can do the flying  challenges (NOT RECOMMENDED; they are impossible), save political prisoners, team up with Bane, team up with Dr. Freeze, whatever you want. You can investigate crime scenes, race across the city, interrogate mooks, whatever you want.
YOU FEEL LIKE BATMAN FOR REAL MAN. WHAT ELSE CAN I SAY ABOUT THAT.
Voice acting is immaculate. Mark Hammill as the Joker is unbelievable. He tops himself in the previous game, somehow.
Introduces new characters not in the previous game, like Ra's al-Ghul and Solomon Grundy.

Cons: 
Story is convoluted as hell. I think if I played through it agaian I would "get it" more but there is so much going on at once and so many characters.
The postgame is simultaneously too long and not long enough. Once you burn through fighting the extra villains it's just you and 400 Riddler trophies. This sucks.
Playing as Catwoman is kind of terrible. There, I said it. The climbing is not great. The combat is hard because she's much more fragile than Batman. 
I hate the way every female character in this game has her boobs out and walks like has as stick up her backside.

A classic! My critiques are mostly just nitpicking. This game rules.

Batman returns in this epic sequel to Arkham Asylum. Arkham City turns the dial up to an 11 and it's not just the Joker that you need to worry about; but also Hugo Strange who is the Warden of Arkham City and knows your identity. And for a unique moment or two if your an achievement hunter. You can get to play as Selina Kyle/Catwoman with her own move-sets and challenge missions (Yup those are back and instead of the Joker as a second choice it be Catwoman)

The story, music score, writing cannot be understated or overstated on just how godly good it is. The late Kevin Conroy delivers his line with elegance as if you really are along the ride with Batman in this crazy Arkham City.

The combat has improved since Arkham Asylum while it's still a bit stiff at times; it's much more adaptable and easier to overcome your enemies with your gadgets and move combo sets.

Definitely. DEFINITELY recommend.

Batman: Arkham City is an incredibly fun action-adventure game that takes place in the fictional city of Gotham.

Players take on the role of Batman as he battles his way through several of the enemies in his rogues gallery in order to stop them from taking over Arkham City. 

Like Batman: Arkham Asylum, the game features an open world environment that allows its players to explore and interact with many of its inhabitants as they progress throughout the story; however, this concept has been heavily expanded upon in Batman: Arkham City. For example, the difference between the two games' map sizes is staggering! This is because Batman: Arkham City has given players a much larger area to play in, and with all of this new space comes loads of hidden Easter eggs and collectibles for players to find.

Because of this, I cannot praise the exploration element of this game enough! I mean, there is so much content in this game that it has taken me actual days to get through it all; and I still feel like playing because there are still things that I have yet to experience! It's amazing!

But, with such a big map, you may be concerned that traversal will be a chore. Let me reassure you that this could not be further from the truth. I mean, I could not express to you in words just how much fun I had gliding around the city as Batman! And although the gliding mechanics were changed only slightly, it felt like such a major upgrade from Batman: Arkham Asylum. I really liked the addition of the grapnel boost upgrade (which allows the player to continually glide by using the grapnel gun to boost themselves from an object into a continual glide).

Obviously the graphics in Batman: Arkham City are stunning, with detailed environments and characters that bring Gotham City to life. It is very unlikely that you will not enjoy spending time traversing throughout the city.

The only thing that seemed to miss the mark were the collectibles. Maybe it's just me, but hunting for the Riddler's trophies is just so gosh darn boring. Sure, the first few times you solve his new puzzles it feels exhilarating and fun! But after the three-hundredth trophy you start to realize that things are becoming a bit...repetitive, to say the least. Still, they added a reason to explore the city, and they provided cool rewards like: concept art, character models, and more!

But, if you aren't one for collectibles, don't worry! The game also features a variety of fun side missions that add a lot of depth to the overall experience.

Now let's talk about the game's combat system. Players of Batman: Arkham Asylum probably noticed how similar the free flow combat systems in both games felt, but I think that Batman: Arkham City enhanced the experience just enough that it did not feel like a boring copy and paste from one game to another. Between making the combat feel smoother and the combos more skill dependent the game's combat felt like it had been significantly upgraded from it's previous version. 

Overall, Batman: Arkham City is an excellent action-adventure game that offers plenty of content for fans of the franchise. With its engaging combat system, detailed graphics, and great voice acting, it's easy to see why this game has become so popular over the years. If you're looking for a great superhero experience, then this is definitely one worth checking out!

Every single main game from "Batman: Arkham" series is great on its own and you should give them a chance, even if you don't know or don't care about Batman or DC games or super hero games overall. 
"Batman: Arkham" series is just that good. Each one of those games are similar in term of core mechanics but they have own personal pros and cons making them unique from each other with no way of picking "the best one" out of all of them:



===============================================



☆Batman: Arkham Asylum

Pros:

+spooky and chill atmosphere of crazy asylum

+everything Scarecrow related

+not "too scary" but "ok" amount of collectibles and puzzles (collectibles that give you both experience points, healing, challenge maps and bonus in game content)

+very entertaining "Joker" DLC (only available on other platforms than PC but there is way to mod it in on PC) 

+rest of DLC's challenge maps is alright too

+not many of them but bosses and mini-boss fights are good enough for the first game in the series, I have nothing to complain about here



Cons:

-the smallest and least dense map out of all Arkham games in term of side content

-the weakest combat out of all Arkham games because of slowest animations ever, least amount of combat gadgets and least amount of ways to take down people

-predator sections feels a bit too slow with not enough ways to take down goons after playing other Arkham games 

-zero side activities beside collectibles which are not even that cleverly hidden

-no fun Riddler puzzles that require gadgets to solve

-very small amount of unique challenge maps



===============================================



☆Batman: Arkham City

Pros:

+bigger and more dense map than in Arkham Asylum

+improved roaming, gliding and exploration

+more NPC's to interact with

+way, way better and way more boss fights and mini-boss fights 

+extra fun side missions

+way more good and unique challenge maps and unlockable bonus content

+4 unique playable characters and lots of extra skins

+Catwoman mini story DLC was ok



Cons:

-story and motivations of few characters in this game are the least coherent out of all Arkham games

-side missions "Acts of Violence", "Cold Call Killer", "Identity Theft", "Shot in the Dark", "Watcher in the Wings" are often hard to progress on your own without a guide because the game expects you to just randomly find very specific locations and characters while traveling across the map

-Harley Quinn's Revenge was garbage DLC with no interesting mechanics, ideas, boss fights, story or gimmicks



===============================================



☆Batman: Arkham Origins

Pros:

+not only bigger and better map but also snowy

+both story and overall dialogue is the most entertaining and engaging out of all Arkham games

+new Remote Claw gadget (that replaces Line Launcher) is very fun to use and allows you to do for way more stuff than crappy Line Launcher. Not only more utility in both combat and predator but also in exploration. Screw Line Launcher - Remote Claw all day all night, BABY!

+Electric gloves aka Batman's Devil Trigger are way too fun in use

+even more unique and better boss and mini-boss fights. Hands down the best out of all Arkham games

+fast travel

+better ranking system encouraging you to fight better for more bonus experience points

+enhanced detective mode and lots of special missions using it

+you are not fighting only prisoners for a change but also corrupted cops

+even more unique side missions

+not as many challenge maps as in Arkham City but still a lot

+3 unique playable characters on challenge maps

+multiplayer mode (its kinda dead at this point but overall quality and gameplay of this mode was very good and fun)

+both "Cold, Cold Heart" and "Initiation" DLC's are very, very good



Cons:

-definitely the most glitchy out of all Arkham games, yet nothing game breaking like crashes or anything that would cause Game Over or corrupted saves or progression block

-few examples of bugs: sometimes you will just miss, get hit or lose combo for no reason or due hitboxes nearby walls, sometimes the room or texture may no load correctly (restart fixes that), there that one floor in open world that loads way too long so you can clip thru it and fall down into water but you never need to go there, that goofy "the dark room" in "Cold, Cold Heart"...

-very weird facial animations during character conversations during in game cutscenes, mostly noticeable while talking to Alfred



===============================================



☆Batman: Arkham Knight 

Pros:

+not only bigger and better map but also rainy

+Batmobile gameplay (driving around, puzzles, combat, pursuit, racing sections) is just WAY too fun

+Batmobile may be the most smooth and responsive controlled ground vehicle I had ever used over the past 30 years of my gaming life

+finally Batman can chill out inside a police station

+graphically the best out of all Arkham games with even more animations and extra details

+Arkham Knight was a really flesh out and entertaining character, despite (sadly) not being on screen very often 

+character that appears during [spoiler]hallucinations[/spoiler] later in the game is definitely the most hilarious part of this game (no, I am not talking about [spoiler] Batman or Arkham Knight [/spoiler])

+each previous Arkham game had a very good end game sequence but Arkham Knight end game sequence is just amazing

+huge number of collectibles and stuff to do 

+lots of side quests and side activities, good DLC's

+8 playable characters in challenge maps

+overall the biggest amount of in-game content out of all Arkham games



Cons:

-a proper final boss fight is replaced by a set piece for some reason. Its a good set piece but I would rather have another Joker Titan boss instead.

-detective aspect of Batman Arkham games is basically and completely gone here

-repeating some races and other challenges is really annoying just because you have to spend few extra minutes to go back to previous point. Was that hard to implement quick restart prompt?

-the game is constantly hammering you hints for the simplest in-game puzzles every few seconds like the the target audience of this M rated game and long Arkham franchise fans was 8 year olds BUT funny enough the game doesn't tell you where to find Freeze Blast gadget at all so its easy to miss

-some people may find this game way too big or overwhelming due amount of content, collectibles or batmobile sections (even tho I had no issue with it and Arkham City had had way more filler collectibles so its funny people complain about it in Arkham Knight)

-after fantastic amount of enemies and bosses in Origins.....this game decided for 10 steps back and just not bother with that at freaking all. 
Knight have weaker boss and mini-boss fights than previous City and Origins. 
Don't get me wrong: bosses in Arkham Knight are still good, fun and unique on their own but the game could do a way better job at their variety and number, especially after so many of amazing boss fights of Arkham City and Arkham Origins.
Heck, Batman: Arkham Knight had so many moments when you think you are gonna fight a boss, especially at the end of each side quest, and then...........nothing. 
Big nothing. A cutscene where you punch a villain and its over. Garbage!
On top of that the game screams for at least two more melee combat fights against Arkham Knight in the middle of story just so it can build up the character a bit more. 

-you better have a STRONG PC to run this game at 60 fps and max settings



===============================================



☆Batman: Arkham Origins Blackgate

Pros:

+it may be fun to play with enough booze and friends around



Cons:

-everything about this game

In modern day, practicing doctor and awesome neckbeard specialist builds one big part of town called Arkham City. Using his mad law and doctor skills, he puts every single batman villain in here, including Joker. Every batman villain gathers in a secret convention centre that's hastily disguised as a huge shopping mall. When everyone is seated, Joker appears on stage, walks up to the microphone and shouts: "yo FUCK batman". everyone shouts back "FUCK batman", except Catwoman because Catwoman. In the corner of the convention, one lone janitor replies with: "but I think Batman is pretty cool, not like that I'm friends with him or anything". Every villain starts laughing at him, but when he takes off his dope stache and hat, guess what? It's Batman. 

The reason why I put that plot twist there is to show you how exactly I felt when I played this game for the first time and how you will feel if you play it.

Huge fan of the Batman Arkham games so here is my review for Batman: Arkham City. There may be minor spoilers so beware please.

STORY: Probably the best story in the whole series. It is interesting and keeps your attention. The villains are well written and they are woven into the main story very nicely. The side missions are good ( could have been expanded on). The main story is a bit short so take your time playing, do a bit of the main story and then work on side missions. 

GAMEPLAY: A big improvement from Batman Arkham Asylum. Combat is smooth and flows nicely. It does not have the best combat in the whole series but its very enjoyable. My biggest complaint is it a huge button masher. Thought my controller and hands would fall apart so get ready for that. (could also be how I play so hmmm) I didn't experience any issues like frame rate drops or bugs (RX 3080).

GRAPHICS: Textures wise, looks very good. Sharp and clean. In terms of the character design, some of the thugs are so ugly. Like ugly ugly. Batman looks good but I think the face modeling for a lot of the main characters falls a bit short. It is an older game so keep that in mind while playing.

VERDICT: You will not be disappointed playing this game. The ending hits you hard, like you will have emotions you didn't even know was there. When the credits play, do not skip it. Watch the whole thing.

batman: arkham city is a 2012 action/adventure game developed by rocksteady studios. one thing i originally said about arkham asylum when i completed it earlier this year was that it didn't age as well as it could've, and while arkham city is a direct sequel, it was released only about two years after arkham asylum and it still was able to GREATLY improve on asylum's gameplay and as a result, holds up wayyy better today than asylum does. arkham city as a setting was awesome and a great upgrade over the more linear asylum setting in the first game. the atmosphere is top-notch and there are plenty of landmarks all over the map, which is very highly detailed. just like how the setting is memorable, the characters/villains you deal with are also great. everything here is just a massive upgrade over asylum, even the scarecrow levels from arkham asylum are clearly upgraded in this game, just given to a new villain and with new challenges/gameplay mechanics. the combat is obviously great, even better than it was in asylum. i started my blind playthrough on hard and while it got pretty hard at certain moments (specifically whenever when you fight a ton of enemies of varying types), there also are upgrades you can select that can make combat very easy even on hard difficulty. the mini bosses and boss fights are wayyyyy better than they were in asylum, and the stealth sections are super fun, somehow clearing a room full of armed guards is even more fun than it was in asylum. the catwoman portions, while brief, were still fun as a change of pace and were a great addition. the side content is also upgraded in arkham city, as again, there’s more to do and more variety. there’s cool moments throughout the game. the story is probably a weak point but it’s still pretty good overall, with good characters and tons of detail for even minor characters. overall, this was about as perfect as a sequel can be, it made all the bad stuff in asylum good, while also improving on everything that made asylum great in the first place. this was a very enjoyable completion experience and i am so excited to play arkham knight (and maybe arkham origins).
