On the day of thanksgiving I bought a bundle (that was on sale) that included Arkham Asylum, Arkham City, and Arkham Knight. The final game listed I cannot play because of the limitations of my pc. The first game in the package was a fun time but with a bunch of flaws. Arkham Asylum is a good game just short of great, but Arkham City could be the greatest superhero game of all time. Before diving into the gameplay it is important to talk about the games story. Bruce Wayne is trapped in a new super prison called Arkham City by a mad scientist named Hugo Strange. Hugo has figured out that batman and Bruce are one in the same as uses this information to fuel his plans. But first Batman must take out the Joker. Because Joker turned into a titan back in the asylum he has developed a deadly sickness. He then injects his blood into batman causing Batman to have this sickness. After that it is a mad dash to find the cure and stop Hugo's plan of initiating his plan of 'Protocol 10'. Although this plot sounds very simple it has multiple different threads that tie together.but the story never became convoluted. This allowed the game to have a story with a lot of depth without having to recap what happened every 5 seconds. The story never overtakes game play which is a very good thing in this situation because of how great the game play is. In this game you ARE Batman. You rythmically beat down foes with you fists and some gadgets, you stealthy take down enemies one by one by zipping up to vantage points and silently taking down enemies, and you glide around the city and use your grapnel gun to bring you to a ledge to fling you up into the beautiful Gotham night sky. The game play excells your fun into full gaming bliss. The graphics are also great too! Although I had to turn my settings down almost all the way the graphics still look amazing for a game that came out so long ago at this point. There is also a bunch of sides modes such as riddler's challenges, Harley Quinn's Revenge(Play this mode after beating the main game because it contains spoilers.), a collectible viewer, etc. For those looking for more of a challenge check out the new game plus. The side missions of the main game are amazing as well. I have completed all but four at the time of writing(The ones I haven't beat are the riddler side quest at 30% complete, the identity theft side quest at 50% complete, the AR training quest at 90% and the political prisoners in trouble side quest at 90%.) I promise you that this is worth full price for any Batman fan like me, but if you aren't that big into Batman I suggest waiting for a sale considering how old the game is now.

This title achieved Game of the Year status, so a review on its merits is superfluous-- instead I will comment on how it holds up, almost 10 years later.

I am currently playing Arkham City on an Acer Predator Helios 300 with an RTX3060, which as of the date of this review is still considered a good, middle of the road GPU, and this game plays smoothly. Readers should note that there exists a mod on nexusmods.com for an unofficial HD texture update, although I myself haven't been successful in enabling the Arkham City Redux update using their built-in launcher. Even so, with  Rocksteady's unique graphical style, it's not a bad game to look at (think X-Box 360). Some of the flourishes seem a bit stiff (falling leaves, newspapers blowing in the wind), but otherwise Arkham City is still able to pull off an immersive and atmospheric presentation. 

Grab it, along with Arkham Asylum, for a great pair of games that really set the standard for superhero-themed adventure titles.

this game is; simply put, incredible. there is not a moment in which you are bored, every single piece of this game from the environment to characters is intricately crafted to perfection. it is a remarkable successor to arkham asylum, with rocksteady's arkham series being both an icon in video games and superhero media whose legacy can be seen across countless media today. 

the gameplay is revolutionary for its time. it is definitely an improvement from asylum- much more fluid with more freedom and combos. there are endless amounts of ways to take down enemies, both in strategy and combos. the arkham combat system has undoubtedly left a major impact on video game combat, and despite its years it never gets old. 

the atmosphere encapsulates the essence of the gotham, there is so much detail put into every nook and cranny. Not a single piece of the city feels "empty", it is evident that the devs put their heart and soul into the creation of the environment. there is so much to explore, and the atmospheric storytelling is rich and interesting. 

the characters are all extremely accurate to their comic counterpart, especially that of joker, harley, catwoman and batman himself. the designs are gorgeous and suit their character so well- harley and catwoman's costumes here might be my favourite across all media. everyone has a unique moveset and feel to their combat, and not a single playable character has significantly better combat than the others.

the storytelling is nothing short of amazing. the foreshadowing in the beginning with [spoiler] the painting of cain and abel is absolutely genius, both a nod to the comic panels of the death of jason todd & the ending.[/spoiler] the ending is jaw-dropping. i was in shock and awe when the shot of [spoiler] batman carrying joker [/spoiler] was on screen. somehow hit harder than an actual movie. 

all in all, a breathtaking game. the arkham series is THE GOAT.

One of my top 20 favorite games I've ever played, but also definitely the best of comic-series-turned-video-game. Gameplay and story are engaging, characters were spot-on, and battles were epic. Gadgets were dynamic and flowed perfectly into the fast-paced combat. DLC content fit, was fun, and was worthy of the base game's quality. Combat and predator challenges were very helpful (and highly addictive). Getting to play as so many different characters with so many different styles and abilities was what really put the game over the top, in my opinion; it's what really upped the replayability from my perspective. This game was a perfect natural progression from Arkham Asylum in terms of story, controls, and mechanics; it was far better than the more recent entry Arkham Knight (which I basically hate with a burning passion). Music was great, art was great, dialog was great, pacing was great, etc. This is one of the only games I own on multiple platforms.

THE BEST BATMAN GAME EVER MADE!!!!!!!

Yet another fantastic Batman game that expands and improves on the systems introduced in Arkham Asylum. Combat feels mostly the same but faster and with a tiny bit more of strategy to it thanks to the inclusion of new enemy types. The best and most noticeable upgrade is the one made to Batman's movement. Gliding all over the city without ever touching the ground feels great and makes moving from one place to another an enjoyable activity that prevents the need to rely on any kind of fast travel methods like many other open world games.

The completionist experience feels a bit worse than Asylum. I think 400 Riddler collectibles is a bit overkill, even if the map is bigger in this game. It's nice that you can actually catch the Riddler with your own two hands this time around (unlike Asylum) while also having to rescue multiple victims along the way but again, these are way too many trophies to hunt down.

The story is very solid, if anything because of the great sense of continuity it has right after finishing Arkham Asylum. It's another rogues gallery story, but everyone gets to have great moments and it's just a good time all around.

The DLC content included in this version of the game is also pretty good. Harley Quinn's Revenge gives some subtle foreshadowing of what's to come in Arkham Knight.

I am currently playing through all of the Arkham Trilogy and just finished this game this morning. While I have yet to play Arkham Knight, I do believe that this game is my new favorite game of all time.

The best Arkham game! In fact, I recommend this installment the most than the other three.

It's a lot similar to Asylum, but with lots of new stuff added. Even the combat has been expanded, but the core element is still the same. The map is twice as large as Asylum, and feel a lot more "open-world" than its predecessor. Even the puzzles are twice as more intricate than the last (damn you, Riddler!). And last but not least, Batman won't be the only playable character.

Overall, not much is changed from Asylum. To be exact, it's more of perfecting the elements that made Asylum so great. You can simply jump straight to City since some of the in-game data sort of explained the event from Asylum, so you won't miss much.

Frankly, it's a lot better to only play City since it's basically an improvement from Asylum, the writing is better than Origin, and it doesn't have sort of unnecessary mechanic (I'm talking to you, Batmobile from Knight).

Worth all the hype it has received over the years. Even a decade later, it's still very very much an amazing game. Neither graphics nor function are dated in this classic. On the contrary, Batman AC is often the standard for many other games to achieve.

Though, IMO, Batman Arkham Knight does top this one, this second installment could arguably be the best (pre-Gotham Knights). It improves upon many of the mechanics of the first, while adding all sorts of freedom and new gadgets. Whether it is a merit or demerit is debatable, I find this one to be much for open than Batman AA. I was much less interested in pursuing Riddler til the end (though the conclusion is better than AA) and finishing half of the other side-quests in favor of just finishing the game.

The graphics are almost identical to AA, but now you have a whole city to explore! Combat is a little bit smoother, and you have a few more options are your disposal.  The story is great, and there is nothing I would generally bash about this game - a fantastic production from RockSteady, and I highly recommend this game to all.

[i]Arkham City[/i] is one of those games that's a contender for best game of all time (though obviously YMMV). It takes the thrilling combat and stealth mechanics from [i]Asylum[/i], making improvements and expanding the story from the tightly linear plot of the first game into an open world mega-prison district. This allows one of the most key additions: improvements to cape-gliding, and the space to use it in, creating some really fun mobility-based gameplay.

It's hard to overstate how solid of a game this is. Even the complaints I have of it are fairly subjective: The Catwoman segments, while still fun, lag behind the main gameplay by the end. [i]City[/i] is also the horniest game of the series, which I thought was a bit goofy and screwed up the vibe a little. But hey, if that's your thing.

Overall, easy recommend.

Jokes aside, this is, in my opinion, the best Arkham game out of all of them. Origins was great, but has a bunch of bugs and completely wastes the potential of an interesting villain (not gonna spoil it, but if you've played, you know).  And Knight, although I've softened a bit on the game, is still probably the weakest due to a plethora of different issues (just to name a few- boring Batmobile fights, awful bosses and wastes of villains, Scarecrow is super boring (seriously, Asylum Scarecrow is best Scarecrow), and once again pulls the Joker card to get out of actually putting focus on Batman's other rogues).

City, in my opinion, is the height of the series. The gameplay from Asylum is improved in basically every way, with more enemy types, a NG+ mode, different characters for challenge mode, a bigger open world, and more varied, entertaining bosses. The story is great, and actually allows Batman's other villains, like Penguin and Hugo Strange, to contribute to the plot and have screentime without the Joker being tossed into the scene because "He's the archenemy so it's ok to keep spamming him nonstop and putting potentially interesting villains into the background!" The atmosphere is great, and it's really fun to fly around the city and just look at the scenery. The thug chatter is really entertaining, there's a lot of really cool sections, and as always, the voice cast does a great job. Get this game. 

One final section here, just to pay tribute to Kevin Conroy, who passed away earlier this month. It's a bit late, but I still want to acknowledge his incredible performance as Batman in not only this game, but in several different movies and shows over the years, starting in 1992. Ever since I first played Asylum all the way back in the early 2010s, he has always stuck with me as THE Batman. Rest In Peace.

Even after 11 years since its premiere, this is still a marvellous game. And its biggest strength? The gameplay. Silky smooth, whether you traverse the city or chain crazy combos, it is pure fun, and I can easily see myself returning to Arkham City repeatedly in the future. The soundtrack and dubbing are stellar as well, as is the story. Heck, even graphics don't look too bad. 
The only thing I didn't really like is the daunting number of Riddler's collectibles and puzzles. I don't see myself maxing this one ever.
Still, this is the best entry in the overall great series.

Well done follow up to Arkham Asylum, with much more. You can tell they had learned a lot from the first game, though I do think some aspects may have been a bit much like all the ways Batman can move and the sheer amount of things to find. Certainly a longer and larger game than the first one. I especially loved being able to play as Catwoman, though I wish we had gotten more of that. I liked how this story line connected to the events of the first one. Would definitely recommend playing Arkham Asylum first as there are a TON of callbacks- this is a direct sequel to the events that happen there. The graphics were lovely, still stand the test of time several years later, and the voice acting was superb.  That aspect was even better this game, less clunky and far more smooth and natural sounding than Arkham Asylum.
Best game in the Arkham series IMO. A Must play for any batman fan, combat is excellent - Easy to learn, hard to master.

TLDR: If you are a batman fan and love comics. This game is a must. It is almost like interacting with a batman comic book. 

Also one of the best versions of batman without a doubt.

The graphics are still good to this day. They are not realistic but it has that comic booky style which is lovely. Everything from the character designs to Gotham city itself (a small section of it but okay) is simply lovely.

Atmosphere? Man, this game definitely shows what Gotham City is like. Unlike any other media, this time you are in Gotham City, although a small section of it, and this means you can explore every inch of it which shows how much developers put their love into it. Art deco buildings are everywhere, there are neon lights illuminating the streets. The backdrop of the prison shows the rest of Gotham city and you feel intimidated by huge skyscrapers. Also, it is middle of the winter and the weather is snowy.  And IMO, there is no better setting than winter and snow (or rain) for any batman story. We are in this city prison called "Arkham City", and at every turn, there are thugs, and big baddies (Hugo Strange, two-face, Penguin, Mr. Freeze, riddler, etc.). Once the game starts it shows you how dangerous this prison is. You are trapped inside this prison with no way out. This prison is alive, you hear the thugs while roaming around the city and they react to the events that happened in the story, they have their own opinions which makes them individuals despite almost looking copy of one another. It is simply fun to stop and listen to what they talk about. 

As for the story, it is just so good. The way the story makes batman face every baddie in his gallery is so good that you don't even stop and think "wait how is that related to the plot right now?". 

As for the gameplay, you FEEL like Batman. The combat is amazing, it is easy to learn but hard to master. There are multiple gadgets you can use during fights and when you master the combat, boy it is just perfect. 

Lastly, the voice acting in this game is superb. Kevin Conroy is the definitive Batman and Mark Hammil is the definitive Joker IMO.

Batman: Arkham City is what happens when you take a good superhero game and try to make it open world, and I'd say Rocksteady did a pretty good job.
They took what made Arkham Asylum great and then added some more to their formula.


[h2]Pros: [/h2] 
[list]
    [*]A good sized city with a lot of exploration options.
    [*]The Freeflow combat system, which is extremely satisfying as you rack up those combos.
    [*]A very well written story.
    [*]Creative side quests.
    [*]Top notch voice acting that includes veterans like the iconic late Kevin Conroy (RIP), Mark Hamill, Grey Griffin, Tara Strong, Nolan North and many more.
    [*]Great immersive soundtrack by Nick Arundel and Ron Fish.
    [*]Great boss battles that require you to actually think and change tactics.
    [*]Puzzles, riddles, you name it.
    [*]The arena/challenge mode can be fun.
    [*]Some of Robin's gadgets like the shield spice up the way you play in the Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC.
    [*]The game can easily run on any potato specs computer.
    [*]You can always listen to the thugs trash talking you then watch their heart rate skyrocket as you beat them up.
[/list]

[h3] Cons: [/h3]
There aren't many of these and I'm probably nitpicking;
[list]
    [*]Some of the Riddler's collectibles can be a pain to get.
    [*]Harley Quinn's Revenge DLC is pretty short imo.
[/list]

[b] TL;DR: This is the best Batman game of all time and everyone should at least experience it once. [/b]

Arkham Asylum is a perfect example of a game where the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.  While the combat and stealth were both merely okay, the level design, exploration, and atmosphere (helped greatly by some of the best voice acting ever in a game) elevated the game to greatness.  Doubly so if you like Batman, and who doesn't like Batman?  The only problem I had with the game (besides the mediocre combat and stealth) was that the game forces both combat and stealth encounters on you, rather than letting you choose how to tackle each problem.

Arkham City adds pretty much more of everything—a much larger map, more optional content, more upgrades, more gadgets—but strangely makes hardly any improvements the core combat and stealth mechanics.  There are some new enemy types and other new wrinkles, but you will be doing pretty much the same thing in every combat or stealth encounter from the beginning to the end; this is a problem since you already did this for 20+ hours in Arkham Asylum.
[hr][/hr]
Unfortunately, the game falls behind Asylum in two key areas.

The first is level design.  The tightly designed environments of Asylum are here replaced with a sprawling city in which 99% of the buildings are just things for you to sit on.  On top of that, the few structures that you can enter are pretty boring and very linear.

The second area in which City falls behind Asylum is the length of the game.  Asylum was a pretty meaty game with a story that would take you anywhere from 15-20 hours to complete; in contrast, City has a story that can be completed in 10 hours. It does have TONS of optional stuff to do, so if you love seeking out side missions and slowly filling out lists of optional content, character models, etc., City might be your game.

However, if you (like me) are not interested in optional stuff and want to play City as the sequel to Asylum, you might be quite disappointed when you reach the end (including a final fight against a boss that comes out of nowhere).
[hr][/hr]
Having said that, it's got the Arkham formula down to a science, and if you enjoyed Asylum you're sure to enjoy this one.

Arkham Asylum's sequel is action-packed and full of that good old combat mastery.

(I have probably a few hundred hours on console.  Revisiting on Steam to honor Kevin Conroy.)

As amazing as Arkham Asylum is, City improves on its gameplay and level design in almost every single way.  The combat is faster, the enemies have a lot more variety to them, the boss battles are amazing, and it's just a perfectly paced game on top of all of that.  (Also, Catwoman.)

For me it's ALMOST a toss-up whether or not City or Knight are the best Arkham game.  (Asylum isn't far behind either of them, and Origins is actually somewhat underrated but not quite as good.)  All in all I think that Knight has a slight edge for having the Batmobile and some of the best level design out there.  But City (even more so than Asylum) is the game that perfected the formula, and expanded the Arkham experience.  Each main entry in the series is one of the greatest games of all time.  And the main trilogy of Arkham games is a nearly untouchable experience.

I was blown away by how well this game holds up more than ten years after release. As an experience, it easily tops 99% of all modern titles both in the genre and outside it, including, unfortunately, the sequel.

If you are reading this and you haven't played any of the games in the Arkham series or perhaps you remember this game faintly from having played it a long time ago, do yourself a favour and play through it again. For me, it served as a reminder of what serious effort and talent in game-design and storytelling feels like.

Oh, and the music is amazing too.

Batman: Arkham City is the second game in the Arkham franchise, and it is considered to be one of the best Batman games ever made.  As someone who has played and beaten all four games in the series (if you count Origins, made by a different developer), I highly recommend this game.  But here's my recommendation:

1. Play Arkham Asylum first.  It's the oldest of the games, but it plays well, the story is excellent, and it's a good introduction to the series.  The story of Asylum leads well into Arkham City's story.  
2. Play Arkham City.  The game's story is one of the best in the series, and the characters are fleshed out and true to their comic-book counterparts.  The large Asylum in the first game is replaced by a larger section of Gotham, and the roster of villains and allies also expands.  Catwoman is also a playable character. 
3. Optional: Play Origins.  It is fun but is more of a prequel.  Still fun, but different developers, and the story isn't as good or faithful to the comics/animated shows.
4. Play Arkham Knight.  The PC port was atrocious on launch but has been patched and really finishes the franchise well.  More playable characters, Bat-tank to drive through Gotham, and a full city to explore. 

Overall an excellent franchise with a compelling story.  And the Steam sales for this series are great.

This is one of the best atmospheric games ever created! This game is from times, when men had chest like a barrel and women were pretty and they knew what to wear. Yes those times. Exactly!

So men are manly, women are womanly, punches hit hard, villains do bad stuff and the only way to solve it is by hitting them repeatedly over and over again. Yes I know the perfect world! Yes, everything makes sense. No grey zones, no middle grounds, simple solutions, to simple problems.
When I played this game before some years, I did not appreciate it as much as I am appreciating it now. Everything around us is complicated now. Nobody knows what, who, where, why. We just know we had it wrong or at least this is what I hear.

Thus do yourself a favor, do not waste time and play, just for the old times sake.
Whether you are a DC/Batman fan or not just buy this game. Just do it. Worth your time worth your money.

Batman: Arkham City is one of the greatest games ever made and easily the greatest superhero game ever made. This is the perfect representation of Batman.
The voice acting is phenomenal with some of the most talented voice actors and actresses in the industry having a role within this games such as; Kevin Conroy, Nolan North, Troy Baker, Mark Hamill and Tara Strong to name a few. This game makes you feel like you are Batman kicking ass and taking names. The story is amazing and fighting, the stealth, the gadgets the city and the graphics are all things that hold up and make this game stand out. This game is a work of art and is one of a very few games that are almost perfect.

Batman Arkham City is bigger and has more of everything than Arkham Asylum, but for me, I preferred Asylum’s story, confined space, and easier-to-understand controls that Arkham City. Batman AC’s story just doesn’t make any sense and felt like a mixing bowl of Batman’s rouges gallery thrown into a story. The chain of events that lead to the end of the story never fit and I played through the game twice and still had to read a synopsis to understand the story. At the end, I strongly felt that Batman mourned the wrong person’s death. Another story choice that baffles me. I did enjoy the side missions and Harley’s DLC.

Arkham City is beautifully detailed and filled with interesting locations. Gliding over the city and launching yourself into the air with a batclaw is very satisfying. Tracking down 440 Riddler trophies is not. Lastly, the amount of button combinations needed for all the quick gadgets, gadgets, jumps, slides, kicks, punches, counters, etc. was over the top. Despite my gripes, I do still recommend the game. It’s a good 20-hour game with another 80+ hours of Riddle trophy and challenge pack filler.

Absolutely a worthy sequel to Arkham Asylum. This game builds on every single mechanic in the original, heightens the stakes of the original story while still maintaining feasibility within its own comic-book world, and really delivers on a surprising and exciting finale. Same great atmosphere as Arkham Asylum, same mood for the soundtrack, and a good number of QoL improvements in how your tools are leveraged. This game plays very, very similarly to its predecessor, which isn't a bad thing at all. I do kind of cringe at the Catwoman segments, but I guess her characterization is just a product of the times. Dock a few points, but it's not a gamebreaker.

Overall, this is very much one of those "if you like the first one, you'll like this one too" situations. More than worth the price tag, in my opinion.

It's hard to call this game an "Improvement" over its predecessor since I feel both games attempt to do different things. The scope of both games is also different.

Now, a cynical take would be that this game is the result of the trend of open-world games infecting the Arkham series, and this is clearly not wrong, but I feel it misses the point that the previous entry was already excellent and that opening up the setting this way was a totally valid way to take the franchise forward. 

That being said, there's plenty of things here that also distinguish the game from many other "open world" games, specially the movement mechanics. Batman's ability to glide and move about is the glue that binds every other aspect that hinges on the open world and it works very well.

Additionally, many aspects from Asylum return, such as the sandbox arenas, the puzzle boss fights and the whole collectibles aspect courtesy of the Riddler. It's clear an attempt was made to include these elements and add a bit of flavor to them as to distinguish them from the previous entry. The result sometimes is a little too on-the-nose when it's gimmicky, but often the set pieces feel pretty fresh, despite the same underlying gameplay.

Returning also is the excellent atmosphere and visual design, along with greater graphical fidelity as expected.

Another interesting addition is the multiplayer component found in the extra stages which focus entirely on combat encounters. It's a nice side diversion but it highlights how this game is already pushing the combat system so far that the problems become apparent. Mind you, just like the previous game, the combat system within the context of the main campaign is perfectly acceptable, but as you play the extra missions it becomes clear that there's a lot of automation and it leads to a lot of the encounters feeling samey. Compare and contrast this to a game series like Devil May Cry, and you can see that the automation of the combat system, while impressive for what it is, ultimately makes a lot of the combat lack player expression.

But at the end of the day that's a minor nitpick in what is otherwise an excellent sequel to an already excellent game. Recommended.

Another one of the games that I used to play on the PS3. Much like Sleeping Dogs, I was pleasantly surprised that I was able to hop back into this franchise. If you're a fan of open-world games and action combat, this game is 100% of you. Arkham's combat system has essentially laid the groundwork for any other similar minded combat system, and if you've played Spider-Man (2018) it's the same exact vibe.

With that in mind this story is also very unique to experience, though most of the game time for me wasn't in the story but was in the side missions. Side missions are great, but collectibles are tedious as any Arkham players knows. 440 riddler secrets is no mean feat, and not for the faint hearted. Not to mention the extra challenge maps.

Overall this is a good game to hop into for the open-world, story and combat. However if you're looking for an entertaining collectibles search this may not be the best since it can be a bit of a slog if you aren't familiar with the game mechanics. Riddler Challenges are a dope test of those skills though, so it might also be exactly the kind of grind you want.

Thursday, October 31st. The city streets are crowded for the holiday. Even with the rain. Hidden in the chaos is the element, waiting to strike like snakes. And I’m there too. Watching.

2 years of nights have turned me into a nocturnal animal. I must choose my targets carefully. It’s a big city. I can’t be everywhere. But they don’t know where I am. We have a signal now, for when I’m needed. When that light hits the sky, it’s not just a call- it’s a warning. To them.

Fear is a tool. They think I’m hiding in the shadows. But I AM the shadows. I wish I could say I’m making a difference, but I’m not. Murder, robberies, assault- 2 years later, they’re all up. And now this. This city’s eating itself. Maybe it can’t be saved, but I have to try. PUSH MYSELF. These nights all roll together in a rush, Behind the mask. Sometimes in the morning I have to force myself to remember everything that happened.

I had to turn off vsync to get it to run on my new computer. With vsync off, I can run it in 4K with max settings, with some minor screen tearing.. I tried frame limiting it in the Nvidia control panel, but it doesn't seem to stop the screen tearing.

Also it installs AMD dual core optimizer when you first run, which may cause issues, so you may want to uninstall it and reboot your PC if you have problems.
The best game on the planet

Improves a lot of things compared to Arkham Asylum but sadly also messes up some of the features that were better in the first game.

What'll you notice first is that game looks a LOT better, no longer does the game look like it's had a brown filter added to it. Everything has more color, is way more diverse and also has a lot more detail. The city feels alive, there are many more different locations than in Asylum and getting around is actually quite fast (even faster if you do the first AR mission for grapple boost). Some locations do feel a bit underused and I didn't feel it was optimized quite well. Usually ran about 120fps on Extreme but sometimes would dip to 30fps for no reason, even tracked CPU/GPU/RAM and weren't even close to being maxed.

Gameplay is much more interesting than Asylum. The combat actually becomes so much easier once you get the hang of all the combos (although some are very weirdly keybinded) and the upgrades feel like they actually bring something useful to the table. There are way more gadgets, some only used on specific puzzles/boss fights but sneaking around they do give you options. 

Platforming is way more fluent than the first game. It actually feels very natural, the grapple sensor is quite on point and the controls behave quite well. You'll still often roll into something when you mean to jump but had it happens far less than the first game. The gliding missions can be tedious as hell though, same goes for the controlled batarang.

There is way more content this time around, the main story is quite shortish but the secondary objectives, collectables, challenges and the game+ mode add some replayability so that's definitely a lot of content.

Again, the voice acting is top notch, Music wise there is nothing to complain about, it's all very well done. One minor complaint is towards the final part of the game where I felt that picking up the chatter from the choppers got a tad annoying.

The characters are very well designed. The taunts on death are even better now with more characters reminding you how bad you are at the game. I don't read the comic books, but get the feeling they stayed true to how they look. Catwoman and Harley are yummy indeed.

Now, I enjoyed the game very much but there are some very big complaints coming next.

The story is by far the weakest part of this game. It's a bit short but worse, it just doesn't make any sense.
So many things had me shaking my head thinking 'wtf'. 
[spoiler]No one seems to care Bruce Wayne gets tossed in jail, Batman gets poisoned but takes 4 months to bother getting the cure, ow nvm Joker has a clone now, catwoman hates plants, bad professor does bad things cause other bad guy told him but ow wait he's got a bomb,... [/spoiler]It's such a mess. Even when the game finishes, it felt like that's it? seriously?

Next is the Riddler collectibles. They were actually very well done in the first game. Not too many, just enough to make you bother collecting them all, with a little secret ending to reward you. Here, they expect you to go find 400 collectibles. They're easy enough to find but goddamn are the puzzles tedious as fuck. I gave up after throwing 40 batarangs in a pipe to get one trophy. Also the menu is a bitch to navigate so enjoy looking for hints. It gets sadder than one of more interesting side quests involving Riddler forces you to collect these or you can't advance the quest. That's just retarted.

Next part that annoyed me to no end. Sometimes for no reason, at least when play with controller, the game will start spamming both prompts. So for a grapple, it'll keep prompting 'F' and 'RMB', keyboard and controller prompts basically. This makes the game have a literal seizure and run at 5fps. But that's not the worst part, the worst part is having to restart the game completely to fix it. Which wouldn't be so bad if they didn't do what they did in the first game. Which is make you sit through another 30 secs of who made they game, ow look we used Bing Video and 10 secs of Nvidia being blasted in your ear. I restarted the game like 20 times over my 19 hour playthrough because the game becomes literally unplayable.

Ow and the game is called BATMAN Arkham City not BATMAN and some CATWOMAN Arkham City. I know she has some killer tits and an ass you wanna eat breakfast off but I didn't enjoy the gameplay as Catwoman. The Mad hatter part was dope tho.

Still, worth a buy. You'll get a lot of content, just don't expect an interesting story and hope you have less controller issues than I did and you might even enjoy the game more than I did.

I bought this based on the enjoyment I had with the first Rocksteady Batman title in Arkham Asylum.  This entry just adds more of everything.  More map, more collectibles, more gadgets, more move options, and most disappointingly, more DLC that you have to pay for to experience everything.  From what I could discern, the "Game of the Year" addition contains nothing new over the original game.  I replayed this version and did not see any difference.

The story is worse than Arkham Asylum and I felt suffered from an excess of villains, but I still enjoyed it for the most part.  This is a good game based on all the additional content you get, but not as good as the original.  Case in point, I 100% Arkham Asylum, but I couldn't muster the patience to do it for this one.  Catch it on a sale if you're into the superhero genre and Batman theme.

An excessively mediocre Batman experience. Honestly, this feels like an intended DLC that the developers padded out to sell as a full game to obtain a quick revenue injection. There are only a handful of forgettable locations the game actually takes place in -- each repeating a handful of times. 

Moreover, the boss fights are extremely lame, the story feels like a wild goose chase with no clear throughput, and the catwoman inclusion just felt gimmicky and unnecessary. Similarly, the levels were often poorly designed -- I frequently got lost trying to figure out where to go or what to do next.
Makes up for the shortcomings of the prequel (which was great despite them) and offers excellent gameplay and environment. Voice acting is top-notch!

The game that makes you feel like Batman. For real though, this game is AMAZING. Such an improvement on the (in my honest opinion) mediocre Arkham Asylum. Of course the main selling point of this sequel is you get to explore a city instead of a cramped claustrophobia asylum. The world is really big but it does what most open worlds, even today, fail to do which is be MEMORABLE. Despite the gigantic size I can still pinpoint which building is where on the map without looking at the waypoints which is a really impressive feat even 10 years later. The city is split into multiple districts and each are packed with riddler trophies to lose your sanity over. Like come on, 282? Not saying they aren't fun to collect, just wanted to point out the absurdity of the amount of trophies riddler somehow managed to place without being gunned down immediately by thugs. It's really impressive how many of batman's rogues gallery they managed to put in this game without feeling overbearing. Each character is pretty seamlessly woven into the chaos and it makes for really engaging foes despite their relatively miniscule role in the grand scheme of things. The sidequests are also really fun with many of them focusing on one of batman's most iconic villains. I would be lying if I didn't say that mad hatter's quest didn't caught me off guard, a call from Alfred claiming he found the cure batman has been looking for and to retrieve it on the rooftop of mad hatter's hideout. Seems a bit SUSpicious dont you agree? Then you wake up inside this nightmarish realm with a TERRIFYING bunny batman, like seriously I thought this would be a really simple side quest but no, it took a completely unexpected turn. The way the game handles each villain is fascinating and makes the otherwise goofy-looking evildoers actually menacing. Mr Freeze was a standout, he looks so silly and as someone who didn't watch the batman animated series growing up he sounded so random and wacky. But his arc in this game, with hsi tragic backstory and motivation, is heartbreaking. And I'm solely talking about his character because I found his fight really easy and disappointing (again my opinion I know a lot of ppl like this fight), brilliant stuff Rocksteady. The story is MUCH better than asylum too with more stakes and a more convincing motivation for batman doing what he does, though I feel the "joker being clayface" thing didn't really stick for me because if you didn't know the character prior to this reveal then it feels like a pretty out-of-nowhere plot twist. The game could've maybe had Clayface play a larger role because the only time hes mentioned in the game before the final fight (as far as I know) is in one of those riddler scans. Other than that, Arkham City is a sequel that improves on EVERYTHING that its predecessor did and is one of the few open worlds that doesn't feel daunting to explore. 9/10
I LOVE this game. Improvements on all fronts as compared to the excellent Arkham Asylum. Highly Recommended.

[h1] READ THIS BEFORE STARTING UP THE GAME FOR THE FIRST TIME [/h1]

During the installation process, along with the DirectX libraries, another program will be installed called [b] AMD Dual-Core Optimizer [/b] which was meant to improve the performance on systems that run Windows XP and use old AMD Dual-Core CPUs.

On PCs that run Windows Vista and later and/or an Intel CPU, you won't need that program because it will impact the performance and cause other issues.

Unfortunately when you launch the game for the first time you don't get the choice to decline the installation of AMD Dual-Core Optimizer (that's why I left a negative review).
In order to stop that program from being installed, do as follows:

[i] If the program is already installed, you should uninstall it. Go to "Programs and Features", select "AMD Dual-Core Optimizer" and click "Uninstall" (perhaps it will take a while, do not cancel the process and wait); afterwords, reboot the PC. [/i]

    1) Go to the installation folder of the game (right click on the game title -> properties -> local files tab -> browse local files)
    2) Open "installscript.vdf" (right click -> open with -> use Notepad)
    3) Scroll down until you see the word "AMD", followed by a bunch of code between the two perpendicular { and } brackets; delete that portion of code, beginning from the word "AMD" to the last perpendicular bracket (note that you must leave the brackets on the left side and everything else)
    4) Save the file. Make sure you didn't delete anything that has to do with DXSetup, VCRedist_x86 and DotNetFx35
    5) When you're done, go to the "Setup" folder and delete "amd_dc_opt.exe" (this is an optional step, just to be safe)

If you've done everything correctly, when you launch the game the installation of AMD Dual-Core Optimizer won't start.

[b] REMEMBER TO NOT VERIFY THE INTEGRITY OF GAME FILES, OTHERWISE YOU MUST REPEAT THE PROCEDURE [/b]

Second on the re-playing saga, Arkham City is a greater improvement on Asylum, most noticeable in the fighting area. The story is richer, the map is bigger and we can engage different enemies and characters from the Batman universe in contrast to its predecessor.

But i have a complain, is for someone wanting to get ALL the steam achievements; the Riddler challenges are definetely a PAIN IN THE ASSSSSSS. My god, i suffer a lot. More than 100 hours to finish this, when completing the whole game (with the 400+ Riddler trophies) took me like 20 hours, tops. Even after playing New Game + (required for a couple of the achievements), still i may have spent 27/30 hours. The rest was just pain through these challenges. If you are not really good with the combat system (i mean, i was good enough for the main game, but for the challenges was something completely different), you are gonna suffer. A lot. It took me all of Batman's challenges, and maybe half of Catwoman's to make a mental checklist of movements to get the most points possible. Besides, you are probably gonna do twice or even thrice for some of the combat/predator challenges, since in the campaign challenges you have to "repeat" them, but with obstacles (if it wasn't hard enough). Definetely this was Satan's work, but i'm glad is over. Will wait some days before jumping into Origins, or i'm gonna have a stroke.

Good ass game. a bit more of a polished, less gimmicky experience than Arkham Asylum with big overhauls added to how you move around the overworld. I thoroughly enjoyed this game's fluid combat and I felt there was a distinct improvement in gameplay and writing. With that being said, the game's pacing, characters, and atmosphere weren't as strong as the first game even though I still had a good time with them. The game suffers from a saturation of collectibles and surface level side missions that boil down to repetitive tasks that waste time. Fantastic visuals for a game that was released in 2011 and still holds up very well. 8/10

I finally played this game in 2022. I was a huge fan of Arkham Asylum, so naturally I bought Arkham City on sale. However, it was a transitional phase in my life, and I mostly went on hiatus from PC gaming, so this sat in my backlog. I'm now trying to clear some games out, and this was one of my top picks. How does it hold up all these years later, with rose-tinted memory of its predecessor?

One negative was just how unfocused and chaotic the story progression is. From the opening moments of the game, the story just barfs characters, flashbacks, lore, exposition, and comic book references, yet none of it feels in service to a greater narrative. It's the video game equivalent of celebrity name-dropping. They clearly tried to cover more of the Batman universe, but they've stretched themselves a bit too thin. I remember Asylum having a surprisingly compelling story with excellent progression, but this doesn't feel that way at all.

The game play is a similar story. It's structured like an open-world game, albeit with a relatively small open world. Throughout it are countless training missions, events, secrets, side missions, characters, collectibles, etc. If you've ever played one of those F2P mobile MMOs that just throws a bunch of stuff at the wall to see what sticks, that's what this feels like. Much like with those F2P games, I honestly think this game throws too much at you all at once. Ironically, if there's anything it gives the player gradually over time, it's the tools necessary to do everything. Hours into this game, I'm still unlocking new abilities needed to complete many of the challenges, which may sound like a good thing, but the game does a poor job of guiding the player through the progression. There are rarely ever tutorials, and when there are, they're almost never any good. There are also minimal indications of when something isn't yet accessible with the current set of abilities.

The level-up menus are so unhelpful that I never really know how to use the abilities I'm unlocking. Many of them are so situational that I just find myself pressing keys when prompts appear without having the time to read or understand them. In Asylum, it felt meaningful to unlock a new ability, and I generally understood the immediate impact it had on my ability to manipulate the game world.

I also think they did themselves a bit of a disservice when placing the main story missions in the open world. In fact, "open world" is maybe a bit misleading, because at least early in the game, there's a huge restricted zone up through the middle of the map, so it's basically a big upside-down U shape. This wouldn't be so bad if the story progressed linearly around the U before opening up the restricted zone for the late game, but the main missions seem to flip-flop between opposite ends of the map, so you're constantly having to traverse the entire perimeter, which ends up feeling like a chore. As if the designers couldn't help themselves, they even exacerbated this issue by introducing all kinds of silly ideas that conflict with this map layout. A perfect example is when you need to locate Mr. Freeze by monitoring temperature and following it to the coldest zone in the map. This sounds like a cool idea, except that the temperatures might lead you to the border of the restricted zone, and the place you get to might be all the way on the other side.

That being said, is this a bad game? Absolutely not. A lot of this inconsistency seems to stem from the fact that it's arguably one of the most ambitious games ever made. The fact that they stuffed so many little twists on what are effectively just prompts and quest triggers is technically impressive, and some of them do feel better than others. One that stood out for me was when interrogating Riddler's thugs. As part of a Riddler quest, you need to walk around, find groups of thugs, and take them all out except for a single designated informant, at which point Batman can lift them up by their throat and interrogate them. This serves 2 purposes: 1) show Riddler secret locations on the map; 2) when you've successfully collected enough Riddler secrets (which are themselves puzzles rather than just basic collectables), interrogating an informant will reveal the location of another hostage that will progress the Riddler story line. These functions should sound completely familiar to veteran gamers, but done in a unique way that integrates puzzles, secrets, and missions together, making all of them more compelling. Lots of the negative things I pointed out above are byproducts of the developer's efforts to go above and beyond in making compelling versions of common game tropes.

This last point is not so much positive or negative as it is subjective. I remember in the mid 2000s, there was this prevailing design trend of games becoming more forgiving and hand-holding, exemplified by games like Call of Duty: Modern Warfare which popularized regenerating health. Only a handful of exceptions like the Souls series were praised for embracing traditional design. Thankfully, this dichotomy is much more nuanced in today's game design, with plenty of acceptance for games throughout the spectrum. This game may not have come across this way when it came out, but playing it in 2022, this game definitely has elements of the Souls school of design, in that many of the challenges and puzzles are quite difficult and opaque. This actually stands in stark contrast to the main missions, as well as the first game in the series, which was known for being a very straightforward and elegant brawler that was accessible to players of all skill levels. You can absolutely breeze through the main story missions in this game and ignore the optional challenges, but if you do attempt them, there are numerous challenges that expect you to master the very fine nuances of the physics system and gadgets. Personally, I don't love this. It's not so much the difficulty level that bothers me, but rather that the challenge prompts do a poor job of clarifying what players need to do. A good example is when the game teaches you to press the Ctrl key to dive while gliding, but fails to mention that letting go of Ctrl puts you back into a horizontal glide. I spent hours trying to complete stupid physics challenges that seemed impossible, until I searched for completion videos on YouTube and discovered that you can do crazy things like dive down and then pull up into a tight space like a tunnel or doorway, which is obviously very useful. I suspect many, if not most, players will breeze through much of the game not knowing that such advanced techniques are possible. However, for the right kind of player, having to discover these things through repeated tries and experimentation might be half the fun, so I think it was worth mentioning as a more neutral point.

To close out, I think this game has not aged as well as its predecessor. One of my favorite games is God of War 2018, and in many ways, Arkham Asylum felt like a precursor to that game. It was a very streamlined, approachable, exciting brawler with compelling narrative and just enough hints of open world design to make the experience more compelling than most linear story-driven games. In contrast, Arkham City almost feels like Arkham Asylum and Genshin Impact had a baby. Many of the core mechanics that worked so well in Arkham Asylum are present here, but the developer's attempt to make an extremely varied open-world experience with every Batman reference imaginable comes at the expense of focus. I spent hours coming to grips with the basics of this game, and now that I feel like I finally get it, I'm not as hooked on it as I was with Asylum back in the day. If you're looking to try this series in 2022, I would recommend starting with Asylum before deciding if you want more. Arkham City is different enough that it doesn't replace the former, and I think the former does what it does better.

Not as good as Origins or Arkham Asylum but from my point of i found this pro's and cons.
•Pros: 
1. Great plot where Hugo Strange now runs a prison like city & Joker dying! 
2. Outstanding voice acting performances 
3. You get to glide, dive & grapple at the same time! 
4. You get to play Catwoman! 
5. There are side missions in the game!
6. Love the boss battles starting with Solomon Grundy, Ra's Al Ghul, Mr Freeze & Clayface! 
7. It was the first Batman Arkham game to be an open world! 
8. Love how you can double or triple counter thugs hitting you during combat encounters! 
9. Love the Beatdown move introduced in this game! 
10. Love both the Remote Electric Charge & Freeze Blast gadgets!

•Cons: 
The Main Story objectives were a bit short! 
Must Buy.

Well it's more Arkham Asylum for you. So that's good. 

Wish Catwoman was a seperate campaign, so you can chose if you'd like to play her, instead of being forced.

All in all good stuff. A well made game, where you can play Batman. What's not to like?

So far this game exceeds its predecessor, Batman: Arkham Asylum, by a long shot. From the fighting mechanics to its mobility mechanics, the mechanics of this game are just amazing. You will also have a wider variety of methods in which you can utilize to apprehend your opponents, and several more useful gadgets to play around with. The story is engaging, and the side missions are great and don't feel like they take away from the story's main focus. The way the characters are written makes you feel that much more immersed into the city of Arkham, and the environments really make you feel like its the end of times almost.

The fighting in this game is phenomenally gorgeous and fluid, almost making you believe that you could recreate these moves in real life. You will love how the fighting is so seamlessly easy that you'll go beat up random thugs on the street just because. The counters in this game are also very fun, and the knockout hits are brutal. Suffice to say, you will have a great time with the fighting in this game.

The movement/mobility in this game is fantastic, and you can move along either the city streets and allies or its rooftops with your grappling hook. Gliding feels very smooth, and there aren't many times where I feel that it is bugged out or feels wonky. Grappling to ledges and higher ground is easy and honestly very accurate if you know how to aim.

The gadgets are more of the same from the previous title, but with a few new additions that make game play new and exciting. These new gadgets come into play with The Riddler's many different puzzles throughout the city. Which brings me to...

The Riddler's puzzles in this game are very fun to complete. Some of them are infuriating, and you might just look up a YouTube tutorial to figure some of them out, but figuring it out on your own is an extremely rewarding feeling. A lot of them are just simple puzzles that can be solved in a minute or two, but some genuinely have me stumped. There are Riddler Trophies that are only accessible through playing as Catwoman, which are indicated as red Riddler Trophies instead of green ones that Batman can pick up. Piece of advice, upgrade to the Sonic Shockwave Batarang as soon as you can. It helps you in the long run.

The graphics of this game are still quite amazing even in 2022. They aren't anything jaw dropping, like some more modern AAA game titles, but these graphics still hold up and can keep you immersed in game play for hours at a time. The animation is pretty good too, only every once in awhile breaking immersion with very obvious clipping and such, but not often. 

The open world aspect of this game allows you to explore most everything, and there is a ton to explore here. Of course you could just simply follow along the main story line instead of engaging in side missions and Riddler Puzzles, but you would be doing yourself a disservice by not at least doing a few of them here and there. Besides, they give you EXP that you can use to gain an edge over your enemies in future missions.

Overall this game is fantastic and well worth the money, although, I would still personally get it on a sale, especially if the trilogy is available in that sale. Even though this game is over a decade old it still holds up in terms of story, game play, achievement, and more. I have found that this is an extremely fun game that pulls me in for hours at a time, always having me wondering what's coming up next. And I'm not even done with the game yet! I will add my final thoughts on this game when I finish it.

I loved this game until I got the the Demon Trials section. Getting lift during flying isn't explained at all and is all but impossible using PC keys. I just keep falling, crashing and dying. It's ridiculous that they would make it this hard. Just awful. Someone figured out how to ruin a perfectly good game.

Now I am at the second visit to the steel mill to get the cure from Joker, and I spent forever trying to get the remote batarang to open a stupid door. Only to go on a gamefaqs forum and find out I was doing it the wrong way. Just moving through this game is infuriating. I don't care what any of these reviews say. This game makes you work WAY too hard in irritating mechanics mastery to get to the fun parts. It's more frustrating than it should be. Farther into the game, I stand by my rating.

Got 56% though this game and I still stand by my review, and to add even more irritation to the game, you can't proceed until you've solved the Riddler trophy mini-puzzles to get more hostages or additional side quests. I have absolutely no interest in stupid mini puzzles. You should be able to sidestep that part altogether. Boooo!
